So, you are god, the general. God gets to blast lasers from the sky to defend his chosen people. Your religion is to commit mass genocide. I think I won maybe 2 times so far. Great game, would not turn back time.
The one downside about this game is the dlcs, if you dont have money to spend you wont see the full scope of this game. 
Other than that, if you like military games and controlling actual armies in real time, seeing around 2000 soliders go after the enemy, this is for you. 
its so satisfying seeing your cavalry hiding among the tree lines, baiting your enemies in your kill zone, and seeing your cav units emerge and smashing the enemy. some good ole hammer and anvil. theres also all sorts of different playstyles depending on the faction you are playing. 
Ikit clawwwwwwwww yes yes! nuke time!

Game boasts unit variety, complicated cross faction diplomacy, a nice climate system that doesn't prevent settling locations but does hinders cities in them, and some of the best total war campaign AI.  

  The negatives being that you need the first game and DLC to really enjoy the game properly, but  certainly worthwhile on discount.  Eventually every faction starts to fell like the battles are getting repetitive and the skill system with the lords kind of exacerbates that since stacking up skills for a particular type of unit and filling your army with them is most effective.

Warhammer II is a masterclass in the marriage of grand strategy and immersive fantasy. As a long-time fan of both the Total War series and the Warhammer universe, this game surpasses expectations, delivering a captivating experience that keeps me hooked for hours on end.

The variety of factions and races is staggering, each with its own unique playstyle, units, and narrative. From the regal High Elves to the menacing Skaven, the attention to detail in both visuals and lore is commendable. Creative Assembly has truly brought the Warhammer world to life with meticulous craftsmanship.

The campaign map is a sprawling tapestry of diverse landscapes and settlements, offering a strategic depth that challenges even the most seasoned commanders. The introduction of the Vortex campaign adds a layer of urgency, driving the narrative forward and adding an extra dimension to the overall gameplay.

The battles, the heart and soul of any Total War game, are a spectacle to behold. The clash of colossal armies, magical spells, and legendary lords creates an exhilarating experience. The strategic depth of army composition, flanking maneuvers, and hero abilities ensures that every battle is a unique and engaging affair.

The addition of the Mortal Empires campaign, combining the maps of Warhammer I and II, creates an unprecedented playground for conquest. The sheer scale of this campaign is a testament to Creative Assembly's commitment to providing players with an epic and enduring experience.

While the game is a triumph, it is not without its minor flaws. The turn times in the later stages of the campaign can be a bit lengthy, and some factions may feel more challenging than others due to their starting positions and diplomatic situations. However, these are minor quibbles in the grand tapestry of Warhammer II's brilliance.

In conclusion, Total War: Warhammer II stands as a shining example of what can be achieved when two great franchises come together. It's a captivating blend of strategy, fantasy, and sheer epic scale. Whether you're a seasoned strategist or a newcomer to the series, this game is a must-play for anyone seeking an immersive and grandiose gaming experience.

Buckle up, folks, because we're about to dive headfirst into the twisted, exhilarating world of Total War: Warhammer II, a game that takes the concept of 'epic' and chucks it right out the window. Creative Assembly has managed to concoct a devilishly addictive concoction that combines the strategic finesse of the Total War series with the over-the-top, lore-drenched madness of Warhammer. It's like watching a barbarian horde crash a high society ball - chaos and entertainment ensue in equal measure.
Let's start with the main dish: the base game. Total War: Warhammer II isn't just a strategy game; it's a masterclass in world-building and faction design. The campaign map alone is a sprawling, meticulously detailed canvas that's more engrossing than an old wizard's spellbook. Whether you're rallying the stalwart forces of the High Elves or reveling in the sneaky, underhanded tactics of the Skaven, there's an exhilarating variety that keeps you glued to your seat, strategizing like a deranged warlord.
But hold onto your axes, because the DLCs take this experience and crank it up to eleven. From the blood-soaked escapades of 'The Queen and The Crone' to the spine-chilling battles of 'The Curse of the Vampire Coast,' each expansion feels like a shot of adrenaline straight to the heart. Creative Assembly doesn't just throw in a couple of new units and call it a day; they craft entire narratives, woven seamlessly into the fabric of the base game, complete with legendary lords that could give Sauron a run for his money.
The devil's in the detail, they say, and boy, does Creative Assembly understand that. From the intricately designed units to the immersive storylines and quests, every aspect of the DLCs feels like a meticulously crafted love letter to Warhammer enthusiasts. It's the kind of attention to detail that makes you want to grab the nearest battle-axe and charge into the fray alongside your virtual armies.
Total War: Warhammer II isn't just a game; it's a vortex of addictive gameplay and immersive storytelling that pulls you in and refuses to let go. With its intricate strategy, diverse factions, and a barrage of DLC offerings that feel more like expansions than add-ons, it stands as a testament to Creative Assembly's dedication to delivering a truly unforgettable gaming experience. It's the kind of game that reminds you why you fell in love with gaming in the first place - a wild, exhilarating ride that leaves you craving for more, even as your eyes droop from lack of sleep. It's a triumph, a roaring success, and by Sigmar's beard, it's a must-have for any self-respecting strategy enthusiast.

Many of the different lords in this game have great gimmicks that make each one fun, with every game there are certain lords and troops that feel similar but for the most part unique in their own way. This game has a massive roster of lords and troops and at 300hrs of game-play in and still finding more. While the overworld of the campaign is similar to Civilization the combat is RTS (But if your reading this you most likely already know this). If you are just getting into Total War Warhammer this is the best of the 3 in my opinion, 3 has some issues to work through but is still fun with the higher troop count and great graphics.

Very little in the way of an introduction of how to play.

It feels like an expansion to a game you should already know how to play, but don't. They don't explain how any of the basic functions of the game work; unit moral, strengths, weaknesses, how cities are built up or basic economy. They do tell you that High Ground is useful, but not how it works. They say that trees help hide troops, but don't show you what that means.

I'd like to get into this game; but the initial learning curve is steep, the game itself is sloooow to play. I don't have the hours of reading that apparently are required to learn what each thing means. I feel completely out of control of the game as it plays. My decisions make no difference.

Was thinking about buying WH3 but after reading the reviews I'll just stick to the Mortal Empires bread and butter. Not giving my money to a dirty company for a trashy expansion where my comments/feedback are treated as a revocable "privilege" after spending hundreds of dollars and thousands of hours. May their company get what they deserve. Play WH2, leave WH3 where it belongs - untouched, unloved, shunned.

This game is so unbalanced its unplayable.  The AI a fair distance off demands payments and even if you pay them they have a high chance to declare war anyway. allies will raid in your territory and you cant do anything about it but declare war on them to kill the raiding army.  10 turns into the game many factions have a full 20 stack of endgame units 
which you just cant fight without losing every time.  Every time i try to play this game i end up rage quitting when a group of elves walk through a mountain  with a 20 stack army, attack my army that is garrisoned in a city some how ignoring the walls/garrison completely while at the same time engaging in an ambush, which tell me how the hell that is even fair?? somehow the AI can have 3 20 stack armies without an economy to support them... ( max difficulty sure i understand but on normal????)
i have had allies with +50 opinion of my faction break the alliance and declare war for no reason whatsoever...  the game is just broken, save yourself the time. 
there are so many exploits too, sure i could use the diplomacy to get all the AI's resources turn 1 but i just wanna play without cheating/exploiting the AI.
i really want this game to be good but it just enrages me every time i play it.

Playing this should be outlawed. Another copy-paste total war with a bajillion of paid content. The gameplay is the same as in any other TW you're ever played. Nothing new here, except for maybe new visual effects/skins for the units. Very repetitive battles, extremely dumb AI that can't fight sieges at all. Out of all units why would they make ghosts climb the ladders instead of passing through the walls... Pseudo diversity of units, campaigns, and spells, with all of them being the same primitive copy-paste of one another. Most if not all of units have no variety of formations, unless we count the default front-facing box a formation. You'll have to download 50+ mods to at least make this game somewhat playable. This game is an excellent example of how this company sells its 'products' together with 38 DLC's, including "blood and gore". The only thing that keeps this game afloat is Workshop.

I'm sure others can find plenty more things to say about this opposition to intellect.

After this franchise repeatedly berates its customers for having opinions and views that are our god given right, over pricing DLC and game... selling us unfinished products and just general disdain for long term players of the game....

i find it hard to pay them any money or pay for anything at full price....
for example,  the winter sale 23 is on and i really want to play WHIII but I simply cannot pay for the game (even at 50% off), i have added it to my cart like 3 times... but when it comes to the purchase i am unable to hit the pay button... especially when i see that the other games have huge discounts (including their dlc)... 

im very happy with the game, but i still enjoy WHI WHII TW rome II and pretty much all of their releases since shogun II.... but god damn i will not shell out the asking price, when they treat their loyal customer base like this... and have the current marketing strategy that completely ignores your loyalty or the investments you've made in the past with them...

buy the older versions at 75% off including the DLC, play for hundreds of hours and wait for the games to hit the sales of 75% 

i mean sure it means i get to play with games that have been released two years after the masses... but you know what... most bugs have been dealt with, the games run smoothly, and i dont have to hate on CA anymore, because im no longer frustrated at them... these games at 75% are amazing value for money, and i play all of them regularly... including Napoleon!! 

after many years i have splurged on a computer that is (in my eyes) a beast, im about to go from playing on a laptop to a desktop, from everything at 20% graphics to full graphics.... my PC room is set up in the basement.... i am genuinely excited to increase my play time on these games... had to play earlier versions to avoid crashing my limited Pcs from the past.. but that is over now....

now its time to destroy everyone with xenophobic excitement and joy, destroying factions and races top my hearts content!

this is my two cents; thank you to all you players who pay full price and keep the franchise alive, I am unable to do so... the taste is just too bitter in my mouth, but god bless you out there... personally if you have limited cash, and love total war, buy on sale at 75% (did i say that already) Now im off to war, have a good one.

Really great game, tonnes of replayability. Been a fan of Total War since Medieval 1. Some of their games felt like factions were too similar to each other, and only varied with religion or starting location. Warhammer TW2 has so many asymmetric but roughly balanced races, and each faction within a race has its own mechanics. It gets a bad rep for DLC, but on sale they cost less than a coffee each and provide further hours of enjoyment.

I have been a fan of Total War series since Rome and appreciated the different historical settings and eras, but since I've always loved fantasy stuff as well I was eagerly awaiting a quality game that would be something like a combination of Total War and Warcraft and I finally got it with WH2.
The mix of 4x, RTS and RPG elements is fantastic, with first being less fleshed out and the following 2 being more prominent compared to other Total Wars, making it a slightly different experience which may not be for all TW fans. The sheer size of the map, faction, unit and area variety are mind-blowing. Different races and even sub-factions can have vastly different play styles and campaign experiences, which provides an insane amount of replayability.
Balance both in battles and on campaign map is decent, but it's only done to a degree where playing everyone is viable and not unfun. Some factions are clearly more powerful than others. Lords, heroes, units, armies, economy can become overpowered if you aim for that and know what you are doing. There are some silly good bonuses and exploits. This may sound bad at first, but I think it's exactly what makes TWWH2 so amazingly fun and not just a decent, impressive in scope game. You don't have to play like that if it's not up your alley, but all that room for different kinds of tinkering with your faction provides an extremely satisfying and unique experience.
CA may have made a lot of bad moves recently and deserved the backslash, but Warhammer 2 is finished and has been left in a very good state. I played countless RTS and 4x games from the last 20 or so years and this is undoubtedly my favourite.

I'm a Total War veteran thats been playing these games since the days of the first Shogun game, but no matter how hard I try to enjoy this one, no matter how many hours I pour into trying out every race or creating mods to improve gameplay to my liking, I just can't seem to enjoy it enough to get through even 1 full campaign. (Yeah I have a lot of hours on record but thats cumulative spread out over many years and mostly accounts for testing).

The unit variety and the different way each faction plays is great. I can't fault that part of the game. The problem is that gameplay is so prescribed. For every race you are told who your enemies are, when to attack them, which regions you should take and who you should not attack. Theres no strategy involved here in the campaigns. Its just endless turns of doing nothing but hitting the Next Turn button while you wait for buildings to finish and your faction's finances to grow. The battles themselves, when you finally get to them after many, many uneventful turns, are very fun but the campaign is just mind-numbingly boring on all modes.

Easily one of my favorite games of all time! The sandbox campaign experience of the Vortex and Mortal Empires maps offers nearly endless replayability, even if you're one of the many who will just replay Karl Franz 10-20 times. Each faction plays uniquely, and even the subfactions within each race can offer highly different campaign experiences. The game offers great battlefield tactical play and solid grand campaign strategy. The musical score is an absolute highlight, and greatly elevates the epic spectacle. And while I was initially drawn in by my Tolkien fanboy sense of wonder, I found the setting to be endlessly entertaining as well. So if your tastes run towards high fantasy with heavy undertones of grimdarkness (and a dash of Monty Python absurdity and nerd humor), you should definitely give this series a go.

This game is magnificent. Criticisms right off the bat: It feels like regardless of difficulty the game is playing for keeps right away. Not much time to acclimate to the rules and style of a new faction. Also there is a lot of information and if you don't like tutorials you'll need to be fast on the uptake.

But that's all the bad news there is. This game has complexity, strategy, not much random luck, and all the glorious character and background of the incredibly detailed Warhammer Fantasy setting. It's not the tabletop game to be sure: some units benefit from that. But the game is visually gorgeous and hella fun. I think my favorite part is that it's actually a dozen games in one, because each faction (and some subfactions) have their own styles, agendae, and even completely different economies. The game is hella replayable.

All the current controversy of the devs put aside, this game was very fun and challenging. I don't play much of the Total War series, but I played the previous Warhammer game and found this one just simply built upon it with a number of slight improvements. My only criticism is the price tag and incentive to own the previous game and all its dlc too, to get the best selection range for its combined campaign that throws both game's world maps into one epic one. Managing each faction gives you different mechanics to utilize and manage, changing up not only how you have to fight enemies but how you even plot and formulate your armies development plans. Newer elements like rites and plots, and with hero units influencing the map and armies on the move, its a lot to manage sometimes before you finally get down to fighting on a battle map but its all been fun to me. Probably not suggested for people who are not into turn based faction management, but if you liked Warhammer TW1 then this would be the next step.

Overall a pretty good game, but some key mecanics broke it all :

- The AI spam heroes in the map and send them to injured your heroes, break your walls, destroy your troops...
Past a cetain point, the AI heroes will be too high levels too even TRY to kill them, the game don't event allow you to try it.
In my instance, I found out in the late game about a faction with already too many high level heroes, I can't fight him at all, i'm soft lock against an enemy i never encountered earlier.

- The skaven faction can attack-ambush you, meaning they don't need to go to ambush and wait for you to fall in, they can litteraly attack you during their turn and ambush you. This is so stupid, because you have no way to defend against it !

- If you go to war with a faction, past a certain point you will never be able to get out of the war. There is no war attrition, meaning if you can't wipe out your oppenent, you will never be at peace with them again. The AI will never accept a peace treaty as long as it still have at least 2 remaining cities. I played a lot of strategy game, I have never seen this level of stupidity.

Honestly, I don't understand how a game released such a long time ago can still have this many core gameplay problems.

Despite some bad balance and lack of diplomacy features from other Total War games, Warhammer 2 is a great fantasy experience. Asymmetry abounds, there are a slew of valid playstyles supported by different races and factions, and the map is giant and full of crevasses to explore. The downsides? A lot of DLC if you want to play some of the factions. Elves are imbalanced. Plenty of the Warhammer 1 races like Bretonnia are outright bad. You will struggle for a while to get the feel for the game and its demands on you. The addition of RPG gameplay via Lords is a nice step up; past Total War generals tended to be picking some stat increases, while Warhammer generals can be their own one-man army if you build them out well.

Overall, it's a hilariously wacky playground of war and destruction that's guaranteed to make you rage and keep playing. Fits in with the best games in the Total War lineage.

This game is a bit older.  This does have the benefits that it is lower price than most of the other entries in the Total War Warhammer Series.  However, it still has an absolute mountain of DLC, to top it off, every time I click on a tutorial, the game breaks.  I can only conclude these tutorials are linked to some networked resource...that doesn't exist.

In terms of gameplay, it is quite similar to Total War Warhammer I (and III, although apparently III has things like charge bonuses which make melee units far more compelling.)  If you wanna buy *THIS* game *now* in 2024 you'll have to ask yourself a few questions, do you like Lizardfolk, Elves, or Skaven?  Do you like Warhammer Fantasy?  Do you like Lustria (The jungle where the Lizardfolk generally live).  If the answer to these questions is Yes, then you should probably pick up this game, for the sole fact that should you decide to buy Warhammer III later, you'll have access to those races.  Though, there's a few catches, Ikkit Claw and Throt the Unclean, who are probably the "best" Skaven legendary lords, are both DLC, and they're not even in the same DLC.  Though, you do get some pretty good "free" DLC like Grombrindal, Thorric, Whurrzaag, Imrik, Gor-Rok (arguable that he's the strongest single Hero in the game, in this game too.)  And the big one, Mortal Empires.  Mortal Empires *is* free, which is good at least, you have access to essentially all of the game except for a couple of characters and some of the factions.  Those factions will still spawn into the game so you do get to interact with them and if you're really good at diplomacy you could get an army of them potentially or have them as allies more likely.

Honestly though, considering how old this game is and how *much* DLC there is, and the seemingly broken tutorials, I honestly can't say I recommend this game.

I have had and am still having a blast with this game. In my eyes it is currently the better TWWH experience for multiple reasons. The game has fewer bugs, a more consistent design, a more stable modding ecosystem and it frequently goes on sale. You have nothing to lose by slowly building up your WH2 collection and then eventually moving to WH3 in 2 years once all the major concerns have been addressed (or it goes on sale). The DLCs and content will carry over so you don't have anything to lose.

The game on its own is great. Mortal empires provides nearly unlimited amount of funs, I'm probably a thousand hours in (this account plus another) and I consistently come back every few months to try another campaign. The game design is pretty tight and the powercreep is still relatively under control. Like with all TWWH games, definitely recommend picking up on sale. You can also raw dog it and just buy everything if you have the budget.

Warhammer 3 is a dumpster fire.  I was content with just avoiding that title until CA decided that they own the rights to all free speech about that game.  Now, I'm going to take the time to write this here, because you morons have earned it.

Positive reviews are a privilege, one reserved for companies that embrace their player base.  Your petulant demands, (not-so) veiled threats, and condescending attitudes have cost you dearly.  Understand that for every player like me that took the time to write you, another hundred have just quietly taken their business elsewhere.  I've seen CA make missteps before, and they usually found a way to make things right.  This, however, is not a misstep.  This is a blatant double-middle-finger salute to the people that allow your company to exist.  Now, you're gonna get that same energy back.

You have lost the business of a loyal customer that has been buying and playing CA games since the original launch of Medieval.  Your conduct should be embarrassing to you, both personally and professionally.  However, since you don't seem to understand anything but money, hear this.  You will never receive another penny from me, or anyone that I am able to stop from buying your products.  As loyal of a customer as I have been, I will be equally loyal as an opponent of your practices.  

Shame on you.

[h3]Customer warning.

SEGA does not allow its customers to buy this game, own it, and play it offline at their own leisure. Total War Warhammer II is, for all intents and purposes, an "Always-Online" service.[/h3]

That is because of DENUVO. Which is the Digital Rights Management (DRM) software that is bundled with this product.

DENUVO forces you to link the product that you purchased (which should rather be your own property, for you to do with as you please) to DENUVO's online servers. Then it forces the product that you purchased, and that you therefore should fully own, to "call home" regularly to that server. This, in perpetuity. Whenever DENUVO is not able to call home, you are not able to use nor access the product that you purchased anymore.

If you must go offline for any amount of time, you are not able to play a game you supposedly own (surprise. As it turns out, you were simply renting it to a landlord, as it were).

DENUVO serves no purpose to the customer. On the contrary, DENUVO weakens the customer's rights to own the products, any product, that they purchase. DENUVO effectively assumes control and ownership of any product it is associated with. That control and ownership should be the customer's.

SEGA is voluntarily selling its customers a defective product.

One which its customers cannot own, one which cannot be the property of SEGA's customers.

One which, once it has been legally purchased by the customer, nevertheless actually remains the property of SEGA and DENUVO.

I didn't think I'd like Total War: Warhammer series that much compared to the historical titles. I have come to like the fantasy aspect quite a bit. The series adds a lot of new concepts to the battles, such as playing with spell casters, flying units, and monster sized creatures. I'm a Total War player, not a Warhammer fan, though I do have some other Warhammer games by coincidence as an RTS player. As such, I have a little, but not much, knowledge of the story lines in the Warhammer universe.

Specifically with Warhammer II, I at least like some of the Total War tweaks to diplomacy. Your allies don't turn around and stab you in the back every chance they get. You're also not bombarded by requests from allies to join their wars 4 times between turns... every single turn. This game isn't heavy into diplomacy, but at least some of the AI decision making has moved away from the ridiculous attacks from puny trusted allies that leads to their destruction at your hands 5 turns later.

As with just about every Total War game I can think of, your enemies will take advantage of any situation to gang up on you with 2-3 of their armies against one of your own. While only one enemy army may be in range to attack on their own, they will bring in another army as reinforcements as long as they can get in range through forced march. This can make the game a bit of a slog, as the AI gets their usual Total War that allow them larger militaries than players could have with the same territorial area.

This is one of those easy to learn/lifetime to master titles. With a double digit number of mage types for the High Elves alone, it's tougher to keep track of what tools you have in your elven toolkit to tackle your opponents. The spells are all over the place, and the icons to at least tell you what type of spell is represented by icons on the screen take a lot of getting used to. 

The battles can be a little hectic, and you really have to watch what you are doing, unless you want multiple units heavily damaged by various types of spells with area attacks. Sometimes you just have to eat them anyways, as you can't always disengage from your fights and move out of spell range before the skies open and death comes from above.

Do not waste your money on this game. This is yet another cash grab by Sega. Can it be fun? Yes for a little, but is hardly worth the price, requires DLC, and the fun is short lived as the campaign isn't much more than, fight, take some land and fight again.

It was a lot of fun for a short time after its release. I never finished it though because after a certain point in the game, it just feels too repetitious and the pace of progression feels too daunting. The real-time battles in the Total War franchise have the unique ability to satisfy that recurring itch for a movie-like, large scale, medieval combat experience unlike any other. Total War: Warhammer II merely adds a new set of updated skins, improved graphics, and a wide variety of heroes. The heroes in the Warhammer series are, at least for me, the main attraction of the game. They are definitely a lot of fun to control as they mow down horde after horde of armies, all the while growing ever stronger. 

There's also a notable number of really fun mods available for the game. The modding community for these warhammer games is really great, and they add a considerable amount of replay value. Even though I didn't finish the campaign, I would confidently give it a solid 88/100. And after 252 hours of time spent playing, I can happily say I've already received my money's worth. It's a lot of fun for sure, but if you're like me, you'll eventually find yourself craving something new before ever reaching the finish line.

Overall I think it's a great game. The vast array of different units, animations and details in the animations is very cool. I like that I don't have to micro manage provinces but they still provide a slight challenge to keeping them happy and your economy strong. The game runs fairly smoothly even on my lower end PC and I haven't come across any breaking bugs. I've always loved the idea of commanding large armies of fantasy units and this game definitely scratches that itch. 

Cons: I'm not a massive fan in lord abilities/powers in battles, I'm not saying it shouldn't exist but shouldn't be so strong. The price of all the packs/DLC, yes I know you don't need them. Don't get me started on buying the blood pack. Another nit pick and maybe I just haven't found it yet is the ability to trade regions/provinces in diplomacy. In Total War: Empire this is a thing. I had a grand plan of giving a couple provinces to my allies to secure my borders to the west only to come home from work and find out that I can't do that. 

If your on the fence on this game I would say get it. I'm definitely not done playing it.

Won the Asur campaign by domination victory (50 provinces) but you would eventually get closer to finish it by Vortex too. I'd suggest first to immediately engage in diplomacy with all elves factions in Ulthuan and help one of them (Chrace or Yvresse likely) to obtain the "Sword of Khaine". Subsequently increase positive outlook through "Intrigue at Court" towards you so that to merge with this faction and obtain the access to the sword which you will immediately give to Tyrion. Later in the campaign you could incur in rebellions in provinces so start immediately to create "Plaza" in each settlement so to give it public order +2. Trying to catch settlements in the Chaos Wastelands is easy but you will need a Lord per each settlement to cope with public order and corruption, so hard to manage. Focus on diplomacy to keep Araby under control and have Pirates of Sartosa and Dreadfleet engaging with Bretonnia and Tomb Kings factions. Send Tyrion oversea to capture Naggarond and Hag Graef entering by the Sea of Malice. Eventually once fought the Dark Elves you will likely have to fight Lizardmen in Lustria. Try not to allow them to quickly merge into a single powerful faction.

As a huge fan of the franchise in generall (combined over a 2000 h), i¬¥m very disapointed by this game title. I became wearry of waiting for a true historical title so i decided to buy the game on sale shortly before pharo was launched. Admittetly, i didnt play every faction and every Lord and currently have ~80h on this Game. Appart from offering a Fantasy setting, there were no real inovations to any of the relevant systems (popualtion, recourses, Happiness, Generals, Army traditions etc). Sure there is magic, which i interpret as a widening of the Generals combat Abilitys. Character Traits which failed to meaningfully impact the game.  Settlement management felt extremly one dimensional and thus a chore. Campainmap at first glance was huge, but on my third playthrough was one dimensional as well. It lacks the chair-binding-effect of having to survive one more huge siege battle like in Shogun 2, Med 2 or even Rome 2. In short, a lot of visuals, no real Addition.

[b] Definetly not worth full price, and i cant stress how much the trend of deniying faction access behind a pay wall for DLC¬¥s is in my humble oppinion a malpractice. [/b]  

I miss the good old days beating the Medievall 2 campain and unlocking additional factions just to beat the grandcampain again with them.
It feels creatively bankrupt since the first title had the same factions anyway (this is the only point i¬¥m unsure of since i dont onw the first title) like a Saga title, not expanding the game in depth. Unit rosters are fairly small, no real mercenary system like in older titles, which leads to a underwhelming Game experience.

All in all, besides not beeing to much a fan of the fantasy genere in itselfe- i disslike this Game for the aforementioned reasons and the direction the Studio decided to take for the better part of a decade. I really hope this gets turned over, or i will quitt buying CA titles all together.

One of the best total war games there is.

I would say, if you like this.
Pick up
-Warhammer 1 + Any relevant DLC
(Warhammer 1 and 2 actually unlocks content in Warhammer 2. You basically get a combined map of both games, and they play in Warhammer 2)
-Warhammer 2 DLC
Other total war games
-Shogun 2 total war (Not fantasy, instead its a REALLY good historical total war)
-Shogun 2 Fall of the Samurai (Most modern total war game there is.)
-Rome 1 Remastered
-Rome 2 total war
-Atilla total war (This may depend on the person. For me its really tough campaigns, and I enjoy that.)
-Napoleon total war
-Medieval 2 total war is another good one, but its starting to show its age.

Rome 1 total war is a bit rough on new systems, same with Shogun 1, Medieval 1, and to a lesser extent Empire total war. Empire is just a buggy mess but its a gem. A rough gem but still a good gem.

Anyways, I love Warhammer 2. I will always love this game.
I would avoid Warhammer 3 as it doesn't bring much to the table, especially with the recent behavior of the developers. (Banning people from the total war forums for ANY negative critique, and of course threatening to not support the games you bought from them if you don't buy their dlc. Only other thing I will say on this subject is this, remember Total War: Three Kingdoms. They dropped it without notice and the community was left stunned, not angry, just stunned and worried that their favorite developers (who were never perfect, but they made amazing games and they generally tried to be well liked) just dropped support on a recent game. We wondered if they were okay or if something bad had happend. That was in fact, some early signs that this team may have well lost their way. And that's a real shame.

All in all, I love these games and I wish the team members behind these gems are doing well. I hope they find their way back to the right path, fans and dev teams walking in line with each other.

Do note, the modding community is strong, the community is strong. The content creators that love this series are honest. Folks like Jon from Many a True Nerd, or LegendofTotalWar are great folks to watch for good and honest opinions. Both of them love the series, they just love the series differently. And that's just fine, I love them both and they are both correct in their views I think.

So that's my rant. This game is great and 90% of the total war games before it are amazing too.
The ones that are not are just getting unplayable due to age, or they were made unplayable by being abandoned. Troy, and Thrones of Britannia are both just okay total war games. As far as I know (Though I have not played it) Pharaoh is much in the same camp as the other two. They are okay.

I've been playing Total War since I was in middle school when it came out in 2004 and I was 11 years old.  Back then, my favorite past-time was just seeing how big of an army of peasants I could beat with 1 unit of roman elites.  I spent countless hours messing around in battles, listening to heroic speeches (and cheating at the game because I was 11 and didn't quite get the campaign).

I was pumped beyond belief when I heard Rome II got announced and bought it immediately (in my Freshman year of college, boy how time flies) only to not be able to play it because of how broken it was on launch.  But it got fixed and countless more hours were spent and finally some campaigns beaten.

In that time I've also played Shogun 2, Empire, Medieval 2, 3k, Thrones, Warhammer I & 2 & 3 (Check my steam library, they're all there).  I even bought the Remastered version just because I love Total War.

And now, I will never, ever, ever do that again due to their ridiculous downfall.  Stop releasing bad games and silencing dissent.  Absolutely ridiculous this even needs to be said.

The game has a great presentation and is technically sound (runs great and I haven't really noticed any bugs), but the AI cheats and snowballs in such an extreme manner you'll be more frustrated than anything else. I get that this was intended to counter how often players get too big to fail by the midgame in Total War games, but the measure taken here has swung the balance into the other extreme. Even in lower difficulties, be prepared to turtle up against several doomstacks which the AI spawns out of thin air and get used to cheesy battle tactics. This game is a classic example of something that all technically works but needs more balance tweaking to be good.

I cannot recommend any CA published game at this time due to the malicious way that the company and has treated its consumer base in recent years. CA has essentially banned criticism of them or their products within the steam forums for their games. They insist if one must be critical of the game that they provide a solution to fix the problem. This is nigh impossible for me as I am not a software developer or well-versed on how these games work under the hood. Therefore my advice on how to fix things must instead be focused on the need to engage constructively with the fan base, not alienate people who have spent hundreds of dollars on their games over the years, and been the base of the company's success over the last two decades. I also suggest that DLC prices moving forward be reduced to reflect the paucity of value they provide to the game. Additionally I would greatly appreciate new content to reflect what has been promised to consumers in the past (3k scrapped DLC). If anyone at CA or their parent company SEGA wants to discuss further suggestions I have I invite them to message me. I would be happy to have a constructive chat on why I have felt unwilling to purchase recent releases from what has historically been my favorite video game series.

Here is the reason why my review is changing. CA shit the bed with the release of TW Warhammer 3. I was unhappy with the release so I refunded the game, and figured I'd re buy if the game eventually reached a state that I would be happy with. There were a few times where I considered buying it, but I held off. Now I probably won't buy anything from CA ever again. They announced a DLC called Shadows of Change for $25. it is not worth that much content wise, and when the community dared to push back on such an absurd price they made a post that essentially threatened us. Buy the DLC or we won't be able to support the game in the future. Which is what happened to TW Three Kingdoms. CA released several sub par DLCs that didn't sell as many as they wanted, so they showed that they will 100% pull the plug. A little bit after that backlash CA announced that they were canning Hyenas, some ugly as sin extraction hero shooter, and it is reportedly CA's most expensive project ever. That tells me that they knew that the game was going to be cancelled and that they're trying to squeeze as much money from TW Warhammer fans to make up for the terrible decisions that the higher ups made.

I will not support CA at all anymore. Unfortunately it will be the developers that will be punished, but I hope that they can find better companies to work for. This whole situation sucks.

As a total war game this fails on every measure. Entire game revolves around a meta wherein you spam heroes/abilities/monsters that smash into enemy lines. The game is the pinnacle of style over substance wherein you have lots of flashy colours and units which hide the fact that there's no real military strategy at work in your battles. Combat is effectively one massive MOBA game rather than a strategy game like TW is supposed to be. I would advice going back to a game like Shogun 2 or RTW, this isn't worth your money ($72 CDN 6 years after release with legions of DLC which are collectively twice the price of the base game).
I prefer historical Total War, but damn this is one of the best games yet.

I used to recommend with passion all previous Total War titles to my friends, but sadly Clown Assembly, led by the likes of psychopath Rob Bartholopuke and other greedy corporate lemmings, have torpedoed this once fantastic franchise into the dirt. Total War is a dying series with antiquated tech, deluded and denuded scumbag management, and a slew of other issues that are unlikely to ever be addressed. It's truly unbelievable how out of touch CA are with their fanbase. I feel terrible for the developers who did their best to save Warhammer but had their efforts thwarted by clueless and soulless executives.

Live by your threats and pull the plug on TW:Warhammer, Rob. Perhaps you can try funding another cringe Hyenas-like project when you squeeze the last bit of florins out of TW. The RTS community is fortunate that up-and-comer Bamboo Games' Ancient Warfare has great potential to replace your dying franchise. Time will soon tell.

I'm sorry, but after years of owning it and trying to give it a solid chance, I'm afraid it's just so dense that if you didn't have depression before, a game like this is sure to give it to you in onset. It's too expansive, there's a million buttons, the brain feels mightily stretched out trying to manage units, understanding what each thing does for (how many people now)... I could barely get into playing Queek Headtaker, and even then, it seems that I continously take out the Fortress of Dawn elves with ease, and right at that moment the Quetgar, *every time*, catches me overextended and wipes me without a chance to get back to base, even though the in-game tutorial is spamming me with "do this, My Lord- do that, my lord, shake hands with this bot to be safe my lord, don't mess with the dark elves my lord" ...if anyone's seen Emporer Palpatine from Robot Chicken, the part where he's going down the escalator and continuously has to acknowlege each stormtrooper cynically until a freak-out happens from all the, "my lord, my lord, my lord"... this is a simulator game to understand why Palpatine from that hilarious episode short was that grumpy and grouchy- it's way too much. I never beat this game, I remember one day two years ago I spent 12 hours straight trying to do the Vortex main campaign and just- UGH, I couldn't win by barely and it was honestly the most depressing thing imaginable, I don't know how Dungeons and Dragons gets away with it- *12 hour-games* just to lose the whole entire campaign, no reverting saves or re-doing, and if you play legendary mode, you can't save at all. The in-game fights feel bland for something that's supposed to be massive and grande and theatrical- it's so many units but you can barely see any units inter-personally finishing each other off: it just looks more like sprites slashing in the middle of the air until one side slowly loses one random sprite at a time. It takes forever to build up, and by then it's three hours later and your time to game is probably up. Who really wants to save and then return to it later? I don't. Re-load it, even with massive ram and a decent graphics card this game takes *forever* to load the campaign and then 1/2 as long to load manual fights, but it's still meh for waiting times. I feel I do more waiting to watch a videogame play itself with this videogame than i am actually playing the videogame. 

If you are *really* into Warhammer Lore, like reading the books, paints the figurines, visits the IRL stores for merch, big into the stories, and want the game for novelty and aesthetic? Yeah buy it, and go round and round and play it like, a million times, I'm sure there's someone who looks in the mirror, sees a Total War Warhammer II turbosweat, and want's that classic Netflix-Style, Stranger Things 1985-esque 12-hour-games of dungeons-and-dragons-with-their-homies-to-feel-the-glory-of-earned-victory type nostalgia. Of course hardcore fanatics will buy this game and really appreciate the obvious replayability and even-more-obvious bragging rights if this game is trending among your friends group and you win it. For those folks that only have 3-6 hours a day to play a variety pack of fun, speedy, quick game and think this is the next one they can buy and juggle their other favorites with, I'm afraid this game is screaming, "you can't balance me and your other games, it's either ONLY me or none of me and you're other games". 

In conclusion, don't buy this game if you're alone in the world and game-hunting. Buy it only if you're begged to do so by your favorite small group of best friends, or if you're a matchmaker and gamemaker, and want to beg your friends for months to buy this with you until they do, but don't purchase and play solo because you'll regret it, mostly because much like League of Legends, you'll watch a guide on how to play with your one favorite champion, lose so much that you question your venture into its' world and then won't touch it ever again after a final immemorable loss of the campaign. Warhammer Vermintide 2 is a more arcade-style experience that will still expose you to the brutality of simulated medieval fantasy war, push your system to its' limits, and will queue you in, munch you through a game and spit you out in 20 minutes. I honestly can't stand this 12-hour play-me-obsessively-so-1-neuron-feels-dopamine-out-of-the-99,999,999,999-other-neurons-that-feel-depressive-disorderly-dread-and-constant-worry-about-my-units-type, oh-no-i-made-one-error-in-two-seconds-now-its-gonna-cost-me-10-hours type games. Between you the reader and me the author, Company Of Heroes 2 is about as RTS as I can handle mentally until it's too big to feel like you'll ever master it in 10 years, too UI-heavy to feel like you'll ever understand the real weight of each button ever, and so dense that the illusion becomes transparent- a purchaseable RTS game that runs longer than an hour *on steam* needs to have homework done on it before a purchase is made because of the two-hour-maximum playtime refund policy. I used to enjoy buying videogames at the face and just seeing what they had to offer, but thanks to design styles like these, *only when it's end-game 10 hours later* do you realize "you know something...I don't like this game", but *hey, you can't refund because steam policy lul*.... if I could refund kindly, I would, because as I said, nothing against the diehard fans of this franchise. But, I can't, and considering how the game became more annoying than entertaining, with all the computer-part-buying it took to finally run this game just for the gameplay to finally just leave me with a pout and dissatisfaction, I would steer people away unless you're wealthy. If you're wealthy, disregard all and buy for novelty. But, if you're budgeting for your next new game and don't want to make a mistake, I'm sure you'll see just how much learning this game takes, unfairly too much imo, and then you'll shrug with ease and move on. It's too hard. So hard, Easy Mode can't be beaten? that's just *too* hard.

In hindsight, maybe if you speedrun your new games at first to test their consistency, you could see for certain if this game is your thing or not, but this isn't a speedrunnable game lest it loses its cinematic novelty and then after a speedrun of this game, you'll *really* say no and refund.

Either way, you find out that it's unhealthy to put your eggs in one basket, and sitting down to try and play this thing through and through *one time* is definitely that. If there's dissatisfaction this bad, if I wrote out this much, if I went to the nerd-like lengths to repulse the game and show distaste for it, it should strike you as "do not purchase unless begged, gifted for free, or purchased on massive discount".

I hope all this helps.

Look, I'm loving this game. But can we discuss the fact that WHEN EVERYTHING IS ON SALE you're paying $94.86 (At time of writing) across 2 games to get all the DLC? And do keep in mind that is prior to the $71.99 CAD for the base game and the $71.99 CAD for the original game. Which means that for me to get the actual full experience from TWW2, i would be spending $238.84 CAD. On a Single Game ( I will accede, a game and a half). Without any Collectors Items.  I just did a quick google search on things I could buy with 280$. Here are a few of the results;
1: a 55' 4k Smart TV from TCL
2: an MJS BUGS 2SE Drone
3 An eddie Bauer Parka.
4: concert tickets
5: a refurbished 500GB Xbox one. 

Any of the above things can be purchased for 280$ or less, and they were just the first things to show up in my searching. Frankly, I have an issue when I can buy a New TV for the price of a complete gaming experience with just one game. even if that TV is objectively cheap.

Even if we take the original and it's DLC out, before taxes we're looking at $54.30 CAD. again, the base game is $71.99. It seems a bit excessive to me to have created so much content (or cut so much out of the base game) that the DLC ON SALE is 2/3rds of the price of the game. Not to mention that when its not on sale, the DLC for TWW2 Alone totals in $89.43 CAD before taxes. LITERALLY MORE THAN THE BASE GAME ITSELF!!!!! 

There's something not right about that.......

This game has always been one of my favorite games since the first came out. That being said, WARHAMMER takes total war to a whole new level because of access to mythical creatures and Heros that can take on entire regiments of units. This basically opens up the game to where you aren't just stuck with infantry, calvary, and missile units.

I have bought all of the DLC when they were on sale. They are not required to play the game and have fun, but it definitely adds to the game, maybe a little over priced.  They open up additional strategies, however the base game has some of the most powerful strategies already available. My guess as to most of the bad reviews recently is the fact that people feel left out because they don't have access to all of the DLC, and need to pay a lot of money. Again, wait until they go on sale. They usually do multiple time a year.

If you love Warhammer Fantasy or 40k this game is a must have. Get all 3 if you want the whole experience. Highly recommend. I've been into Warhammer since I was a little kid and I have to say this is one of the best strategy games out there.

AI Cheats on every difficulty. You can make it about 30-40 turns before the AI cheating snowballs into you getting attacked from all sides. These games are DLC cash grabs with the same base engine.

If you take the same number of troops to a fight the AI just won, you will take substantially more losses or outright be defeated. When you take a settlement you get 25% of the gold that the AI gets. The AI can muster forces twice as fast as you on every difficulty. 

You cannot make troops without a lord so you're handicapped even harder by income and the AI backdooring your undefended settlements (because you cannot place a few troops in each settlement to defend because lords are too expensive)

For anyone just getting into Warhammer Total War, enjoy the rabbithole you're about to go down.

This is obviously a sequel.  There's a big campaign in this game that combines this games factions with the previous game's factions on one big map called Mortal Empires, but you have to own the first game AND this one.  You can buy this game by itself and play a smaller campaign called the Vortex campaign.  It's a bit different from regular total war campaigns and it's controversial among fans.  My recommendation would be to buy this one and the first game together so you can jump into Mortal Empires.  

This does mean that the best experience is $120 starting price plus.  Any DLC you buy from either Warhammer 1 or 2 is then unlocked in Mortal Empires as well.  This is quite expensive for the average person but the good news is these games are a bit older now.   On steam sales I've seen both the base games on sale for 50% or even 75% off.   That gets the combined games at or below $60 total.  Much more reasonable as a starting point.   And considering the number of hours of fun this game delivers you're going to get incredible value for money if you enjoy this game.   

That said, if you've already enjoyed total war games, or enjoy strategy games in general, I've very confident you'll love Warhammer 2.  It really is one of the best in the business.  Every faction plays completely differently on the campaign map and in the real time battles.   And the game is brimming with cool units to play with.   My personal favorites are the Empire with it's steam tanks, hellfire rocket batteries, and rifles.   And Bretonnia, a more primitive medieval faction that fields Grail Knights with their gleaming lances, Trebuchets, and Grail Reliques - the desecrated corpses of heroes being carried around by peasants to inspire other units.  Don't ask it just  works.  

Be aware as well that there is a lot of anger at the publisher CA about the third game Warhammer 3.  There have been a few people taking it out on CA in this games reviews as well about the publishers pricing strategies and greed.  While these are not invalid complains, as I mentioned these games go on sale regularly since they're older.   So you can jump in around Christmas or Summertime at a reasonable price and get stupidly high numbers of hours if you're into the game.   Warhammer 3's base game is leaner than this one was at launch so just take your time with this one instead.  Enjoy it and wait for Warhammer 3 to sort itself out.   

Have a lovely day if you made it this far, and enjoy yourself.

Total Warhammer II is definitely one of the greatest strategy games out there. The campaigns are fun, interesting and engaging from start to finish, the battles are rich with detail and strategy, and the campaign map and turn based aspect are done well. Warhammer II looks really good on high graphics setting, and the attention to detail on maps and models is amazing. The unit control, combat, missiles and spells feel really well done and flow nicely. All in all, a very well polished game that is easy to enjoy for both hardcore strategy enjoyers, or the casual. My critiques are the state of the turn based aspect and DLC's. For a game about Total War and epic battles. there is an awful lot of diplomacy, economy and city-building involved. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, and some people might enjoy the way it works, but I play the game for the strategy in battle, not on the map, and I feel like I spend most of my time debating what economy buildings I should construct, carefully considering diplomacy, trying to trade with foreign nations, deciding how I should research technologies, and more. Is it well designed system? Yes. Is it what I want out of a game about 'Total War'? Not really. Second, the DLCs. Warhammer II has 5 or 6 completely free playable factions and 18-ish playable lords, which is certainly enough to satisfy most casual players. The problem is, Warhammer is a big game with many aspects that go unexplored when you are a F2P player. There are whole new ways to play when using other Lords and factions, but each new bit of content must be payed for separately as a DLC. Such a DLC reliant system when it comes to new content means that, unless you are buying new DLCs, the game can get dry, fast. I am happy to spend money on DLCs if I really want the content, but it's an option few have after purchasing the base game. In my opinion, they need to either implement sales, or free to play weekends with the DLC's to give us more incentive to lock in a purchase, or lob some of the DLC's together into single, bigger packs of content.

Other than the turn-based tediousness and DLC craze, Warhammer II is in a really nice spot, and a great game definitely worth playing.

Classic Total War gameplay with Warhammer Fantasy factions and units, reworked and fleshed out amazingly well. If you're one of the people who liked your generals progressing in previous iterations of Total War this game takes that above and beyond to the point where it can almost be called an RPG game. I'm a guy who collected relics in MTW2 for my kings and made sure to pass them over to the heir before the King died. I really hope they take some RPG elements from this game with them for future TW games even historical ones. 

I used to dream about Warhammer in Total War when me and my friend played Shogun and Medieval Total War(1) as a kid. This is basically that dream come true, including everything CA learned from having decades of experience in the genre and the series. I'd honestly consider this a must buy for both Total War and Warhammer fans. Any strategy fan should get it too. The first game was also AMAZING and can be bought cheap on sale now. If you're short on cash grab that one. But I'd really just buy both of them to be able to play the merged campaign map Mortal Empires which is a MASSIVE map where you can play as any faction from the 2 games. I only play Mortal Empires now really.

It's honestly one of the best games out there and settles your itch for Grand Strategy, RTS and RPG at the same time with great execution in each regard. Perhaps it could be even more RP options hehe but thats a personal opinion. 

Buy it, you won't regret it!

Usually trilogies follow the format: Middle, worse, best, but Warhammer total war seemed to do the opposite: middle, best worst. 
This game is by far the most fun of the three and the most interesting. TWWH1 was great, but felt more like just a sandbox conquest. The campaign style in the second game of the series adds a much needed depth. I think I've sunk more hours in to this Total war than any other. Still one of my favourite games.

Okay, this is my third review revision and I am going to recommend the game. But in doing so, I definitely want to make clear that this game can be quite difficult, even on standard difficulty settings. It took me a long time to understand the many nuances of the game enough to successfully complete a campaign. Before that, I sunk a lot of hours into playing campaigns that I ultimately lost.  More often than not, I play video games to unwind after a stressful day, so I'm not typically looking for a herculean challenge when booting a game up.

With all that said, once you do get the hang of things, the challenge becomes more entertaining, instead of the head banging against the keyboard thing it felt like during the first 40 or so hours of playtime. 

To understand some of my concerns with the game, I left my original review below.

ORIGINAL REVIEW OF TW: WARHAMMER II
Problem with this game is that I just don't find it very fun.  It has an annoying propensity to generate deathstacks,  which essentially eliminate hours of planning on your part.

I've played the game with three different races and it pretty much works out the same way every time. Plan strategy, build up an army, run short of resources and then get crushed by a deathstack. 

Just not a lot of fun. The point of a game is to provide a fun environment to solve challenges, not waste hours of your time on pointless challenges.

Update 7/20: I gave the game another shot, after loading Warhammer 1 and I found it's just not as much fun or balanced as the first game. If you like a fast-paced, chaotic-style strategy game, this could be for you. But the insane pace of advancement and death stacks just gets tiring after a point and it seems the point of the game eventually just becomes building a doomstack of your own so you can repeatedly auto resolve combat encounters in your favor against more numerous forces. Just not a ton of fun for me. Still a thumbs down.

Monetisation policy is dumb asking higher and higher prices for new DLC's while only stripping the game to its bare minimum they think is acceptable.

Furthermore the game features many imbalances (always the same factions that get strong (Greenskins, Etaine, Couronne) and the same factions which get destroyed ez (Vampire Counts, Skaven, Vampire Coast). Chaos invasion is a joke right now on TWW2 (gets destroyed easily by the strong factions I just mentioned). Autoresolve is broken (seems to favour amor and ranged heavily, which may also be the cause of the fact always the same factions rise to power because the auto resolve will always be in their favour, because of their unit roster.

And lastly, the AI is (even though this game is from 2017 and TWW3 2022), the AI system seems from decades ago. It is not smart and easy to bait, on the higher difficulties uses al kinds of cheap cheats to 'be a challenge' and battle AI always has exactly the same approach to a fight in several scenario's. Furthermore you have the human bias. AI seems to prioritise focusing the human player in such an obvious way it really gets to me (sometimes is willing to nuke it's own existence just to be aggressive to the human player).

Long story short: game has too many flaws and CA monetisation approach is shameful. It's just not worth it anymore

Original positive review below the line.

If you're buying this to play the Vortex campaign, or Mortal Empires, go ahead: it's a great experience.  If you're buying it as DLC for Total War: Warhammer 3, I recommend not buying it.  CA breaks chunks of their DLC every time they release new DLC, and then [i]do not[/i] fix it.

***************************

Yes, you have to buy Total War: Warhammer to have access to the Mortal Empires campaign.  No, I don't see that as a reason to downvote this game.  The game is, in and of itself, a great game.

In terms of mechanics, it builds very well upon the first title in the trilogy and goes even further in differentiating the races.  The Vortex campaign is a relative departure for the series in having a goal-focused campaign rather than an open-ended sandbox, but in reality, the Vortex campaign can also be treated as a campaign sandbox if you so choose.

The extra "thank you" from CA for buying both games (I & II) in the otherwise free Mortal Empires DLC is a glorious thing; the largest and most varied campaign that CA have ever created.  It has bugs and balance issues, and Norsca (from the first game) is taking a disappointingly long time in being integrated properly, but it's still a wonderful way to lose hours of your playtime.

This review has been switched to negative due to predatory actions of CA and their mods deleting anything that opposes their new overprised worthless DLC.

This 25 dollar DLC features 12 unit models, 3 lords from already existing sides and some basic mechanics that are absolutely not worth the price. As I said in my previous unfairly deleted post, I am a working adult in US, 25 dollars is not the issue, the amount of content we are getting for 25 dollars is. Imagine, base game that is 50 dollars has several sides, dozens of lords, 100 of unit models, so how is it that a bunch of unpopular legendary lords and few units cost HALF the price of base game?!

Even more realistically does this amount of effort amount to this price? If you can get a brand new AAA game for 70 dollars? Can anyone actually agree that this DLC with few months of effort is worth 25 dollars while CA isnt even finished fixing the bugs and issues the game already has? This is a blatant insult to the community and a corporate cash grab. 

If we allow this to happen once, this will set the new standard for DLC, instead of giving us what we would pay 25 dollars for, like Nagash, Ind, Nippon they will keep spawning these 25 dollar pathetic lord packs expecting us to consume. Dont forget that a game is a business, they want to do least amount of effort for most amount of profit, this is exactly that, least amount of effort DLC.  

I am not a troll, or CA hater, I have every DLC, my account is open take a look how many hours I invested into this franchise, I am what they should be targeting a super fan of the franchise. I am all for supporting CA and buying DLC that have worthy content, but if this is their new tactic, sell overpraised junk and silence anyone who speaks against it? Forget it. I got all I need and I rather give my money to the modders. 

Since I see that CA is actively seeking their moderator dogs to silence the community, I will also be switching my review to negative for the time being with this exact message as the review.

I am a 54 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my child, who is 14 now. My child got this game last Christmas in 2021 from their uncle, so we installed it on their computer and they started playing. By the end of the week they had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my child, as they are always out with their friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside them. I loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my child for help and they invited me to a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my child since my ploycule died. This game has ever since brought me and my child closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my child many happy memories.

its fun

Although I do not bear great trust with the company - with the long-lasting high prices and increasingly expensive DLCs - I cannot doubt that this is the best RTS experience I've tried. A wide range of viable tactics, storied and beautiful units, and 

I second everyone's opinion that Mortal Empires is best if you can pick up TW1 on sale (although Vortex is perfectly fine) - and will include that, for me, after a few playthings - I added the 'double upkeep cost'. Battles become far scrappier and desperate - 6 low-level units out-maneuvering eachother, for much of the mid-game. Without it, you will quickly have max-size armied with the best units, and only fight opponents with the same. Fun, but every battle become a grand escapade on equal footing. With 2x upkeep, there are far more 'hopeless hillside holdouts' that grant the greatest satisfaction.

Mostly, the game is great, and at 600 hours I still feel like a novice. However, in that time seige battles have become a slog, and the over-world random-event choices are largely uninteresting - but when I close my eyes, I see eager units in rank and file, watching blessed trebuchet bolders blot out the sky.

This game has a very high, and obtuse, learning curve. 

The scant (but rapid fire and incomplete) "tutorials" - which just amount to a few dialogue boxes popping up constantly at the beginning of every turn in the early game, do nothing to teach the new player how to actually play.

This game (and the other Total Warhammer titles) need an actual small-scale tutorial before starting a campaign. How it is now, you'll be forced to start a new campaign with zero knowledge and be breadcrumbed the little advice they decided to tell you. 

These 4X games are not generally easy to learn for new players. This is just another on that pile. I have tried learning this game about four separate times. Each time, I get gang-banged into failure by random armies popping out of the jungles by turn 15 or so. All on easy difficulty. 

The game hates you for playing it, and if you want to learn it, spend 20+ hours watching/reading dry and boring instructional videos by random people.

The series has reached its pinnacle with an excellent launch and superb DLC support. It remained strong even after the launch of its sequel, until the release of Immortal Empires.

This might be one of the best games ever made (Edit: can confirm, one of the best games ever made). Everything from the original game has been improved upon and expanded with almost no negatives. My main two complaints about the first game were lack of map variety and Chaos invasion, and both have been resolved. Chaos now has difficulty settings or can be completely disabled. There's a completely new map with story objectives, and the Mortal Empires campaign roughly doubles the size of the previous game's map. While access to the Mortal Empire map (the main campaign) requires ownership of the original game, all games and their DLC go on sale regularly. The laundry list of DLC might seem intimidating too, but it carries over between games, including into the sequel to this.

My only complaints now are the difficulty of victory conditions and the new AI behavior. The first game's AI felt pretty aggressive, both to you and other factions equally, often wiping out a neighbor if they couldn't confederate them. Now it seems the AI is more aggressive towards humans than other AI, and AI is more apprehensive about razing another faction. I've had several games where a faction everyone hated would get down to one settlement multiple times and everyone would stop attacking them for some reason. AI also seems more aggressive towards factions ranked lower than them, and more passive against factions ranked higher than them. Certain factions tended to stay near the top of my games, with my allies refusing to attack them unless I dragged them into a war against them.

Victory conditions now are much more difficult to complete and make actually finishing a game quite an accomplishment. Most factions now have to capture (or be allied with factions who own) at least eight major cities on the map, in addition to their other victory conditions. This means you'll be painting the map and making some awkward alliances just to check off part of your win, never mind some of the more absurd condition lists like what Vampire Coast have to go through. If you have Chaos invasion enabled, you have to kill their three leaders too, and they don't spawn until turn 140-160. 

These feel like small complaints compared to all the excellent content in this game but they might be frustrating deal breakers for some people. Most of my feelings about the first game still stand so check out that review for a more in-depth take on the series. For an even more in-depth take, check out Mandalore's review on YouTube. It's 1 hour 20 minutes long, but the first hour is mostly about the first game's races. It's well edited, very entertaining, and covers way more than someone like me with under 1000 hours. I highly recommend this for anyone who enjoys strategy games, but beware the steep learning curve (again). New factions, new cities and settlements, new faction technologies and interactions... even with playing the first game, it feels like starting over again. This is a proper sequel, a massive improvement over the first game, and isn't just $60 DLC.

The first thing that struck me about Total War: WARHAMMER II is its sheer scale and attention to detail. The game boasts an expansive campaign map that spans continents, offering an incredible variety of landscapes and factions to play as. Whether you're commanding the noble High Elves, sinister Dark Elves, savage Lizardmen, or the insidious Skaven, each faction feels uniquely distinct, and their playstyles offer a wealth of strategic options.  

The real-time battles in Total War: WARHAMMER II are nothing short of epic. Watching vast armies clash on the battlefield, with legendary creatures soaring overhead and spellcasters unleashing arcane powers, is an awe-inspiring spectacle. The tactical depth is unparalleled, and the addition of Warhammer's iconic units, monsters, and spells adds a thrilling layer of complexity to the battles.

playability is simply outstanding. The sheer variety of factions, coupled with different victory conditions and unique campaign mechanics, ensures that no two campaigns ever feel the same.

In conclusion, Total War: WARHAMMER II is a genre-defining masterpiece that seamlessly blends the strategic brilliance of Total War with the captivating fantasy universe of Warhammer.
I think I can say I enjoyed this game quite a bit by my time played.

It's like playing the Tabletop game but without the figures, socialisation and work involved in getting set up. Which is both good and bad. On the one hand you can jump into a game in minutes and be smashing up Skaven with your Feral Carnosaur, which is great (and features some good animations as well), on the other hand, it lacks some of the magic of rolling dice with a friend. 

Also it's a Total War Title, with Total War style province management which gently scratches that Crusader Kings itch without quite satisfying it.
Nukes, Dinosaurs, Dwarves and Tanks. What else could you want?

A cost effective way of engaging in the Warhammer world, campaigns are challenging, there's a good and diverse modding community.

[b] Achievements. They cost money. [/b]

[h1] The Game[/h1]
The second installment in the Total War: Warhammer series. Turn-based strategy game where you can play one of many factions available with different mechanics, strategies and missions.

[h1] The Achievements[/h1]
The achievements are: difficult, grindy, require help from specific players and require several DLC. It is very difficult to estimate how fast you can complete all of the achievements as it is very skill based game with a hard learning curve and some RNG involved. Prepare to spend both money and hundreds of hours in this game.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
The game is very, very fun in the variety of content that it offers. The problem relies in needing both the first game for the best experience + several DLC for achievements for other factions. This is however one of the best strategy games I have ever played and I felt that it can provide many hours of enjoyment (and frustration) but be aware of the time and money required. A good but very cautious recommendation.

Good game, undermined by many trash features.  The RNG is trash and Heroes are an obnoxious feature.  

RNG is trash
The RNG is well known to be fully rigged, so the game explicitly lies to you by giving your probabilities of success/failure.  It is decided before the attempt, so if you see your low-level Hero for example, has too low a chance to attempt something, and opt to use your expert, they might still fail 1000 times out of a thousand because the AI determined that the next X attempt by your agent on Y target rolls a natural 1.  This means that the skill of your agents only matters on the margins, and having 'teams' of Heroes to operate together is largely pointless, because you WILL run up against certain fail scenarios no matter what you do.  But you need to invest in them or the AI will simply ruin the experience for you, see below.

I hate Heroes
I learned that you basically have to constantly invest in assassination from the beginning, because if you don't you lose because you can never catch up and the enemy can destroy your buildings, kill your units, and assassinate your characters with impunity.  This happens because the RNG is fake, for one, but for two there is no way to train up assassins well enough if you don't do it from the start, and sending five lower level assassins just gets them all killed.  At one point is was spending 25k gold a year remedying sabotage from an AI across the map from heroes that I couldn't assassinate.  I ended up abandoning the campaign because it was too annoying to keep playing.

Lighting Strike is bullshit
Lighting Strike is an ability that uses the games arbitrary limits to penalize you.  The AI can, 100% of the time, deny your reinforcements.  So if you have three full armies, and they have two, they can, three times in a row, without chance of failure, fight your armies, two against one, one at time.  Granted, the player can do this too, but I don't want to, because its ass.
