Ahoy ye landlubbers! Gather 'round and hear the tale of Total War Warhammer 2 as narrated by none other than Luthor Harkon himself!

Avast me hearties! If ye be yearnin' for a game where ye can be a dastardly pirate lord and command armies of undead beasties then this be the game for ye! Total War Warhammer 2 be a grand adventure on the high seas where ye can conquer lands and build an empire fit for a scallywag such as meself. Now me fellow scurvy dogs let me tell ye, the battles in this game be as fierce as a kraken's tentacles! The clash of steel, the roars of monsters and the blasts of cannons will shiver ye timbers! But fear not for ye can unleash all sorts of dark magic and monstrous creatures upon yer enemies. It be like havin' a whole crew of zombie pirates fightin' alongside ye!

But here be the best part mateys: ye can explore the treacherous seas and hidden lands of the Warhammer world. From the sweltering jungles of Lustria to the icy wastes of Naggaroth ye can sail, plunder and take control of the very oceans themselves! It be like being a shark with cannons for teeth! Now I won't lie to ye, there be a few minor flaws in this grand adventure. Sometimes the AI be a touch daft like a parrot with a peg leg but don't ye worry, ye can still have a jolly good time sinkin' enemy ships and sackin' cities!

Sup ye scurvy dogs! Almost forgot that my mind shattered into pieces within the game. Hope ye will learn the tale of my fragmented consciousness as ye plunder the enemy cities so you can deal with my schizophrenic problems. Ahoy again me fellow scoundrels! Luthor Harkon be back to sprinkle some extra vampire flavor into this jolly review!

Listen well ye mortals for in this game ye can assume the mantle of a blood-sucking vampire lord! Picture this! Commanding an army of undead minions clad in dark armor and fueled by an insatiable thirst for blood! Ye can raise the fallen warriors and turn them into your loyal servants, ready to feast upon the flesh of the living! It be like having an eternal crew of bloodthirsty buccaneers! Yer vampire captains and monstrous sea food creatures will strike fear into the hearts of men! It be a spectacle as thrilling as a moonlit dance with the dead!

In the end ye foolish mortals, WH 2 is a vampire pirate's dream come true! It be filled with swashbucklin' action, undead hordes and more loot than ye can shake a cutlass at. 

So hoist the anchor, set sail and remember mateys; dead men tell no tales, but they do leave hilarious Steam reviews!

I'm a long time Total War player, and this is my FAVORITE one in the series. It's taken me a while to write a review on this game because I was thinking to myself "well anyone who likes strategy games MUST already know how good Total War Warhammer 2 is."

but now I'm here, on a Thursday, and thought to myself "Why don't I go to Steam and review all the games I really like", you know, what normal people do. 

Total War Warhammer 2 is one of my favorite strategy games of all times. The sheer VARIETY of factions you can play is incredible, a feat on its own. The play style difference between two factions, even some within the same race, is one of the main selling points I use when roping my friends into spending way too much money on this game. (Sorry bois) You can play Orks, and your boy can play Goblins, and the issues you have to deal with and the problems you have to solve in your Empire are going to be VASTLY different. 

The way that they have seamlessly woven so much Warhammer Fantasy lore into the mechanics of the game is incredible. Magic items from books, characters from stories, it's all there. (Most of it anyway)

The MAP DUDE??? THE FUCKIN MAP??? It's so incredibly detailed and beautifully rendered. You can see every little mountain top. You can see dragons and griffons flying around mountain peaks. 

THE ONLY thing I dislike about the Total War: Warhammer series is the Immortal Empires campaign with multiplayer and how they sorta handled it. If I wanna have a decent experience with my friends, even in Warhammer 3, all of us pretty much have to have own all three games. You COULD still play if everyone just owned the same one, but really, the experience isn't complete and there's some restrictions. I would've liked to see some system where if the host owned all the games, the guest could choose from any faction or something? (idk man i'm not a game designer). Kinda like Stellaris does. 

ANYWAY.  I fucking love this game. If you love the Total Wars series, or are a fan of the Warhammer Fantasy lore, get this game. Thanks luv u bye

OK...this is probably the best game I've EVER played!
Yes I am a big Warhammer fan, and especially AOS/Fantasy. So this has everything every other TW has but more & better! 100% recommend this game, to anyone.....seriously!

If its on sale.

Game is extremely limited compared to MTW2 and earlier, and not as good from an experience/modding POV.

It does have alot of mods, some of which are really good - but no where near the quality and variety of mods we had in MTW2.

Norsca/Chaos are not implemented very well, and for the other factions I played (everyone except lizards and Vampire Coast) the game is a chore and grind if you try to play anyway the designers did not intend.

For example; say you want to play a HE faction that is in Kraka Drak so you can be the frontline vs Chaos invasion - doesnt mesh well as Imrik is good in mountains but sucks in snow.

Say you want to create a Fimir kingdom out of Albion with the intent of fighting Chaos later; kinda rough because Chaos doesnt trigger until your Norsca faction (required for Fimir units) pledges to a Dark God.

Say you want to play as Chaos and just be a wandering horde intending to conquer the Darklands and face off against the TK? Really a grind because, even though you have no intention of invading the Empire or Dwarfs, the Empire and Dwarfs will always hate you.

Say you want to play as X faction but build tall and have fun sending agents out into the world to do your bidding? Not viable because you simply wont have enough agents as their cap is tied to buildings.

My point is that, unless you are playing the 'canon' way with a given faction you will quickly run into barriers. Now some mods help break down those barriers, but they cant overcome this final nail in the coffin;

If you want to lead the Armies of Chaos against the Free Peoples of Middle-Earth you flat out CANNOT do this. The map is, from what I have seen and experienced, quite static. This is a Warhammer Fantasy game and that is all it will ever be.

This is Why both WH1 and WH2 die out over time (so will WH3) whereas MTW2 still has life left in it. The possibilities are so much greater with MTW2 because you can create so many unique campaigns and mods - even with limited modding skill.

So, ultimately, WH2 is, like WH1, worth it if you get it on sale. Don't pay more than $30 - $40 altogether, including DLC. I would say same for WH3. Wait until it is on a massive sale after it has 'died down' a bit, and get a superior product that is as fleshed out as it ever will be.

WH1, btw, was a huge disappointment for me, but WH2 did include enough variety to get me to over 200 hours, which made it worth the $40 I spent on it. Just barely, but still counts.

Anywho, cheers and all that.

So after playing a bit of this game, I have found its issues.

There is a ridiculous dlc system which requires you to download free content that should already in the game without being manually added. Some of these dlcs requires an account different from Steam to get them. It is frustrating and getting the dlcs is made in the most dumb way I have seen in almost any game.

The Second problems relates to these dlcs and so after buying this game for like almost $80, you do not have the majority of the characters and factions to play and requires you to spend like $110 on dlcs, which is stupid since you should already have them or have it be free dlcs after paying a Triple A game's price.

My third problem is a mechanic that is very powerful and does not have a lot of counters for, that you can get after the early game. It makes it so campaign battles are not very large which is disappointing for me because I would like to have several lords with different army styles working together to create something chaotic and fun. The only way that you can do this is custom battles I believe unfortunately. This makes me have to create more consistently the same armies in order to be consistent with counters, which makes it slightly less fun.

This game is actually one of the better Turn Based games and kind of reminds me of Mount & Blade for the fighting aspects and how fun that is. I think it is a fun game but with the dlc overpay, I do not think it has the longevity to keep you playing unless you have money to spend. Get if you like the concepts, but maybe just wait until Warhammer 3 gets some patches as its bugged right now

I love the different themes and factions, but they will leech you for every single cent they can.  Take the dlc for the beastmen with Taurox; that's an awesome dlc, but you want to summon other beast lords to serve the gods of chaos?  You need to buy Call of the Beastmen; to summon more gods.  Why?  If I play the other beastmen, I can just buy a lord at a town, but because it's Taurox then you need specific beastmen from Warhammer 40k total war 1.  You want to be awesome as a high elf.  Then you need the queen and the crone, because you need their unit to be a serious high elf player. Seriously? Did you not just gouge me for the base game?  What is it with these games where you pay full Triple AAA prices then have to buy the developer a boat with all these DLC's to play a normal game.

This is now one of my favorite games. I can see myself trying different races/species. Some people say it is similar to CIV. It's not (IE one cannot build new cities. They can only be conquered). In many ways it is better. 

HOWEVER, there is one major fly in the ointment. It is turned-base, but as the game progresses and more of the map is revealed, one can wait 5 minutes or more after clicking 'end turn'. It takes several minutes to start a battle and several minutes to end one. A suggestion to the developers is to create a patch that only shows movement for units within sight of one's own and not for all movement (like CIV does). I found myself doing chores in between turns like wash the dishes, take care of the cat box, etc. Or read many pages of a book. This tedium prevents me from playing the same game for longer.

It is very replayable. But the long turn change and pre/post battle waits and the DLC overload factor lowers my score. 7.5/10

Edit: This review concerns the Mortal Empire campaign game that requires Total War: Warhammer 1 (as I call it). I very much enjoyed warhammer 2 without it. It only had the story-based Great Vortex campaign. But now with this second option, the game is even better. It is simply a game of conquest with no complicating story behind it. All the races, the map, and many other things from warhammer 1 are included in this campaign game. My new score is 85/100

The game is amazing and probly needed to fully enjoy immortal empires, but you're gonna need to do needless and crappy research THEN PAY MORE if you want to play a faction from this game with the full roster.  the other two don't have this DLC structure from what I can tell.   lame af to see it here

The amount of bullshit I've seen in the 20 some hours I've played is truly incredible. 

I know this is the norm for strategy games, but the AI is miserable and passive, both on the campaign map and in battle, and I often find myself losing battles and on the strategic map only because of friendly AI. My reinforcements spawned behind the enemy, or to their side? I spent 2000 gold on sending troops there? Well, you know what the friendly AI will do when the enemy makes a beeline with their massive army towards my 5 units? Stand there. Just stand there for 5 minutes, until all my units are dead. Then, the enemy makes their way over to them unimpeded and finishes them off. As for the campaign map, you'd think that after 2 decades of developing Total War games, CA would have figured out how to simply change a few numbers to the benefit of the player. It's great seeing 80% of the empire taken over or destroyed outright by turn 30.

A vampire lordess dressed in light clothes and armed with a sword took out hundreds of men on her own, while surrounded. I should mention, I had taken out every other unit in the opposing army. Alright, let's give her the benefit of the doubt and assume she has inhuman strength, or is bolstered by magic.Fine. But then how was she able to wrangle up almost a hundred men as captives? On her own? Those men wouldn't just run in different directions? What happened to the other hundreds of men that routed from the field? She killed ALL of them?  On top of capturing 87 men??? It would be alright if this was a demon, a dragon, or something else. But a woman, not even on horseback? Seriously?

You CANNOT TAKE REINFORCEMENTS INTO QUEST BATTLES?????? WHY? There is NOTHING preventing my second army from entering the field. What is this retardism? There isn't even an in-game explanation on why half of my forces are suddenly blocked from entering a battle.

There is no armor/equipment system for units like in Medieval 2, which is disappointing. but eh, whatever.

I have lost three siege battles because of the completely fucking obnoxious and nonsensical city square capture system. I would have won all of those battles, if I simply had more time. Instead, enemy units would make their way to the city center, sit their asses down, and for some reason the hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of armored, armed men defending their homes, who are actively fighting and in good morale, just decide to lay down their weapons and let themselves be taken captive??? "oh boo fucking hoo, the enemy had 15 tiny, poorly trained, and unarmored goblins standing still in an unimportant square of this massive fort/city. Guess we'll just give up and let ourselves be fucking slaughtered??????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????" what the actual fuck?????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????? Could you imagine this happening in the real world? Oh, the enemy captured a city block? Let's send all our men to be taken prisoner by the enemy and give the entire city up. Before you say, "bUt oTheR tW gAmEs hAd tHiS toO", it actually mattered, because the units of the defending army would always flee towards the square, and attacking units would generally route out of the city. Here, broken, shattered, demolished, morally crushed units will magically push past your units and run straight into the heart of the city (where, logically, further defenses and choke points  would be waiting for them). It's just downright nonsense.

What fucking mongoloid said "yep that makes sense, go ahead and add it to the game" ??????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????

On top of that, routed enemies will always flee INTO the city, not back out, or up to the walls, where their other units are fighting, which exacerbates this problem SO MUCH. Again, it also makes absolutely no sense.

On a similar note, integrating other provinces into my faction along with their armies often wrecks my economy, despite the fact that, supposedly, those provinces should have been able to pay for the upkeep of their own armies prior to me acquiring them, and the gold generated by those provinces.

Armies you are not at war with can just go around freely raiding your provinces and land, causing unrest, losing you money, and spreading corruption. There is no way to tell them to fuck off, and if you attack them, YOU WILL FACE DIPLOMATIC CONSEQUENCES?????????????????? This is some Civilization 5 levels of diplomacy bullshit. Who designed these systems? Did they not play the game? Did no one think, at any point during the game's development, that shit like this makes no sense? Like, come on. Some developer playtesting came across this exact situation many times and okayed it??

Just play Medieval 2. It's cheap and actually fucking works. I'll continue trying to get into this game, especially because its production quality is so high. But come on. There is so much game-breaking logic-defying garbage, that it feels like there was 0 actual playtesting involved. I'm not even going to comment on the greedy DLC pilfering policy. All of these little "problems" start to stack together, and it is a serious detriment to what would otherwise be a very fun game with amazing graphics. On its own, I would shrug my shoulders and say whatever to any of these issues. However, when I can form a list of them, and many of them can ruin your experience outright, it quickly deteriorates into a shitfest that makes me question if anyone ever playtested this game. It's incredible that these were non-issues in earlier TW games, but they're popping up now.

lol, and as i finish this review and turn back to a battle I was playing, two units of crossbowmen stop responding to any commands. I tell them to shoot at a unit, they turn around and run towards an enemy cavalry unit engaged in melee with swordsmen. I drag out the reposition icon. They keep running. I click back for them to move. They keep running. I use the halt command. They keep running. They were NOT running because of oncoming enemy infantry. They were standing perfectly still behind a friendly unit of infantry UNTIL i told them to attack a target. THEN, they freak out and decide to stop functioning outright. Nice. You can really see the quality and lack of bug shine through here.

Committed myself to a review once I hit the 1k hour mark.

Warhammer 2 is moreish, the food you can't help yourself returning to. The sheer diversity of the roster, the wealth of GW lore and the compelling gameplay loop is a bedevilling intoxicant that CA have brewed. If my mixed metaphors don't give it away, this is a strong recommend.

I come to the Warhammer instalments as a long-time player of historical Total War, who still avidly follows and plays the Europa Barbarorum 2 mod for Med 2. I also come to the titles as someone who was absolutely fascinated by the 5th and 6th edition-era Warhammer Fantasy tabletop as a kid and have never looked back. 

CA have managed to capture the feel, the sounds and the sights of the tabletop magnificently - CA's artists and designers, their sound technicians and their voice acting direction deserve the greatest of plaudits. It's a triumph, and every time I load up the game, I am transported back to leafing through the armybooks in the early '00s and hanging about the local GW on Saturdays.

As someone who plays a lot of historical and values authenticity as part of battles and campaign structure, I thoroughly enjoy WH2's single-entity units, magic and battle pace. It is an arcade of treats, more akin to certain HoM&M fantasy RPGs of old, and that's what one should keep in mind when coming from historical titles. It's faster, it's explosive and totally absurd. Strategy and tactics remain, but they are simply different ones. That's the direction these titles have taken, and I am fine with it.

As for how it translates from TT, it is more difficult to compare and is somewhat a subjective experience. I don't seek to replicate that experience like-for-like (particularly given the mixed rep of 8th edition), but in general, the vanilla game following all the updates since 2017 gets the general feel down. There are a vast selection of mods at this point, ranging from overhauls to smaller tweaks to get your desired sweet-spot. I'd recommend the Tabletop Caps mod to at least give armies (both yours and the AI's) some structure and balance.

On the confusing array of purchasing options and DLC - other buying guides will likely explain this better, but the only purchase I would make initially is to buy the base-game of both Warhammer 1 and Warhammer 2 when they go on sale (which is pretty regular). This is purely to unlock the Mortal Empires campaign in Warhammer 2 itself and grant access to the base-game factions of the original game, all of which received overhauls and roster updates in Warhammer 2. This content alone will provide you hours upon hours of gameplay. You can then make decisions about the factions you enjoy playing and whether you want to purchase the relevant smaller DLC packs that add new lords, factions and individual campaigns. Mandalore described it best; they are [i]√† la carte[/i], and can be approached one at a time.

A further note - I closely follow Warhammer 3 and its developments even if I have not purchased it. With this in mind, I'd also recommend Warhammer 2 as currently the more complete experience, having had years of updates and a selection of mods to fine-tune your experience. I am waiting for Warhammer 3 to go through a number of patch cycles and content updates (as well as requiring a PC upgrade) before buying into that experience. There is more than enough well-rounded content between Warhammer 1 and Warhammer 2 to satiate my needs until that happens.

"WOLLT IHR DEN TOTALEN KRIEG?!!" - Joseph Goebbels, adress to the Nazi party, Berlin Sportpalast, 1943

"Total War" is a concept that dates back to the early 20th century, maybe late 19th. it means "war of annihilation", "genocide" in modern words. This choice of title alone should tell you everything you need to know about the game series... 
But if you need to dive deeper, here it is:

"Warhammer II" is STILL for the delusional Sunday warrriors and worshippers of the "mighty and manly" Sparta - which has been a ruin for over 2000 years while "sly and effeminate" Athens still endures as the capital of Greece...
Morale is STILL a gimmick. Humans can STILL almost run as fast as horses. Logistics, demographics, and natural ressources are STILL just an afterthought. And again, the only thing medieval are STILL the graphics...
But with the addition of so many new factions came two new treats! One from Games Workshop and the other from the Developpers!
The one from Games Workshop is wild inconsistencies. "Take the money and run!" Notoriously, there is no-one in the studio making sure the whole Warhammer world holds together. They just pile the childish gimmick of the week on top of last week's gimmick, milking it as dry and fast as possible before moving on to the next cash-cow. In game terms, this means huge and random balance issues that keep appearing. They fix one, and two new issues come up. At the time of this review, for example, the Empire is so marred in random events, rivals factions, and dissentions, that's is guaranteed defeat in 20 turns, even if you reload your auto-save every 3 turn... It's like playing with a pervert GM who love to throw a level 20 dragon at your level 1 group, just for "fun". Last year, Morathi's faction was crushing most of the map, wreaking havoc on the campaign. Now it's Alith Anar... Next year it's gonna be a new faction. Boring.
The one from the Developpers is FORCED paying content and unfair (illegal?) marketing. Notoriously, in every Total War title, even if you don't want a DLC, you are forced to play with it as it automatically shows up in your game. Oddly enough, the DLC factions even sometimes ruin your campaing until you buy the DLC. Weird, uh?  

But if you're into BDSM, specifically scatology and golden showers, you could still give this game a go! As far as I'm concerned, I've learned my lesson this time...

I first reviewed this after eight campaigns and over 1400 hours and as I learned the mechanics the game became more engaging but irritating due to both random AI events and unbalanced starting positions. The  game is particularly hard during the early turns, putting off a new player due to difficult starting challenge and early negative events.  For me, the number and frequency of these AI mechanics are irritating as they undermine planning, building, tactics and strategy. In diplomacy, long term allies will turn on you if they are able to join a stronger alliance and unprovoked neighbours will declare war pulling you into world war with their allies.  Missions mostly cost more to achieve than the rewards are worth and most cannot be achieved within the timescale or without leaving your home provinces vulnerable to invasion and ruin.  From the start, rogue doom stack pirate armies roam the oceans.  As a new player, I thought these would invade when I did not have an army capable of defending against them.  This upset my positive engagement with the new game.  I later learned that they don't land or attack unless you set sail near their path. This game would be more engaging for  new and casual players with the random negative events were less frequent and less severe.  This early experience of this game is the least satisfying total war game I have played in two decades., although it improves as you gain knowledge and experience.  The game development seems to be for experienced players wanting harder challenge rather then new or casual players.  I do not recommend this game for new or casual players or for players that are looking to build an empire through building, planning, strategy and diplomacy.  The game rewards battle and conquest above other gameplay. Nonetheless I have continued to play the game.  I have now recommended it as it is a good game once you learnt how to play it.

I've had the pleasure of playing many Total War titles over the past few years, as they were a significant part of my childhood and always bring back nostalgia when I revisit games like Total War: Medieval II. Now that I've spent a considerable amount of time playing Warhammer II, I can confidently say that it holds a special place in my heart. The game has very well designed elements, stunning graphics, and fun gameplay. And, of course, we can't forget about that one annoying faction in every Total War game that relentlessly sends armies your way. This time, it's the Rats!

Anyways, outstanding game I highly recommend to any RTS/Total War enthusiast. Also, the game becomes even more enjoyable if you play with a friend; there's nothing quite as amusing as listening to them panic as their lone ranged regiment battles a monstrous beast, especially when it's their first Total war game :)

Overall: really fun. Great game.

Some con's though, (con's present in all the other Total War Warhammer Games in some form):

1. The specificity of the some of the units coupled with needing to micromanage the Lord/Hero's abilities becomes really cumbersome in the late game.

2. Kind of a late game thing - kinda not - but I enjoyed how visceral the battles felt in Fall of the Samurai and Empire.... I loved how a random cannonball could 1-shot your general and musket-volleys fire was loud and devastating. Pitched battles generally didn't last long in those games because units would die/route so quickly. Which I think is historically accurate as far as martial battles go.

Meanwhile, battles in WHII/WHIII can sometimes feel like pillow fights....

Units (particularly high level; thus the "kind of a late game"-comment) can just got at each for minutes.... And there's plenty of Youtube videos of high-level lords solo'ing full-stack armies. 

It can make battles feel like a cartoon representation of a battle versus an actual battle.

Apart from that - great game.

I've been playing Total War titles since Medieval 2 (back when games came on disks!). So a long time. But I can remember even 20 years ago wishing they'd ditch the historical settings and just go NUTS with a fantasy setting because there were little hints (like the Roman "Arcani" units in Rome 1) here and there that they wanted to go in that direction. I assumed if they did that it would be an original world, and I never would have guessed they'd get into Warhammer Fantasy. 

But you could not ask for a better setting for a High Fantasy grand strategy game than Warhammer. 

Otherwise, the structure of these games has changed very little over the last 20 years, where you work on a map to conquer the world, agents and armies running around taking objectives. The battles play out roughly the same in every game, with artillery, hammer & anvil tactics, etc. And each game brings a slight spin on it, enough to keep it lively.

So what makes Total Warhammer (all 3 games) special is the obsessive attention to detail, because Warhammer is the king of completely over the top purple prose. Unit designs are pushed to 11. Creative Assembly could have just copied the tabletop miniatures, but it's like they said no no, what if it was REAL. Let's go bananas with this. It's a match made in heaven to have CA on Warhammer. I would challenge ANYONE to find me a game with this much detail. Sheer volume of data and visual stimuli, pound for pound its not possible.

And for me this is what makes the game so god damn fun. As you go further into each faction's unit tree the units get more wild and unhinged and crazy, but with a loving attention to detail that renders them on the battlefield in their hundreds.

AND THEN YOU GET TO SMASH THEM TOGETHER AND BLOW THEM UP. 

It's better than any previous total war game because instead of boring units of roman legions re-enacting the battle of Cannae or whatever, you have flying Gorgon demons fighting wizards riding dragons. And the thing is, it feels as *real* and *respectful* to the source material as the old games did Rome vs Hannibal at Cannae. Imagine that! 

Oh wait you don't have to!

The Total War Warhammer series from the announcement trailer was something I prioritized getting a gaming pc just to play. And I have enjoyed every step and moment of its life cycle. From learning how to use a keyboard to play these games, to waiting for the all new race dlcs, to watching all the amazing content that's amassed from the YouTuber community. 
   It has been everything I hoped it would be and then some! The world is just freaking awesome! I always come back to it. Its gone through bugs and issues throughout it's life cycle but both CA and the community has helped it grow into something most definitely worth your money. I just today learned more about the modding community. SMH. I am always late to the party. (Lol) But a lot of that is because I'm very much a solo gamer that only hooks up to the internet for the new updates and to download new games so multiplayer is also something I've never done and don't intend to but the content on that front is also amazing! 
    But there are very few games that I can think of that is anything like this game. Check out some of the content on Youtube and see if it doesn't catch your attention. Getting long-winded.... its an amazing series that I'm still putting crazy hours into and I think you will too!

I've been playing Warhammer games since Rome I, this is easily the worst total war I have ever played. The AI suffers no attrition, they can spawn full armies with late-game units while you're still stuck in the early game, and your economy is so pathetically weak that in order to patrol your lands you would need at least twice the income the game allows you to have. This game is pathetic, utterly pathetic.

UPDATE:  March 24, 2023 (a couple years after my initial review below)                 I decided to flip my review from a Thumbs Down; to a Thumbs Up.  After many                  more hours of playing this game.  What made this game more bearable, and                 actually fairly fun?   MODS.  Community Mods; made this game enjoyable.                   Without the Mods; my review would remain a Thumbs Down.ORIGINAL Review:I really wanted to rate this game as a "thumbs up"; but I just can't.Really, I like just about everything with this game.  Cool Lore.  Great, entertaining battles.  Awesome diplomacy features.  Cool factions.  Nice events.  Quests, a great.  Challenging game on Normal.  Fantasy is fun.Here is the main HUGE PROBLEM.  And the reasons why I find this game so very annoying to play.  In fact, I can't play it anymore, the annoyance factor is so high.Bad implementation, regarding re-claiming your own lost territories.  In particularly when your settlement gets devastated or Ruin. When the player, or the AI lose a settlement; any other faction, including your allies can sweep in fast and 'take it' for free. I have had so many games, where I lost my settlement to Chaos Hordes; and it became devastated.  I was mere turns away, of not 'a' turn away from reclaiming it.  When... my ally, swept in fast and took it instead!  Right smack-dab in the middle of my Main province.  Where the ONLY way in the game that you get get 'your settlement back' is to declare war (on the ally).  There is no feature in the game to TRADE territories, or ASK for your territory back.Also; if you lose your territory to an enemy in general, even if not devastated;  then any other faction or even your own allies can War them and take that settlement which previously belonged to you!  And they keep it.  And there is no way that you can get it back, unless you War that other faction.  Too often, in my games, my allies are 'taking lands' that belong to me.  Where I just lost a Battle to an enemy, or some horde devastated my settlement.  And Swooooop!  In comes an ally to take my land.   And then I have no choice but to declare war on a 'long time' ally; just because the AI is too stupid to understamnd that "Hm.  If, I take my allies land... that might piss him off.. and he will probably declare war on me".  Real dumb AI mechanics here.It seriously kills my gaming experience.  Totally.  What a turn off.  It makes the game pointless.  Allies are pointless.  Keeping claim to territory is pointless.  Territory diplomacy is 'non-existent'.  Diplomacy in general is great!  Just not so, with territorial diplomacy.  Nor, territorial politics.  It is virtually non-existent in this game. All they need to do is simply program a feature in, that would totally fix this problem!  And they can't do that.It is an easy script too!  As I am also a game programmer.All they need to do it implemenet this logic:IF a faction loses a settlement (by devastation or occupation), that faction has 'X' amount of Turns to 'reclaim it'  If X amount of turns expires, then any faction may take claim to that settlement unhinged. It is such an easy piece of code!!!  And it would totally FIX a huge problem in this game that a lot of people have been complaining about.For real.  Stop allowing factions (even allies) to swoop in, and take my territories, the very moment that I lose one to an enemy!I have had some games where my allies will literally patrol around a settlement of mine; that they "think" I might lose to my enemy.  And immediately, once that happens, they claim my land in 1 turn.  it is so ridiculous.  Truly.  It breaks the game for me, every time.  Every time.  I am done with this game; after this review.   Where normally I am a HUGE TW fan.

MY units either run away or wont attack even with clear line of sight. Apparently the company tried to fix an issue of ranged being too strong for players that exploited their use. I bought the game and all of the DLC. This person explains very politely the issue: youtube.com/watch?v=amtXcGCNrH8 . I look forward to when this game is playable and thank the staff for their dedication.

Update: As of 2/16/23, you can access Immortal Empires and play the Warhammer 3 races without owning Warhammer 1 and 2 - great change!

There were plenty of bumps in the road to get there, but Warhammer 2 became my all-time favorite strategy game.  The variety of factions and the grandiose world map of Mortal Empires make for a fantastic RTS/TBS sandbox experience of humans, elves, orcs, undead, and more.  If you're willing to venture outside the historical strategy setting, there's a lot here.  Start by buying Warhammer 1 and 2 on sale, then playing Warhammer 2 Mortal Empires campaign (the Vortex campaign isn't so bad either, if you want to mix it up).  If you enjoy it, pick up the DLCs as they interest you.  If you can't get enough and just need more, then take a look at Warhammer 3's Immortal Empires mode (in beta and still maturing at the time of this review).

STEAM Workshop does not work with this game, unfortunately. You can subscribe to mods on STEAM Workshop. They will show as installed and active on your WH2 mod manager--but they haven't actually been installed, and thus will not play. So far there doesn't seem to be a solution to this issue. Logout/login to STEAM; Selecting/deselecting download prefs in Steam/Settings/Downloads; restarting PC; selecting and checking mods in Mod Manager--none of these fix this STEAM Workshop issue for WH2. 

As I like to play Total War titles with mods, and STEAM is now pretty much the exclusive access portal for WH2 mods, lack of workshop support for this title makes it pretty boring after a few playthroughs. I own every other TW title (except WH3), including DLC's and have 15k+ hours in the franchise. Every other TW title on my PC is heavily modded--either through STEAM Workshop or the Nexus--and they all work fine. Except WH2.

Or laugh in delight as you one man an entire enemy army and still come out the victor. Have you ever wanted to feel like a god, I have. Let me tell you a story; I conscripted one of the finest elven armies the world has ever seen, with all prostrating themselves as they are inevitability conquered. Yet, I could not protect my coasts from the Mongolian horde that are the vampire pirates. After losing my coastal cities again in one of the biweekly raids by them, I decided I had enough. I sent my invincible armies into their hell coves to purge them one and for all, and I lost. not just one army, that would be embarrassing enough; I lost three of the finest armies that I could muster. So now it is personal, I pour my countries entire GDP into creating even stronger armies, near bankrupting my country to do so. Finally, I send the armies to destroy the vampirates for good.except, that the turn before the battle BOTH the humans and the dark elves land troops in my capital region. And that children is when you press quit to menu and swear to never touch that retarded piece of shit again.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well.

This is a positive review that focuses on negative elements.

In tabletop Warhammer, you have battles between equally powerful armies. Those armies have constraints that force you to make strategic choices. (I can have either a cannon or a monster, but not both.) For various reasons, that's not feasible in a Total War game. So instead, you can have whatever you can afford in your army, which is fine.

But that means the strategic constraint is put on your overworld economy -- and the problem with that is that that economic system isn't very interesting. It's pretty bare bones. Other systems are oddly implemented, like diplomacy, where the UI gets really confusing when there are 70 factions to interact with. I wouldn't say they're bad, just not particularly interesting.

Since the economy is the gameplay focus, you can also try to win by playing efficiently. i.e., you can win with an all-dragon army, but that's economically inefficient if you're just killing swordsmen. This means if you play tactically, you can get by with less. But I found this a bit awkward as well, because the game leans really heavily into battles. With brief interludes, you'll often fight several per turn. 

To fight efficiently, you often can't automate battles. So to make it tolerable to fight a hundred non-automated battles in a campaign, the game really speeds these battles up. Often, battles are over in five minutes. To do this, infantry must move close to 20mph -- once you see it, it's hard to unsee. This is disguised somewhat by being able to pause or slow-down time, but it creates a kind of surreal tempo to battles that I thought was chosen to be suitable for multiplayer and to enable a focus on battles, not strategy. 

Together, this makes the game less compelling to me than I think it seems at first. There's a pretty but gameplay-bland overworld map, and frequent battles where the main difficulty is a self-prescribed goal of economic efficiency. On harder difficulties, where you can't pause, there's some micro -- and that's mostly it. 

Overall, the game isn't bad. And it's definitely more fun than the first Total War: Warhammer. The attention to the lore, the tone of the universe, and the faction diversity all feel good. But after 70 turns or so, I find it hitting a slog that I think could have been avoided with a bit more inspiration. 

(For instance, nothing in the game has upkeep except for units. This means the economic side of the game is mostly unit/no unit decisions. But provinces should have things you can build outside the city for upkeep. Garrisons at choke points, shrines, mines, or other things that cost upkeep or had benifits/drawbacks would create a diversity of economic choices and make each province feel more interesting and personalized. This is an example of something that would have made each campaign feel more interesting to me.)

So enjoyable. The high elves are so great, all of the leaders were in my hands. Oxyotl and Eltharion campaign gave me the best experience with any TotalWar there is. Came back to vampire counts and went on to conquer whole world like in the 1st TW:WH game. Magic is satisfying AF! Units are beautiful, same the terrain. 900+ hours, such a good time... So nostalgic, such a good time....

And yet, I am so exhausted, so dissapointed at the end. Every single faction tries to attack me, no matter the distance, no matter the map situation, no matter the faction strength difference; just attack player, attack player, attack player. Everything dies so fast, I cannot even feel interested in a single battle or look on this shiny super unit graphics. Siege battles are so boring, ugh, I always autoresolve them, even if it not gives me a good outcome. The confederation system is idiotic, some races are just turbocollecting terrain and others are doomed to gain everyghing on their own. It hurts me the most, when almost dying faction, like Reikland or Naggarond confederates a lot stronger faction, just to spite player.

Had a lot of hopes for TW:WH 3 but this game wasted me so much... like, drained completelly to the point, I do not love TotalWar games anymore :(

Still, I recommend this game. Just to feel the awesomeness of everything You will get and the painful burnout of Your TotalWarLover soul at the end.

[b]This will be more of the rant toward the developers rather than a review.[/b]

Overall the game's fine and there is a lot to admire design-wise, but there are tons of glaring issues that leave a bad taste in your mouth. Most of them technical or monetary.

Having sailed the Black Ark for a while now - for the single-player and checking out the DLCs beforehand - I finally bought this because of the multiplayer, and only because there was a big discount. On the topic of high seas - the Steam version runs worse than the cracked one, there is at least a 10% loss to performance. I can only assume it's because of Denuvo. Give me a break.

[b]Graphics[/b]
It's personal to a degree but to my eye it clearly looks worse than Total Warhammer 1 (i.e. lighting is odd if not outright broken, something people pointed out at release and it seems to still be an issue).

[b]Performance[/b]
Bad performance is easier to point out. First of all, it simply runs very poorly on 1440p+ resolutions. The FPS are lower than TWH1 without offering a significant or justifiable improvements. The first game looked just fine, there was no need to push for more "advanced" tech. If you're making what frankly is a glorified expansion (TWH 1.5), don't force in more demanding tech that many players won't be able to run, just to be able to claim that's it's "new and improved".

If you don't set everything to High/Ultra, it's an eye sore and loses a ton of aesthetic value. And I'm talking about the campaign view here, not even the battles. There is nothing on the map that needs this kind of hardware. I don't have a habit of calling developers lazy, the story is often more complicated than that, but I can't come up with any other description here. The engine is trash and has been so for years now.

[b]Downloadable Content[/b]
The DLCs policy is by now infamously bad and for good reason. At best it's confusing and requires more than the usual amount of research to understand what works with what, across two games. Some of the content is very good and clear effort and thought went into it, but everything is overpriced. Some of it is laughably bad and should've been discounted to 1 quid/dollar or given away for free. The Blood God situation is terrible no matter how you slice it. I don't mind the Mortal Empires policy, but it could've been handled better.

[b]Positives[/b]
One thing that has to be said is that there was a lot of free content, patches and reworks of existing races that went into the title post-release. In my mind, that does somewhat make up for the past mistakes and fills with confidence for the future, but in the end I decided to leave a thumbs down review to communicate the lingering issues. If Creative Assembly continue with this level of quality and dedication, the third entry should be free of some of the problems that have plagued the franchise.

However I know that *if* I ever get around to buying the sequel, it will be years after release, at a steep discount.

A solid game for people new to the franchise, casual players or those who love the Warhammer lore, however a disappointing and poorly implemented upper difficulty campaign makes for a forgetful late game and at times, often a not very enjoyable one. The creative team have done a phenomenal job here, with the art and animations. There is an awful lot of very good content to be built upon here for the next game and with a few changes to sieges and some balancing adjustments, TW:W3 could be a fantastic game. If however you are a returning TW player, or someone who enjoys playing on the harder difficulties then this game falls short.

If you like running down hordes of zombies with Knights and Dragons, planning sieges against Vampire castles, just destroying evil in general by the thousands, then this game is for you. 

If you like being bad and just decimating those dumb Humans, dwarves, and annoying Elves with giant Lizards and Ogres, then buy this game and do what you were born to do, to bring down the world of man and make Sauron proud.

As of Jan 23. Still better than WH3 IE. (opinion)

I've played too much. Yes. But I still come back to it. It's got to be my top game of all time, I remember saying that when WH1 was fresh. - and I've been gaming since the 80's (OK, Boomer!). 

Thinking of getting into it ? Want the option of a vet/addict? 

I'm going to be explaining why I've gone back to WH2 having played 600 hrs of WH3. For some reason i finally feel the need to express myself on what I consider to be a masterpiece of strategy gaming.

I have all 3 games and all dlc's other than WH3's ones. There is enough content here to keep you going and coming back for 10000+ hours. Value is not a factor in terms if cost. It's there. For all the criticisms that can be placed on the Dev, CA. They really put there heart and soul into these games and it shows. Not perfect, nothing is - get over it lol - but great, no doubt in my mind.

Engaging, challenging, fun and often very very funny - Brian Blessed is great as Gotrek " Squeaky Bum Time!" Goblins chanting " Stab Stab Stab! " poor Malekith complaining " abominable snow!" Voice acting A+

There's a depth and breath of mechanics that just provides so many options to explore and perfect. WH2 has some cheese to be exploited - they removed most of it in WH3 - but that's part of what I find fun - the Empire's endless hordes of Heroes with insane impact in the campaign and battle maps for one, there so many to pick as examples. It's just fun - not balanced - but fun - Pretty much all gone from WH3.

WH3 hasn't hit the right notes - for me - it feels slow and tedious compared to WH2. The world its so much bigger, they deliberately made the travel distances longer (2 turns between settlements compared to one in previous versions). The pace of battles has also been slowed. Some of the under the hood mechanics have been tweaked  - CP if you know about that - basically the enemy will route off the battlefield if you get too far ahead in any given battle. All too often in WH3 I've been sat the waiting for the battle to end and it just feels draggy - specially in Major Settlement battles. "Is it over yet?"

The new races in WH3 are great, brilliant models and interesting (enough) mechanics, little short on troop rosters though. Love Nurgle armies personally, hilarious.

WH3 has some really really great QoL tweaks, much needed improvements to WH2. They removed the AI cheats that dominate WH2 meta - your melee troops will suck, regardless of tier in WH2 - you have to rely on missiles, arty and magic to do killing in WH2 - WH3 feels much more balanced from this aspect. So there are big positives for 3, I completely acknowledge that.

They removed the exponential increases in maintenance costs for troops so you can field many more armies to address the above issues. But the most recent patch did it in for me - removing (effectively) the settlement battles that were a key feature of WH3 - they almost never happen - and REMOVING WALLS FROM MINOR SETTLEMENTS!!! I can't tell you how much that ruined the game for me. Minor settlement battles were ok, the major settlement battles are bloated and tedious, they feel unnaturally drawn out and painful, as said above. tower and barrier mechnics - so meh.

I personally really dislike the look and feel of the new WH3 maps, graphically and design. WH2 is just straight up prettier and way more detailed. Sure concessions were made for the scale vs performance, I get there are reasons for these things, But WH3 looks like a cartoon in comparison - for the campaign map. Also the newly designed battle maps - some are just really badly designed, they look unnatural with weird isolated circular pockets of trees, also hill formations that just make battle more painful - a design issue so very subjective, but bugged me a lot. They feels rushed in design and don't really add much in terms of tactics.

WH2 had so much time to mature and that is still the case - WH3 may get there but for me there are some design choices that are jarring. The updates for WH3 are waaaaay too slow - CA appear to have less resources committed to WH3 than for WH2? dunno for sure bit seems to be. 

As a game, Highly recommenced, if you are ok with  long investments of time to do campaigns - I've not PvP'd at all, which would be more pick up and play for short periods of time - I'm saying it's a time sink.

WH3 - I dont thin it's going to get there my friends. There are some fundamental design choices that I think make 3 more distict from 2 that 2 was from 1 - haha if that makes any sense?

Buy 1 and 2, get all DLCs other than the blood one (pointless rip off).

Boomer, signing off.

Cannabis,[a] also known as marijuana[b] among other names, is a psychoactive drug from the cannabis plant. Native to Central or South Asia, the cannabis plant has been used as a drug for both recreational and entheogenic purposes and in various traditional medicines for centuries. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is the main psychoactive component of cannabis, which is one of the 483 known compounds in the plant, including at least 65 other cannabinoids, such as cannabidiol (CBD). Cannabis can be used by smoking, vaporizing, within food, or as an extract.

Cannabis has various mental and physical effects, which include euphoria, altered states of mind and sense of time, difficulty concentrating, impaired short-term memory, impaired body movement (balance and fine psychomotor control), relaxation, and an increase in appetite. Onset of effects is felt within minutes when smoked, but may take up to 90 minutes when eaten. The effects last for two to six hours, depending on the amount used. At high doses, mental effects can include anxiety, delusions (including ideas of reference), hallucinations, panic, paranoia, and psychosis. There is a strong relation between cannabis use and the risk of psychosis, though the direction of causality is debated. Physical effects include increased heart rate, difficulty breathing, nausea, and behavioral problems in children whose mothers used cannabis during pregnancy; short-term side effects may also include dry mouth and red eyes. Long-term adverse effects may include addiction, decreased mental ability in those who started regular use as adolescents, chronic coughing, susceptibility to respiratory infections, and cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome.

Beautiful game with INCREDIBLE large-scale battles; it's very fun to watch armies battle it out. It's like being a director of your very own Lord of the Rings movie-grade battles. But that's where the positives end.

It is a very unbalanced game... at least regarding AI opponents. It's the classic game developer problem of giving AI opponents WAY TOO MUCH resources, supports, map awareness, cheats, etc. to keep up with human players. Challenge is one thing. Balance is something else-- and the devs really missed the mark on this. Even playing on the easiest settings I was struggling to make it to "mid-game" (and I would consider myself an experienced Civ 5 player). But this might be remedied with a considerable amount of research and practice. 

Unfortunately, I was past the 2-hour limit of gameplay so Steam would not refund my purchase-- despite the game being bought less than 48 hours ago. Disappointing. 

I might come back and play this eventually, but much more likely it will fall into the deepest depths of my Steam backlog.



TLDR: If you can tolerate terrible balancing and AI, to the point where it is almost game-breaking... then go for it! There are fun moments to be had in this game. The large-scale battles are the saving grace.

Otherwise... SAVE YOUR MONEY!

EDIT - STILL much better than Warhammer 3...

Please note, the learning curve is steep, but after a few battles and mistakes (plus a few tutorial videos) you will be able to manage just fine. There is mixed feelings about the paid DLC, which I do agree with most of the negative attitude towards content that should have never been cut (looking at you Blood for the Blood God!!) and later charged, I did purchase most DLCs and was quite happy with said purchases.

The game really scratches the tactical itch. So if you're someone who enjoys tactical games with a fantasy backdrop then Total War: Warhammer 2 is for you!

NOTE: To unlock the "open" world sandbox-like mode, you will need to purchase Total War: Warhammer (the first game) in order to unlock this. Also plan to invest in a few purchases, especially with Warhammer 3 due out soon. If you are only interested in trying the game out and less interested in the big campaigns, then:

 - Purchase only Total War: Warhammer or Total War: Warhammer 2

If you're interested in the open world mode as well as the story mode (getting caught up with the current content) then:

- Purchase Total War: Warhammer
- Purchase Total War: Warhammer 2

For DLC, you only need to purchase ones that would interest you. If you are interested in Undead then:
- RIse of the Tomb Kings (The Tomb Kings army unlocked in both story campaign and open world)
- Curse of the Vampire Coast (Vampire Pirates, really need I say more!)
 (The remaining undead DLCs are more if you want another Lord in your armies and some are not very good, purchase if you only want to complete your roaster).
If you play High Elves:
- The Queen and the Crone is excellent and a must have for High Elves, plus it isn't too bad for Dark Elves either.
Now it is worth knowing that there are some DLCs under the Total War: Warhammer (first game) that player might want. If you want to play Wood Elves and Chaos Knights are purchased through the Total War: Warhammer (first game) page, but once you unlock these armies they DO carry over to Total War: Warhammer 2!

Okay, there is a lot of videos to aid you on your armies, tactics, etc. The game is fun and rewarding! Worth the price! Hope this helps, happy gaming! 

NOTE: As of now, Warhammer 3 is still being worked on with the option to purchase it before it is complete. Tempting, but most players want to play the sandbox mode - Immortal Empires, but it is seriously buggy and imbalanced.

EDIT - After all this time, I realize that CA's Warhammer IP isn't really all that good. The other Total War games are much better and to be honest, Warhammer, Warhammer 2 AND especially Warhammer 3 are troubled games. I know this isn't what most of you think, but there ARE much better strategy games on the market. OH and MUCH MUCH cheaper!! Anyways, I am sure there are many who disagree and some who just want to relive those tabletop Warhammer days (and CA's Warhammer series does that - sort of) but CA needs to do better. Plan and simple.

More difficult than what I expected going into it. I am new to the Total War franchise but was drawn in by the Warhammer Old World aspect. Almost perfect. For a long time I would have opined this to be the gold standard in Total War games - for the historical fan it offered an expansion on the exotic magic and monsters of Warhammer 1, and for the tabletop fans it introduced the more fantastical races with more ambition and faithful detail than ever. Mortal Empires was the pinnacle of this, both game maps mashed together into one huge campaign - a campaign which showed off the best of its global map strategy and real-time battle tactics.

Weaknesses (such as the one-dimensional sieges and flatness of older races) were concealed by dedicated modders, and eventually CA themselves once they began releasing DLC that reached across both games to offer extra race content for the old guard of the Old World. Although there is now an intimidating amount of dlc, I would say it all justifies its asking price, and you will certainly get your money's worth from this title. These days Warhammer 3 is the more obvious choice and is overall a stronger experience, but sometimes the old ways are best.

i would recommend this game for die hard fans of the genre considering the OVERWHELMING AMOUNT OF DLC.

This game will nickel and dime you out of roughly $200 or more for a single player.

It is really a cash grab and there is very little integrity in the business model for the game, but that doesn't mean the game isn't solid. 

The game itself is actually really well programmed and the faction balance is very well designed.

Pros:

1. Graphics are great
2. The game runs fairly well
3. The AI is very smart and is tough on you forcing you to not only focus on military prowess
4. A vast array of factions to play
5. A vast array of sub factions to play
6. As opposed to earlier releases of the series this introduces more "abstract" or "fantasy" style type troops ie wizards etc...
7. The interface is non-intrusive and well made
8. The tutorial in this game is very in depth
9. The battle details are amazing.

Cons:

1. Tons and tons of DLC. 
2. The AI can be rather rough to the point of frustration resulting in discouragement at times. (Managing to have way too much strength militarily etc..)

Conclusion:

Bottom line is that the game is VERY PRICEY and Creative Assembly has had this market cornered for a number of decades for a good reason. There is no way any other company that I have seen has placed this much detail, effort, and time into a strategic game

I say they have created a great product but have gotten too big for their britches.

The price tag is getting too big and a lot of people are leaving the genre because of it.

Total War: Warhammer III has released and though this review is not about TW WH3 must say their effort upon launch of TW WH3 is much less than the effort put into TW WH2.

This is very indicative of when a company has decided to cut quality while asking for the same price tag.

Build a brand with a good product and then take quality away from it. 

In other words, I truly believe that TW WH2 is the last of the series that any effort will be put into by Creative Assembly.

I say get it while you can, but only for people that are hard core fans of the genre.

To be honest the game is a bit of a letdown. As a longtime TW fan i was excited about the fantasy setting and in that aspect it's refreshing. However the mid to late game became frustrating after 100 or so turns. The layout of the map causes every race to be very isolated from each other and since your main goal is to achieve more magical shards than your enemies you barely have the need to explore. However, after 100 turns you will get attacked 20 times per turn from ships full of armies out of all different directions and ending every turn just becomes a tiresome process. The gameplay is simply not very well balanced and the map doesn't allow you to strategically secure your position. It seems this Total War forces a certain playstyle on the player, where there is no room for careful planning or empire building, but instead you should rush to keep up with the pace of the enemies and have dozens of fights every turn. Not my personal cup of tea..

I recommend this game, BUT there are some issues with this game that won't be patched out as the focus on future development will be of Warhammer 3.

This game is great on so many levels. Music, graphics, game play, the depth and intricate systems. an easy 8-9/10.

some of the issues are really major. A simple one is, I am unable to win. I have conquered the whole map. And there isn't an inch left uncovered. And the final objective I need to complete to win for a victory screen, "Kill the leaders of the factions of Chaos", won't complete. There are no factions left to kill. And online, there are reports of players who have the Chaos invasion turned off, and still are given that unwinnable objective they can't complete. 

So there's a good chance you could be on turn 250+ and 80 hours in, with all short and long term goals complete, and unable to "win". I mean, I know i've won at this point. but not being able to get that victory screen sucks.

The 2nd thing I don't care for is how the diplomacy system works. I won't go into depth here, but I find it very lacking. A game I've played with a diplomacy system I prefer is Endless Space 2. But the two games are very different in how the campaign map is structured, so I know the way diplomacy works in ES2 wouldn't necessarily be the perfect solution for Warhammer 2. But it is a reference point for a direction to head in for where I'd like diplomacy to go in future installments in this franchise. I understand Warhammer is a higher emphasis on war, so maybe it was never intended for diplomacy to be a great option. 

3, standard diplomacy is bad. Lizardmen diplomacy to confederate with other Lizardmen might as well not exist. Lizardmen will only confederate if you outpower them 5 to 1, AND if they are surrounded on 5 sides by their other enemies. They will refuse your money and any offer to confederate even if your relations are over 500, even with mods. I had to wait until relations were around 700 to finally confederate with my next door neighbors, at turn 200. This forces you to wage war if you want to own that land. Which depending at what point of the campaign you are in, they may have a military alliance with the other major factions, so if you wage war to force the issue you may trigger WW3. Making Lizardmen the only race that becomes nearly impossible to confederate the entire race into a single faction. This may be working as intended, but if it is, I don't know why this was their intent. 

Overall though. This game will steal days of your time and be a fun time.

Edit:
I'm changing my review from positive to negative in view of the absolute state of Total War Warhammer 3 and the unceremonious abandonment of Total War: Three Kingdoms. Original text to follow below. The two main changes of opinion I've had on this game are 1. That I can't give credit to the developers for the amazing modding scene and 2. That Total War Warhammer 2 offers almost no improvements over the first game whatsoever and represents a complete lack of ambition by the developers. It falls short of the amazing potential that a Total War Warhammer game has. It doesn't even have an option to customize and paint your armies and units  - even though that really is an essential feature for a Warhammer inspired game. What's more, we are about to experience history repeat itself with Warhammer 3 where almost no gameplay improvements will be made, no army painter will be present, and the only new things will be a handful of new factions that don't really interest me. I won't be buying Warhammer 3 on launch and I'm left heartbroken over the realization that Total War's developers have such a low level of ambition for their games and the scope of the features to put in them. 

Original Review Text:
I did not play the original TWW because it seemed like too many issues were weighing that game down: Ridiculously fast battles, terrible siege battles, limited regional occupation etc etc. The launch of the sequel made me reconsider however, since new features were added and regional occupation was fixed - and because it included my favorite army, the High Elves.

I enjoyed my first foray into the Eye of the Vortex quite a bit, however there were also plenty of painful moments. Especially the Ritual mechanic is very frustrating with the way the Chaos/Skaven incursions are implemented. Later forays into Mortal Empires further informed my opinion on the vanilla game. I'll break down my thoughts in bullet points.

Pros:
+ great army variety (many different unit types), both within army lists and of course between factions
+ great character development for lords and heroes, also quest battles
+ good sandbox gameplay, especially in Mortal Empires
+ Interesting and appropriate campaign map features/mechanics
+ Vortex story and cortex currency work well enough

Cons:
- Battle speed is extremely fast, units die way too quick
- Lord and Hero characters have huge health bars are deployed as single warriors without a retinue of bodyguards as was the case in previous total war games
- One on one combat in battles is poorly animated, no Med 2 style sync kills
- Too many redundant activated unit abilities like magic spells and buffs
- AI problems in battle and on campaign map
- Overly simplistic diplomacy breaks immersion constantly, wars happen for no reason and you can't give/buy regions
- Terrible siege battles
- Units become obsolete as you tech up because of straight-up better units
- Vortex rituals senselessly punish the player as Chaos forces triple-team and raze ungarrisoned tier 5 cities on ritual turn 1

The consequences of the way too fast battle speed  are not to be underestimated. Battles will last for 3-4 minutes and you'll be pausing constantly to issue new orders. The two battle lines of disciplined infantry will break apart as one side wins after just half a minute of fighting. In classic total war, the infantry would slog it out for far longer while you would maneuver with your reserves, cavalry and skirmishers to swing the battle in your favor. That's how an inferior force is able to win. If the main engagement only lasts for half a minute, there's no choice but to rush in with everything and hope you have enough. If your army is weaker, that initial engagement will go badly and then it'll all be over. Not to mention that the high speed gives you zero time to appreciate the atmosphere of the battle - further reducing immersion. So much for my opinion on the fast battles.

Luckily this most glaring issue was solved for me by the inclusion of Steam Workshop mods into the game. My personal winning mod turned out to be Carnage in the New world, which slows down the battles and also gives each hero character a retinue of bodyguards in battle. The moddability of TWW 2 is thus what saved it for me and what will likely save it for many others as well.

Getting Mortal Empires and just going wild with all the 20-30 Legendary Lords at your disposal is a great experience as each faction will not only have different armies and campaign mechanics, but also faction specific victory conditions. Bretonnia's Errantry War is a personal favorite so far. 

So all in all this is a game you can have a ton of fun with. Mortal Empires brings virtually all of the Warhammer Fantasy universe to life, which makes it virtually an auto buy for any tabletop fan. And Warhammer newcomers will have a great introduction to this ridiculous but epic world. And the replay value is just off the charts since each campaign can last many dozens of hours.

The Vortex Campaign is not as good as the Grand Campaign in the first game. It feels too linear and forced, whereas the Grand Campaign was more along the lines of do whatever.

However, Mortal Empires more than makes up for this. The AI turn times while playing Mortal Empires doesn't feel as long as CA predicted, in fact it feels infinitely faster than it should which is amazing.

Each faction feels unique, even the different sub-factions. All of the Legendary Lords feel distinct from each other. The AI is aggressive but not overbearing, a fine balance was struck. 

Mortal Empires is both incredibly frustrating and rewarding. Watching allies crumble in the face of the combined might of the Vampire factions is the cause of 80% of the stress in my life, especially considering the Empire is sitting on four stacks of twenty unit armies and refuses to do anything to combat this threat. However when my allies who are warring against the Vampires with me do finally listen to my advice and help push back the horde of undead I do not believe I have ever felt a greater sense of relief and satisfaction.

More of the same: slaughter, kill-kill Skaven and prancing High Elves waiting to get wrecked. Now with Vampirates and exploding, running corpses added to the mix! Yay!

The combined land mass and races of Warhammer I and II in the Mortal Empires gives players plenty of options. The factions are different and depending on the legendary lord, the races themselves can work in many ways. Replay value is high!

Warhammer II offers lots of replay value even if you don't own the prequel. The Vortex campaign with the different main races will provide plenty of entertainment. Some of the DLC races and legendary lords have their own campaigns, keeping the game fresh. Playing as the Brass Bull is quite different from the Sisters of Twilight for example.

With the launch of Warhammer III, those that own all three games Warhammer III offers unparalled replayability in the form of the Immortal Empires. For those that want a good campaign though, Warhammer II is still the answer. The Vortex campaign and various other campaigns for the DLC races are the best the series has to offer.

I feel that TWWII is the benchmark which all future versions of TW should be gauged.  TW3K's meets this mark where TWTB misses the mark.  I love this game and continue to play it over and over and over again.

I really want to  love this game  especially since I adore the Fantasy setting of Warhammer and loved the old TW's but......... 

Edit here: im discounting in-game Dlc content, and will *try* to talk about vanilla only m'kay.

Main Cons (which cripple the game) -Poor Optimization; Game runs like pooh (Like real bad if you dont have a decent pc and was/is still poorly optimized so prepare for that). 

-Simplification&Blandness; Every faction just seems like they're just copy pasted of each other with only a few couple slight touch-ups here to differentiate. (funnily enough and a example would be The Dark Elves and the Skaven who almost play similar to each other aka (("the numbers game/meat grinder tactics")) in TWW 2, even though while dark elves in the warhammer, tend to be glass cannons ((Hit like trucks,break like glass)) however in TWW2; they lack the truck part).
skaven however shouldn't really be Glass cannons in the game, since skavens should in warhammer (rely massively on meat grinder tactics, swarms for the bulk of their armies and *really* hard hitting abominations and contraptions, while receiving buffs if they're in a swarm, which they do not, they also cannot naturally climb/dig over/under walls like they can in both lore and in other games, same like gobbos but that's up for debate) and that's a *single* example to also make them all seem somewhat "special" but they really aren't and it really does show.  

-Greed; CA also has a greedy policy for their games and DLC just like Paradox does ($15-25 per DLC $75-85+ for the base game) with lack luster-mediocre content and the sad part is 90% of TTW 2 is exactly just like EU4 in regards as it is only DLC and it is pretty fucking bad...... don't believe me? uninstall *ALL* the dlcs and we'll see who's right.

-Sheer Laziness; There are many, instances here of such. but I will provide a quite (in)famous (unfixed/not added) example here; "The Musket animation issue". There is a textbook definition of: "no excuse" here for all the musket men in the game *Especially for the Human ones* to not have *any* of type reloading animations for their muskets (they just literally wiggle their guns up in the air). Especially since *such has already been made in prior games*
all CA had to do here; was just simply add the prior animation code for their unit tables that was already in Empire/Napolean&Shogun 2 here to TWW2's unit tables (TWW's engine is almost similar to all those three games, I can gurrantee you this here. since I have knowledge in modding the series. starting from the first 3-d games here to the newer engine games ((starting From Empire+)) )   

Side Cons:
 Lore inconsistencies- (units and factions), Repcons of previous lore- ( Ex Weaker famous warlords, like Grimgor and Archoan the EverChosen) 
(also they only did the repcons for JUST this game btw), 

Missing units and hero's/lords for factions- ( ex, no mummies or scarabs for TK's or Valten/Luthor Hoss for the empire, No Empire chapterhouse knights, no hochland long rifles, none of the empire unique steam tanks, 90% of actual choas units are non-existant, no daemonettes, no plague-bearers, no bloodletters, pink horrors or choas juggernaughts,nurglings and etc), 

Missing/improper Factions- ( Ex no Marks of chaos, its only a mechanic for the main chaos faction), the Nippon colonies-(the japanese-like faction in warhammer, The amazonians(the aztec warrior-like people in the new world), The Dogs of war (its a "unified" merc faction in the warhammer universe), The southern kingdoms (basically the italian-like factions in warhammer, they somewhat are different and distinct from the empire itself, which the empire itself is German-like), the pirate kingdoms of Sartosa, ((saltspyres faction)) does *not* count in this review because a) its dlc and b) it's wrong; There should be another island close by sartosa which HUMAN pirates ((and Ogres)) inhabit and their a "unified" faction is called that. saltspyre's faction should be completely different from them), The ogre kingdoms, Araby-(the saracens of warhammer)  and etc) ((Sidenote here about Chaos- Chaos Cannot be generalized as easily like it is currently in the game since it has multiple AND different "Marks" or factions for all the chaos gods and each of the chaos gods, their warriors who fight for them in this game are summarized as one which is incorrect and makes no sense since 90% of the time, they fight amongst themselves in lore due to them being the opposite of themselves (like Khorne versus Nurgle) and pretty much in every other source, the game also does not state that if the main choas faction represents choas undivided or not and even if it was so it cant *really* be a "true" faction since most who are choas undivided usually ends up siding with one god themselves or the warband leader decides for them by force since they all usually get tempted by one of the choas gods somehow or someway (unless your name was Kul but he died WAY before the setting of TWW 2 takes place ((like a couple of hundred years before and during the reign of  Magnus The Pious))  *which TWW2's setting/backdrop takes place, in the end of times era*) ,

it has Pathetic Gore and strategy- its honestly the worst In any TW AND Warhammer i've ever seen and both are *known* for their Gore (mostly Warhammer here) and TW for its strategy.

Pepperidge farms remembers- CA also employed alotta main influencer-like TW youtuber's to be falsely positive about this game both at launch and currently as I write (Edit a year later of the review: they've been tonned down a little, since the creation of the review)........

.So in short Just play Team BOTET's version (Call of Warhammer) mod for Medieval 2 instead it's alot more better, fun and more detailed than this........ and its free or better yet play the mount and blade mod of warhammer called Warsword Conquest (its literally based on warhammer). it is also free to play like BOTET's mod and it is as equally true to the series.
