Do not buy, i love the universe. avoid like the plague. Out of the 4 Total war games iv played this is by far the worst. I don't pretend to be the best Total war player. But looking at things like, i can have a lord recruit troops out his ass in the middle of the map, but if i do this the lord on the other side of the province in a settlement shares the same 3 recruit pool. so you manage a faction. one lord at a time. Also, god mode beast men will be waiting in ambush at turn 4 outside the ruins your quested with taking. A full army, no economy, no recruitment cost, no upkeep, no settlements. they are rogue, scary and spawn out of the blue, early. If your army is standing still, on the map, with no destination planned. you can still get ambushed. meaning you get no deployment phase, your enemy can spawn anywhere around your army, you cant retreat, and your army is stretched out in a column as if it was in march. I remind you, that would be really cool. If your army wasn't standing still and you already knew the enemy was there for 2 turns. Also they had to move the length of your lords maximum map movement range to "ambush" your army. God mode beast men. Total war aside can we all agree that Warhammer needs to stop with the gluttonous behaviour. If you want the sand box mode, If you just want to manage a faction without playing the vortex campaign. which, in my opinion is a pushy and annoying mess with constant pop ups from 3 different advisers. compared to Medieval 2 or Napoleon. To unlock the "free" mortal empires campaign you must first purchase the previous game at full price. Because overpriced 3 foot tall Titans and miniatures don't make them enough money, cool as they are. If you love Warhammer, maybe try 3. maybe you'll have a better time with this game. But if you want a much better Total War experience then I highly recommend Napoleon or Medieval 2.

This review is for the linux port made by Feral interactive.  The game crashes with a segfault error on the loading screen between post-battle and map transitions, so hours of carefully micro'ed battles go right down the drain.  The frequency of the error increases as more of the map is discovered until auto-resolve is the only way to play the game.  After searching for a solution it seems this issue extends back for years.  Feral interactive needs to fix this issue.

The other steam linux forced compatibility version are so poorly ported that they're unplayable.  

Great.  Now the prophet and the warlock DLC is not working.  Games says to restart to use new DLC which was working before but now does not work after restart of game, computer, or reinstallation.  What a mess.

The segfault and dlc issues are still there even after upgrading from lucid linx to jellyfish ubuntu.  This wasn't a problem until I wrote the review about feral.

Bye Linux Os.  See you in another 5 years.

I really want to leave this game a good review, because it's quite fun, but I can't because it crashes *constantly*.  In fact, its favorite time to crash is immediately after a manual battle, which is the *worst possible time* to crash, because you've just spent a half-hour of tense un-save-point-able time in-game.  Since it crashes so often, this is sometimes on the like third of several defensive battles, which you can't save in-between.  So, you've just spent like two hours meticulously micro-managing my troops, and then the game crashes and you get to start all over.

Very Very Annoying Tutorial Forced onto me that makes me frustrated as all actions are blocked until you make tutorial guy happy.
Takes away your camera control a lot, makes the whole game feel jarring as it zooms down. And you have to spend your time fixing the camera again how you had it, causing you to loose orientation.
Also the tutorial is horrible UI wise and keeps taking away control, on my widescreen there is a small button to press to continue, getting me stuck for minutes until i see that and oh.. they blocked all actions until you click X, then they let you do WHAT I TRIED TO DO for 2 MINUTES... and got "NO I BLAME YOU, NO CANT DO"
And again, Tutorial... oh my god stop moving my CAMERA AROUND. It feels like a bad 2000's game that has camera pans 'YOU GOTTA GET THIS TARGET"

But i feel for anyone who has to redo the whole save game and has to suffer though HOURS of tutorial.
Maybe its done this way so you go over the 2 hour refund time, and can't get your money back when you get to the actual game and its terrible.


Unit Selecting is tiresome and forces too many Actions, no CTRL + 1 - 0 Binding of units to hotkeys. Causing endless moving camera back and forth between units to actually place them. 
Oh my god the camera even has a delay and you fight against the inertia to have an actual fast action per minute..
There is also no mini map to click and move between parts of the map, making even harder to play properly.
There is a way point option but they ignore it half of the time if you manage to do actually the properly set it up, they ignore it halfway and just sit around while the other half does something...
And then its horribly bad when you are trying to set a route, then set way they should line up and you end up making a cross as you try to get it working and have to start all over as you did too many useless way points.. UGH!

When a enemy is routed, they run and scatter and even if you click on the right hand portion, they just go all run after 1 unit on the far left... Wtf is that path finding and priority.
And due the lack you can't hotkey units, i end up having half of them somehow forgotten in some forest till i zoom out enough.. Cause there is no dam mini map to tell you.
Bad Camera Controls, there more meant for an Editor than a RTS. Horrible lag by switching between map and tactical view, by forcing repeated scrolling (20 sec) to switch.
Why do they let you scatter the enemy, i want to kill them all, this just seems horrible to leave some alive, as technically they could rally later against you again. What flawed logic in this.

It seems like this whole game is written and balanced around the top down tactical view. Which is Incredibly boring.
Yet you miss out on the End Battle button in the Overview Mode that's actually more overview than crappy sideways 3D camera that has not enough fov for a proper overview and no proper movement.. And i spend 5 minutes figuring out wtf going on when i routed them all, oh boy is it booing...,oh wait i am in the overview camera.. and it hid the dam End Battle Button...

Overall it seems like its geared towards Players who never had an Actual Proper RTS. 
Or i am just too old and used to Warzone 2100 and Conquest Frontier Wars or even the so beloved starcraft.
Even settlers 3 did it better.
Overall it feels like it wants to be RTS but also wants to be addicting like Mount and Blade, Bannerlord.

I would quit and throw a Physical copy out the window, shatter the CD by accident and never play it again as it had 'Insert CD to play' if it was really a 2000's game :P
I guess this is what you call RTS Lite with Addictive Elements so you keep playing and playing..

Don't listen to the negative reviews.  I have never played a Total war game before, let alone RTS/Turn based games and I notice a trend that most of these reviews have far too little hours meaning they didn't even put in the effort to learn the game and actually find what is so fun about it.  That being said, I jumped into this game and thought I would get bored after about an hour, but the more I learned about the game, the more I wanted to keep playing.  After a day of watching guides and playing the game, I immediately became addicted and now I play this every day.  If you have a friend and want to play Co-op, I recommend getting Warhammer 3 as it has vastly improved multiplayer.  I've owned Warhammer 2 for a total of 7 days now and I already put 102 hours into the game.  That should speak for itself.  Also, Skaven supremacy.

Total War 2 has finally the story campaign we desperately needed, but that story is just another generic warhammer story where some things could've changed the setting and then revealed that it's not the case. Not a spoiler, but finishing the story is part of the campaign since you're technically raced againts other faction which isn't a desperate race. You could even say that the whole racing thing isn't a race since you keep having opportunity to catch up with ease. Even if you finally finish the race, the reward is rather ok and not that fulfilling.

In the base game, you'll play 3 factions like the Nice Elf, Evil Elf, and Rat people. And they have their generic traits; Nice Elf is good at archery (ranged), Evil Elf is good at sword (melee), Rat people are good at number (quantity). These 3 races has few factions too and their interaction is as limited as their race. This means Nice people can only interact with nice people since why not.

Battle gameplay, it's good.

With all the existing DLC, you better get it in a bundle since its improve many aspect of the game. And get it in a sale since it's obviously wants you to get all the DLC for the best experience. Too bad the ending of the base game is just OK, so just get it on SALE. Not recommend it with full price since it has many DLC's.

Having spent 430 hours in this game I have to say it's amazing. The sheer depth of content and number of races in mortal empires isn't matched by any other game I've played.

Having played it once a day for the last week or so and kept a log of the crashes, every session has at least 5 instances of the game just quitting to the desktop. Sometimes it freezes and I have to manually quit, other times it does it on its own. They occur randomly with no real trigger, but commonly on loading into battles or ending turn. 

I love this game, but while it is in this state I simply cannot recommend it.

This is an excellent medieval fantasy strategy title. But for what it provides in graphic quality and gameplay, it removes it in being particularly infested with glitches and bugs. And that's especially true with the multiplayer aspect. In solo mode, the game is fairly steady. But in multiplayer, expect *atrocious* loading times(in the area of 5 full minutes to load the game and another 5 minutes to load every multiplayer battle). In terms of glitches, this game has entirely frozen my PC multiple times to the point where only a hard PC shutdown would fix the issue. Along with numerous crashes along the way and the screen stuttering simply by moving the camera around the map. I am equipped with a Ryzen 7 5800X and AMD Radeon 6950 XT with 32 GB of Ram so hardware is not at fault here. I have tried to locate fixes to these issues and apply corrections to it but literally nothing works. 

EDIT: This game actually requires you to install it to an SSD for it to work correctly. Something that the developers should have added in the game requirements but haven't.

9/10 overall for the game but it gets a point off for not warning their clients about the importance of installing this game on an SSD.

EDIT #2: The multiplayer mode of this game is bugged and causing my entire PC to dead-lock after an hour of play or so. No fix exists despite this game being released 3 and a half years go. For this reason, I cannot recommend the game.

Word from the expert: All of this is caused by Windows 11

So I came back to this game after 3-5 years of not touching so I will adjust my review by saying this. I regretted it greatly. After 40 hours, I've uninstalled and it will remain uninstalled in my library till the end times. Its still amazing just how much the devs didn't playtest this game. One highlight was I was facing a Dark Elf lord, He Malus something, the legendary lord of Hag Graaf this was 35 turns in. He lost his entire army but wasn't routing. So I literally dunked all my high tier archer arrows onto him. After he lost about an eighth of health from like 7 or more volleys. He full healed, mind you this was the second time he used a full heal (or atleast a very powerful heal). So I used the rest of my arrows and he healed to full after that. So I dunked literally my entire army onto him. He kept getting stun locked so I suffered no casualties from the ensuing fight, but it took and I do not exaggerate. Atleast 10 minutes just to whittle him down, he had insane regeneration. For every 200 points of damage he took, he'd heal 100. 

Why the hell do Strategy game devs think that to make the game harder, the AI needs more cheats? Like come on, instead of making their AI smart and make good decisions to counter you. The devs just say, meh thats too much work and slap on a plus X amount of gold per turn, plus x amount of unit replenishment and x amount of attack and defence buffs. I'd rather get outsmarted by a foe than out-cheated. 

Old Review:

I had very, very high hopes for this game. I liked the factions, the map (before ME), the races, the beasts. But there are too many flaws to give this game a good review. 

                                                      NOT MODDABLE LIKE MEDIEVAL 2 TOTAL WAR
NO LOOSE FORMATION.
NO FORMATIONS AT ALL
-Before ME-
1. Extra army upkeep. This feature was horrible in Warhammer 1, and of course they had to keep it the same in this.
2. Diplomatic relations with certain factions while doing the rituals. It kinda makes no sense how the Lizardmen and the High elves can't team up considering that their goals are for the benefit of the world, or Dark elves and Skaven, since their goal is to use the Vortex for their own will.
3. Dragons and Hydras having cool downs on their breath attacks are just stupid. How can these mythical beasts have a cool down on breathing?
4. Intervention armies. so you pay 2000 for a crappy army to be destroyed 5 seconds later, pay 5000 for a somewhat good army but will be destroyed by the garrison or your last and final option, 10000 for an army of elites that a garrison stands a chance at winning. I found it idiotic how you can't decide where it can spawn, if i want it to be at a capital or a far flung island, makes it impossible for cordinating a double attack when your army spawns far away from the capital, but always the AI spawns at the capital.
5. Rituals requirements. At the first two rituals it took long to get the stuff, but later on it only took like 5-10 turns to unlock the next ritual.
7. Chaos armies during rituals. As i was playing as the High Elves i had major issues with the armies spawning out of nowhere as i start the ritual, its kinda hard to manage a war with the Dark elves, A war with Skaven and a war with the Lizardmen while five chaos armies and two skaven clans are torching ulthuan, and some people may say, get more armies scrub, but its impossible when you are losing 5k+ from extra army upkeep. And how Chaos armies always spawn in your weakest region.
8. How you can't dismount someone while they are riding a horse or chariot.
9. You think that in this that Eagles could soar through the skies and attack weak units like archers or artillery but no, they are very slow and are useless for running people down.
10. Spells, the spells were nice but there are far too many limitions for them, Teclis and Morathi are some of the best spellcasters there are and yet they have only a dozen spells.
11. Income, income was for the most part hard to raise for the high elves unless you have the Gold mines or gem cutters. The Entertainment building at tier 5 only produced 240 gold while the Industrey building at max produced 200 gold.
12. How few special settlements during battle there are, there are only a handfull of unique settlements, most of which are faction capitals. Attacking a faction capital was a suicide mission considering it would require atleast 2 full stacks of elites to attack it IF there is no army garrisoning it. While one really awful feature is when your capital is besieged your income just plumits by nearly 5k. I was playing High elves at 4 ritual so i started it and Dark elves sent a intervention army, it spawned and besieged me right away making my income which was 7k+ per turn go to a -1000 per turn which ruined all my garrisons and armies, right away i lost about a tenth of all my forces everywhere and that made it real easy for the Chaos forces to just steamroll me.
-After ME-
I had very high hopes for ME, because it would turn this game into a sandbox again, i wanted to play as the High Elves and just Fortify ulthuan and make it a fortress. Or play as the Dark Elves and Enslaved Bretonnia or the Dwarves. Then After it released i had the biggest disapointment of my life, bigger than COD Infinite Warfare.
1. Ulthuan lost multiple locations like Caladors Repose, The Glittering tower, Shrine of Lileath, Carin Thel, The Shadow peak and more. 
2. You could travel from the Cult of Pleasure's shore to Ulthuan in one or two turns.
3. Most of Naggaroth and Lustria was is gone.
4. Half of the New world is gone making it much more difficult for The Lizardmen, Order of Loremasters, Skaven, Vampire Coast and more smaller factions.
5. Half of the map below the Badlands (past the undead empires) are gone.

I have bought Medieval 2 total war, Rome 2, Attila and Warhammer 1. Warhammer 2 is better than Rome 2 and Attila but in comparison with Medieval 2 total war i would not put over 500+ hours into this because of how how little moddablity there is.
Fantastic game. First time players should definitely check out some walkthroughs and FAQs before diving in.

It's playable, and quite fun, but eventually the broken diplomacy mechanics will get on your nerves. It seems CA has abandoned this for Warhammer 3, so the diplomacy in 2 will never be fixed.

For this reason, I highly recommend you do not get this at full price. It's somewhat worthwhile, since factions and DLC carry over to Warhammer 3, but this version of the game has outstanding issues that make it quite frustrating to play. Wait for a big sale and pick this up on the cheap.

Around 2yrs ago, I was your average competitive FPS grinder, rushing through 1500+hrs of CSGO and then around 2500+hrs of Rainbow 6 Siege. I had never touched anything else apart from some good single player games. Playing those FPS games every day really affected my mental as somedays were awesome, but most were exhausting as I played the same map over and over and got outplayed by or just outgunned by others. Finally, I decided it was time to stop.

I began scouring Steam for random games that I may like and then Warhammer 2 caught my eye, partly because it was on sale. I had never played a strategy game ever but for some reason, the screenshots of entire armies fighting each other seemed really cool to me. So, I began searching for some gameplay videos to see how it played and then I found this video by "LegendofTotalWar" from his "Save your disaster battles" series. It featured a doomstack (essentially, an extremely powerful army) commanded by "Ikit Claw" a character lord from the game. The moment the battle started; I was spell bounded! Thousands of rats throwing poison bombs, shooting lightning cannons, firing Gatling guns and throwing pink fire at the enemies and burning them off! Even as someone who knew nothing of the game, I quickly realized how overpowered that army was and how quickly it was eradicating the enemy! That video basically sealed the deal for me, and I purchased the game immediately!

But I still was absolutely clueless as to how to play the game. I quickly searched for LegendOfTotalWar but realized that he was a veteran player and further Reddit searches informed me that he is an extremely good player who discovers and uses "cheese" tactics a lot, which while amazing, take time and practice and weren't suitable for beginners. And thus began my journey of schooling to learn Warhammer 2 as I began with Zerkovich's "You such at Total War" which taught me a lot of basics, and then watching multiple full campaign gameplays by awesome people like "Elven Plot Armor", who explained everything they did and "lionheartx10", etc.

Today, I am an absolute lover of the franchise and immensely enjoy my time with Warhammer 3, but WH2 will always hold a special place in my heart as it was the one that started it all!

A masterpiece!

Attention to detail is mind-dazzling. A team that created this game clearly put a lot of love in it. The game is full of light humor and awesome fantasy lore. I enjoy 'historical' total war, but this is just amazing.

Everything makes sense here. No silly siege mechanics (yes, I am looking at you, warhammer 3).

The battles are so good in Warhammer 2, I do them twice. First, I play them. Then, I watch them in slow-mo listening to glorious music. 

Goblins are my faves. Yes, the HORDE is coming for you, "warriors of light", hehehe. The HORDE - its huge, its evil,... and its yours.

I always come back to this game when i inevitably burn out on whatever game i fixate on for too long. The replay value is unmatched. So many factions so many tactics such a huge map. Personally i love playing chaos and beastmen (not just for the aesthetic) because its purely fighting and steamrolling anyone that gets in your way. The game is pricey but its worth every penny (youre gonna wanna buy total war warhammer 1 and most of the dlcs) also be prepared to spend many many hours of enjoyment for the full experience.

What you do is you get upgraded Wind of Death or Burning Head and you can drag it across multiple enemy units and it just rips through them. You delete units with mages. Or you can get them to fight a lord and a couple of heroes in a big clump and you just cast Flame Storm or something and it's "bye bye" enemy units. Do that a couple of times and you win. Or you can clump them up in the same way and then shoot them with arrows and bolts or artillery. 

Basically, you slow the enemy down and then shoot or magic them to bits. Sometimes you have to take out their artillery, missile troops or heroes first. That's when the battles get more interesting. 

That's how you win Total War: Warhammer 2 battles. And when you win all the battles, you win the (total) war.

edit: After another six hours with the game, and coming from a background of RTS games (I was diamond in Starcraft II), the A.I. of unit control is simply too frustrating to allow me to enjoy this game.

Example: I would issue orders for my units to begin engaging in battle. Separate orders for each separate squad formation.  Of all the groups, it seems that half the time only 20-40% of the squad formation would fight, the other 60% would sit in the back and chill. Yes, even archers would do this for some reason.

I would then reissue orders for that single squad to attack the same group, or a different group, it doesn't seem to matter. Most units would continue to pick their noses and enjoy their meal in fruitful delight.

This also seems to happen at the same consistency (very high consistency sadly), even when the battle just started, leadership is high and the squad of units isn't shaken, startled, panicked or anything along those lines.

The game simply feels unplayable to me due to the lack of responsiveness of units.

To add pain to the suffering, this is nearly 10 Total War games later, after they've had plenty of time to make the units have half-decent A.I. (or at the very least, listen to the player's own damn orders for god's sake), and as such I cannot recommend Total War games, at least not if you prefer any sense of order or control in a battle.

Your mileage may vary, but holy crap is this frustrating to me as an RTS player. Which really sucks since the game is very cool thematically and aesthetically.

My idea of a perfect game is a game that can easily be started, understood, but have unbelievable depth if desired. A game that no matter how wired and in-tune you are, there is always more to mentally overcome. 
Designed for high IQ players, the total war games are a refreshing unicorn, in an every dopamine quenching call of duty player and game base. 
Its an absolution perfection of a strategy game, with the ability to conduct and control incredibly fun real time battles if you wish, or just automatically resolve in a split second and continue your turn-based campaign. The turn based removes the stress, and allows complete focus on your empire, as well as giving the ability to dive in or out whenever.
Warhammer 2 release is the cherry on the top of the franchise, and one for simple reason. It leans into the magical theme and goes hard on it. So many factions to play as, so many unique abilities and features for each faction, makes each campaign decision or battle action special. 
I get lost in this game, but not the confused lost. The type of lost where all the geopolitical issues of the real world are vanished, i'm one with the game, with my race, living my best life, enjoying stretching my brain and completely satisfied when I conquer and build wealth.

This game is challenging to say the least. I have spent more time playing this game than any other single player game of the sort. It is a time suck though, set a timer or you'll find you've wasted the day away.  All that said there are some pros and cons:

*The pros:*

Fun campaign and map.

Can play this same campaign from any point of view and faction you want.

It's very challenging. 

Lots of strategies to win.

Can play fun battles or just auto win or lose.

Can save your place.

*The cons:*

The only campaign.

After a while this same campaign and map will get boring and you'll be wondering why there isn't more to this game other than different factions.

The AI cheats, in fact this is deliberate laziness on part of the developers. The AI cheats non stop. For once I would love to find a WH style strategy game where the AI doesn't cheat on what is basically infinite moves, omnipotence and infinite resource mode. Once you realize it cheats it sucks ALL of the fun out of the game. Every time I come back to this game it's on some idealized wish where I forget this is the case, then quit out of frustration because I can't even win on normal mode. I long for a game where nobody is cheating. Instead I'm stuck with literally every game out there being grossly unfair to play.

I am a 12 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my transgender Son, who is 82 now. My transgender son got this game for Christmas from his great great great great grandma, so we installed it on his calculator and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 0.1 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my transgender son, as he is always out with his fiends doing ritualistic activities, or doing drugs. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my transgender Son for help and he forced me to do 12 lines of cocaine before he helped me. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my transgender Son since my goldfish had died. This game has ever since brought me and my transgender son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together sacrificing people to the dark demon lords. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my transgender Son many happy memories.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

Total War Fantasy is a good introduction into Total War games and Warhammer Fantasy. The initial buy-in cost is pretty high, but it isn't as high as it seems. You do need both base games of TWH1 and TWH2, and maybe a few DLCs for your favorite factions, but you don't require all of them, if at all. 
The gameplay is fun and there's a very high level of attention to details. The entire development team put a lot of effort into this game and it shows. That being said, it is very taxing on most computer systems, and it does have some high minimum requirements. If you can run this game, its well worth its price, though I recommend waiting for sales if you want to buy DLC.

Total War: Warhammer 2 is in my opinion the best Total War game thus far. And yes Warhammer 3 is currently out. But it's buggy and needs balancing from what I've seen. After my 500+ hours I've barely bought any DLC. And I like the variety of approaches each faction and lord has. I've played around 5 Total War games, but there's just something amazingly shiny about Fantasy Warhammer Total War. It's well done. 

I should note. I do not play anything but Mortal Empires in this. Never even tried the other mode. Mortal Empires requires the purchase of Warhammer 1 as well as 2, It's a much bigger map that combines the 2 games in a more sandbox theme. 

Also, when Warhammer 3 gets better, It's worth noting that DLC purchased carries over to the new "Immortal Empires" epic massive entire world.... If I'm not mistaken. Feel free to comment and let me know.

This game doesn't feel like Total War. Neither did the first one. 

The graphics are epic, with huge creatures dwarfing the humans and, well, Dwarfs, but good luck finding a point in the chaotic battles to be able to enjoy those visuals. 

The units are awesome, from dragons and cannons to ents to simple footsoldiers, but despite the uniqueness to them, it really comes down to which unit has more experience. The strategy is lacking. I've had shield units hold a line while weaker units run behind the enemy and attack...and I still lost. Meanwhile every battle turns into chaos as units rout and then return to battle time after time. There's a ridiculous amount of micromanaging in this one compared to other Total War games because the speed is so high. 

As for the campaign, it has a beautiful map and lots of cool features, but I personally find it to be almost too chaotic as well. It's hard to keep up with where your armies are and what your relations are with other factions because the map has so much going on. Edit: Additionally there's almost no time for peace, where you build your nation and prepare your armies for war. You'll constantly be at war from the start and allies do more harm than aid as they call you into their wars. Continuing the point of endless war, you'll be limited to two armies around turn 30 because you never get to build your economy. It's incredibly hard to fight a two front war with just two armies...and then you must factor in unhappiness in your towns that pops up at the drop of a pen. If an enemy is raiding, your town is unhappy. If corruption gets too high, the town is unhappy. Soon you have rebellions, adding MORE foes to fight with your two armies and weak economy. 

Maybe this is an unpopular opinion, but I recommend sticking with the Warhammer mod for Medieval 2.

Edit: Maybe I'm just a loser whining because I'm bad at the game, but this is my opinion and having added edits after an additional 20 hours of gameplay, I stand by it.

Buyer beware, reviews are flooded with people who have long supported the Total War and/or the Warhammer series and are completely blinded by that.

This game costs a ridiculous amount of money to really get into and on top of that it's completely unfriendly to anyone trying to get into it. Selecting a starting "race" "faction" or even just the specific character is like playing slots at a casino, you could be alright but odds are you're just going to get absolute garbage. For some characters or even whole factions this is actually how it's supposed to be, to give players a challenge if they want to choose that but with no indication or warning for any of these you're just rolling a die and hoping you get a chance to even play the game to begin with.

On top of the previous flaws the advisor in the game is absolutely worthless. The advisor tries to tell you all about the backstory of the character you picked but doesn't say anything about what you should try doing to start or warning you from attacking the 1 single enemy they place right next to you because you're guaranteed to lose against that 1 single enemy despite anyone coming from literally anywhere thinking "Well, they gave me 1 enemy to attack at the start, I guess I should attack it."

TL;DR If you aren't going in to this game with some kind of financial backing and a trained professional there to guide you through every step of the game you'll probably end up hating this game and yourself for suffering through this horrible experience.

After 50 hrs on Warhammer 1 and 36 on 2 I am still dissapointed. The battles don't feel good. I have basically the same army composition as my enemy but I always need 2 or 3 armies to be able to beat them, in battle or just auto resolving. I create a spearmen line but some guy comes with cavalry and all the soldies in the unit so flying like 30-50 meters and they all scatter. I can't use real tactics, and yes you may say: "it is fantasy" but I don't know, after 80+ hours combining both games, how to play, I don't know why I need so many armies to defeat another, or how the AI seems to just roll out full armies that destroy mine even on the easiest difficulty setting, I don't like the small and simple sieges, the battlefields where theres too much stuff happening, the units that pull ladders outta no where. Im ok with the fantasy setting, in fact I was super hyped for Warhammer I, but after that dissapointment, and then playing this game I can't recommend it, What happened to tactics in battles, to creating lines, yes adding huge units and monsters and magic will make that stop working, but it feels to me that Im just throwing everything in the middle and hoping they win, there is good fights now and then that feel propper Total War battles, yes. But most don't, a easy AI completely destroys me in the campaign, my army garrisoned in a walled city gets erased by 1 enemy army with similar army comp, then said army comes to fight me and again odds are in their favor, I try to fight the battle but theres no use since I too get destroyed. I feel the best technique is a massive melee and hope for the best. Sorry, I don't think is a bad game, is quite fun, but is not Total War, and is not something at least I can learn after 80+ hrs. I have a lot of experience in games like: Medieval II, Rome 1, Rome 2, Barbarian Invasion, Attila, Shogun 2, Empire, Napoleon. And yet im completely lost, as if I was playing against hardest AI. There is nothing I can do, im reasearching, using agents, checking unit stats and trying to figure out a good army comp and strategy, getting annoyed trying to keep my corruption or untainted levels, even an enemy with 1 city gets like 4, 5 armies and there is no way for me to beat them, I have a fortified province capital with a 95% strenght full army and it gets erased by 1 enemy army, then the main army also gets erased in the next turn by the same enemy army. Im not complaining the game is hard, but if im struggling so bad even on the easiest setting, with stuff than in any other TW game would allow me to have an easy time exploring and learning the game, then the fun goes out, Im trying to immerse myself in the world of fantasy that has been delivered here and I can't because of basic gameplay stuff. I wish this was more like Rome 2. I can't describe more my feelings but I try to like this game, and I kinda do, but I can't recommend it for a Total War fan, and maybe for someone new the fantasy element attracts them, fine, good luck trying to figure out how this works. Cheers.

Thoroughly enjoying the game. The economy side of things can feel a bit shallow, more so than the other games depending on what race you choose to play. That said, I really don't think it takes away from the game and is fairly enjoyable in its own right.
 For a game series called Total War it should come as no surprise that the battles are the main highlight of the game. All the races feel unique and play pretty well given the long series of updates. Everything feels pretty solid on a balance front in my opinion but given the nature of the game having a wide variety of races with their own specific niche, there are some matchups that just feel pretty one-sided: i.e. Wood Elves vs. Dwarfs.
There can be a bit of a barrier of entry given the amount of content and dlc on offer, but it doesn't feel like a Paradox game where you are almost punished if you don't have the dlc, the game still plays perfectly fine all on its own. Also in my experience I found this game, and the Total War: Warhammer series as a whole, to be the easiest of the Total War games to just pick up and play without any real experience.

Overall I would give it a 9/10, with the only issue being some minor technical bugs and balance issues.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game as a gift from his aunt for his birthday last month, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my faction and lord and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is my first TW game I have ever played. I was cautious about buying it because it's price is $60 even though it came out in 2017 according to steam. I feared I was dealing with a greedy company that cares only for the profit rather than the quality of their game. In this regard I was half-right.

+ The game it self is fun. I enjoyed the vortex campaign and it definitely has replayability. My first completion of the campaign was as nagarythe which is supposedly one of the harder high elf factions to play because of its starting location. But I like ninja/assassin style classes so I went with that. The ambush mechanic is soooo fun! 

+ There is a bit of a learning in the form that you have to learn what each unit type does. Most of the units have counters, so you should take the time to learn what counters what and what makes for a good team composition. You don't want to be filling your team with just pure 20 units of shock cavalry like i did in my first playthrough, thinking you are gonna dominate in an epic showdown like Rohan did at Gondor in LoTR. You will get obliterated. I like the balance of knowledge you need to obtain in this game. Learning how to play wasn't too much of a head ache. I had to watch a few youtube videos explaining the units and good strategies but other than that I was able to learn everything I needed to know to win my first campaign(on easy lmao).

+ The music in this game is great. The tracks in-battle makes the battles feel really epic. Good job to the composer(s)!

+ I was worried about the city-building aspect of the game. I am use to city-builder games like civ6 and Humankind. In these games the emphasis is less on the battles and more on the cities up bringing. So I was worried the lack of city interaction would reduce my overall enjoyment of the game. But it didn't. You can raze cities to the ground and build ruins into cities and you can also customize them to have certain districts based on your needs. But it wasn't on the level of customization of the games I mentioned. However, this is fine because the focus point seemed to be the battles and the vortex anyways. Everything I was expecting to be able to do with my cities but could not do, was disappointing but acceptable because of the epic battles. Infact, I found the city management to be in the way at times. Many times I did not want to devote any time to my cities but instead just focus on the vortex and wiping out them filthy druchii and skaven neighboring me.

- For what the game offers, I really enjoyed it. But I can honestly say it is absolutely not worth $60. I would reason $40 at the max. After you complete the campaign, there is really not much to do after that except do the campaign again on a different faction. You can do multiplayer but given the nature of the game, I didn't really care to try the multiplayer. There is also the immortal empires, but you can't play it unless you own the previous TW:W game. So basically, the meat and potatoes of the game is infact the campaign.

- As I just mentioned, the game kind of lacks content. The campaign is fun, but not nearly enough for the price tag of $60. This can be countered with the Immortal Empires campaign, but you can't even play it unless you own the previous TW:W game. I find this to be absurdly unfair considering you have to pay the initial price of $60 to even play TW:W2. But to make it even more absurd, to play the Immortal Empires you have to basically pay another $60 to buy TW:W1. There are many who will argue "Just buy the bundle on discount". But if these people can not understand the error in that mentality, I'm not even going to bother explaining it. Simply put: I feel it is greedy and unreasonable to ask me to pay basically $120 plus tax, to play a simple campaign mode that is already present in your game but locked behind a paywall that is only unlocked after forcing the player to buy the previous installment of the franchise. And no, I'm not going to wait until the bundle goes on sale. Many people - myself included - have no idea about this before they buy. How many people fell into the trap of waiting for Warhammer 2 to go on sale to buy it alone. And after they buy, they realize the unfortunate truth that is: You shouldn't buy warhammer or warhammer 2 individually, even on sale. You should buy them both as a bundle on sale. And I guarantee they are doing warhammer 3 like this. Locked content only unlockable by buying warhammer 2. And just like me, people will have no idea to buy it all as a bundle and not individually.

How can they know to do this? Do your research? Did you? If so, good for you! But personally, I'm not going to scour the web searching about whether or not I should buy warhammer 1 to get my moneys worth out of warhammer 2. That's absurd.  Why would I waste my time doing research about something like this? That is unreasonable to ask of me. If people can't understand how much of a cash grab this is, that is there problem. This is clearly a scheme for the publishers to bait people into giving them double the money for a game that shouldn't even be worth its initial price tag. i would actually support it by buying Immortal Empires as a dlc. I wouldn't mind giving the company $10 or even $15 bucks to play Immortal Empires. But no, they want me to give them a whole $60 to play immortal Empires. F--- that...I don't want to buy warhammer 1 because I don't want to play warhammer 1. I wanted to play warhammer 2 that is why I bought warhammer 2. I am NOT going to buy a game that I have no desire to play, just to be able to FULLY play the game I DID want to play. That is complete bs...


- The campaign itself was lengthy. But I found a lot of the time required to complete the campaign was forced from me by the game. There is a term for this, I believe it is Artificial Game Lengthening(?). Your mission is to basically gain control of the vortexs power. You achieve this by gathering these magic fragment things to perform rituals. This is the first example of the game forcing you to put "extra" time into it. Basically, you can't do those rituals until after you acquire enough of those magic fragment things. You acquire them passively every new turn. You can speed up the generation by capturing settlements that have them in abundance. But no matter what you do, you basically have to sit there and wait turn after turn until you have enough required to do the ritual. After you acquire enough of those magic fragment things and begin the ritual, you now have to wait for the ritual to complete. This is the second example of the game forcing play time out of you. Each of the rituals require a rediculus amount of turns before they complete. And you basically just have to sit there and wait turn after turn until they do. After that, you rinse and repeat the process: Wait until you gain enough fragments > wait until ritual is done > repeat. I truly hate mechanics like this. This artifical game lengthening crap always leaves a bad taste in my mouth. 

---Final thoughts---

Overall I enjoyed my experiences in the game. The campaign was really fun and it made me actually care about warhammer lore. I don't know much about it but after playing the vortex campaign, I found myself watching lore videos on youtube. It is all quite interesting to me. So yes, the game is good. But imo no, its not worth $60. If you are one of the unlucky ones like me(you took the logical approach of choosing which warhammer game you want to play, waited for it to go on sale before you buy and then finally bought it), then I am deeply sorry for you. Sometimes its difficult to avoid cash grabs that are oh-so-subtle, like this. I recommend the game, but ONLY when its ON SALE and ONLY as a BUNDLE.

And to all of those who have no yet fallen into this trap but may in the future: 

DO NOT BUY ANY OF THE WARHAMMER GAMES INDIVIDUALLY EVEN ON SALE! WAIT FOR A BUNDLE SALE OF AT LEAST 75% OFF!

By far my first introduction to Total War games, or to grand strategy games as a whole. I don't know how many countless of hours I've spent trying to complete one campaign because oh my god one campaign takes FOREVER to complete, all because the objectives are sometimes quite absurd (in mortal empires at least).

But even with the long ass campaigns, there's just something really appealing to the game that makes me replay the game over and over, and that is the HUGE roster of factions you can play as. With different legendary lords that has specific play style, you can legit make an army that will greatly benefit you on how your Legendary Lord plays. I was also a big fan of Warhammer 40k, so apart from the DoW series, this is the closest I can get to a grand strategy version of Warhammer universe(on fantasy at least).

All in all, if I have to rate the game base on my opinion:

Story wise: 8/10 - If you like Warhammer fantasy novels, then you'll feel right at home here.(for Vortex campaign story at least. cuz Mortal empires is just sandbox, so no story there)

Gameplay wise: 7/10 - Vortex campaign is complete doo doo shit because of the campaign mechanics that force you to have a race with other factions that becomes absurdly difficult especially in harder difficulties, But thank god for Mortal empires saving this game. I'm gonna give it a solid 7/10(could've been lower if it wasn't for Mortal Empires saving it though)

Map design(for mortal empires): 8/10 - I'm glad CA really followed the designated faction's true map locations base on the faction's lore and all, but holy hell the map design and positioning is just awesome.

Price tag: 2/10 - I'll be real blunt here, nobody buys this game for Vortex campaign, most people play this for the multiplayer and the oh so good Mortal Empires. And with it's price being 60 bucks, you'll need another 60 bucks to buy the original Total War Warhammer 1 just to unlock Mortal Empires and the other races to be playable in multiplayer and all. So if you're in a tight money problem, I would NOT recommend you get this game unless you're 100% sure you're okay with spending large on this game. Because apart from needing the first Warhammer game, they still have DLCs to unlock certain factions and stuff. So all in all its quite pricey. And with Warhammer 3 Immortal Empires just released, the price of this game should drop if I have to be honest.

Replayablility: Very High -  All thanks to the HUGE roster of factions/races with lots of different Legendary lords with certain play styles, you get very high replay value on this game, even though one campaign can  take you HOURS just to complete it.

All in all a really good game; especially for a Warhammer fan like me.

I love Total War: Warhammer II. I know that's a weird way to initiate a negative review but I will clarify my position. I think that Total War is a fantastic series and that Warhammer II is the best of it [EDIT: With Immortal Empires in Warhammer III, I now believe WHII has been usurped]. As my hours would suggest I have spent quite a bit of time on the game and will likely spend just as much (if not more) on the third game once Immortal Empires drops. With that said, I can not recommend this game for its price-tag. If it was a single 60 dollar purchase I would still question its price-tag given the third game has released, however 60 dollars is not what you will be spending to enjoy this title. Very few players play this game solely for the Vortex campaign and factions, most play this game for the multiplayer battles and, more importantly, the Immortal Empires campaign. You do not get the further with this purchase. If you plan on buying this game on Steam and also wish to play Immortal Empires, you must pay an ADDITIONAL 60 dollars for the original Total War: Warhammer game, bringing the price-tag up to 120 dollars. But even if you spend THAT amount, there is still a large amount of money a player can expect to spend to access all of the content within this title. 

I can not wholeheartedly recommend this game to any new players as the expense-to-access cost is ludicrous. I will continue to play these titles because of the amazing content the developers put out, but it is the company's horrendous business model that earns my downvote.

Despite the resounding success of TWW, their innovation in bringing tabletop games to the animated stage, and their willingness to listen to criticism I have to give this game a thumbs down.  I've really wanted to enjoy this game!  I really did!  But the egregious R-P-S syndrom, cheating AI, and little room for experimentation, with fresh eyes this game doesn't really have much fun factor once you can see past the eye-popping visuals and well constructed GUI.
Against a CAI opponent, there seems to be one thing that is hammered into your play, run after run.  Stay alive long enough to snowball and then win.  That includes the Mortal Empires campaign.  This is easier to do depending on the faction leader's start condition.  Starting areas that are wide open and easy to navigate have an advantage over areas that have 3 or less paths to take.  Seafaring empires take the cake on this one, no surprise.
Starting conditions are also dictated by the other empires you START OUT at war with.  The Empire has one of the strongest starts but also one of the weakest in this regard.  
If you can get past the initial hurdle, that's just the start.  If the game decides to kill you, it just will.  If you choose an aggressive faction, the AI will try to slow you down by fighting you en masse, usually effectively.  If you have a defensive faction, the AI will try to bore you to death by micromanagement.  If you try to blend the two styles, you might have more fun, but it can vary from game to game.
For whatever excuse I might come up with, I didn't have much fun playing TWW2.  From hyper-aggressive AI, to constant micro-management headaches, the game got stale for me.  It won't be like that for everyone, and I already know I'm in the minority here.  But I really do like TW games.  TWR2 is my most played game in my library to this day!  But I just didn't have fun with this title....

A deviation from the more historical Total War games, this take on the franchise will appeal to those who enjoy the fantasy aesthetic or are familiar with Warhammer lore. Its greatest deviation from other Total War games comes in the inherent asymmetric experience found in utilizing different factions. I enjoyed this because many other Total War games quickly became stale after a few campaigns, as most factions are so structurally similar.  The asymmetric gameplay may not appeal to everyone, as there are some drawbacks with balancing issues that can always emerge, especially in the PVP meta. However, if you are looking to play immortal empires or other campaign modes, this makes every playthrough with a new faction feel like a unique experience, with each faction possessing different game mechanics, strengths, weaknesses, and aesthetic.

My favourite Total war. And I mean it. I always felt that this franchise needed to cross the border and go Fantasy. They did it with TWW1/2 and the result is perfect.

It brings Total war to a whole new level of strategy and replayability. Add to that the huge amount of mods and you have the biggest opus of the TW series. Some mods add more content than official DLCs...

Now after saying this, keep in mind that if you just buy the base game itself for 60‚Ç¨, you will have to spend 223‚Ç¨ more to unlock the game fully (you need all TWW2 DLCs + TWW1 Base Game + All TWW1 DLCs). Yes a few DLCs will add some cool content like new gameplay mechanics. But their main purpose is just to make playeable the factions and races that were already present in the base game !!!!!!!!! 

So take it all if you're rich and don't care or can get it on sale, stay far away else !

But like they handle the DLC makes me angry. So far i didnt had problems with DLCs. If they release a Peck.. i mean Dwarf DLC i just didnt buy it because i never play Pecks. 

But right now i played the Lizardman Campaign and seen something.. im not sure.. is it funny, brazen, idiotic or sad? 
Lizardman have a building you can build for 3700 gold that does nothing. Really nothing.. its just there. no positive or negative effect. If you dont have a DLC for it. 

Its ok that DLC has content you dont get if you dont buy the DLC.. but insert a Building that doesnt do anything without the DLC? Is it an advertising poster? Or just bad Programing? 
The building should be part of the DLC like the units of that building. It has nothing to do in the main Game. I really feel fooled about it. 

Another Point i dislike is that they make DLCs in doublepacks. They make 2 Races in 1 DLC. So if you like Skaven but dont like Lizard (as an examble) you have to buy if and get an Helf DLC you want and an half DLC you didnt want. 50% money waste in my eyes. 

Well all in all the Game is still good and worth playing. You can see by the Time i played it.

My favorite game of all times is Warhammer: Dark Omen, a 24 year old precursor to the series as well as the proto-game for the genre as a whole. But somehow the studio behind this new iteration makes us suffer again from the same problems that Shogun always had, just on a 10x scale. It's boring, repetitive, bloated and pointless. Everything that was good about Dark Omen is gone here. 

Storyline that makes no sense and was added as an afterthought. A ton of stuff that doesn't change your core mechanic but adds more work you need to do. Crazy grind to get to new armies (unlike in DO where you simply gain new troops as you go - and btw you always had just one troop of each type and it really made it feel unique and also personal). Completely visually unreadable units. It feels like it simply was made with no love. Basically both mechanics - battling and city development are just tiresome, repetitive and not fun.

Maybe this is all done this bloated way so you can sell games for $60. But if you'd just create a super slick polished one with much less bloat and clearer progression and narration, even if you could sell it for $30, you'd still make more players happy and make more money?

To me this is similar to new Baldur's Gate, having the same problems and just being totally overloaded comparing to the old game. Bloated, no fun, overcomplicated, uninteresting story. Why is it hard to simply do what was done before, but with modern tools?

Do yourself a favor. Find Warhammer: Dark Omen (it may be hard to make it run on your PC) and give it a try.

For everybody involved. Study Dark Omen and stop bloating your games!

There is a near constant problem in Total War Warhammer 2 where units frequently forget - if not outright ignore orders. This can be pretty much game breaking at times and makes battles that require any micro at all (i.e. cavalry charges, skirmishing) frustrating at best, rage inducing at worst.

Why this issue hasn't been fixed yet, I don't know. It's a very common complaint and only half assed solutions have been offered in the form of disabling a few default options to limited effect.

In addition, units lose their shape and cohesion very quickly, and cannot pull back to reform due to them "gluing" to the enemy, and this is compounded by the previous point. There is little tactics in play here; It is just a moshpit with hundreds of units.

Keep these things in mind if you think about purchasing this game.

When Creative Assembly decided to make a Total War game with a high fantasy setting, they could have used any number of intellectual properties or, very easily, slapped together their own universe with the usual tropes (dwarves, elves, orcs, etc.) and called it a day. Instead, not only did they go with one of the better established fantasy settings out there in Warhammer Fantasy, they have really done their utmost to be faithful to the extensive lore put out by Games Workshop. Every faction's style of play is unique, and (most of the time) the lords themselves have their own special strategies and identities. At it's best, WH II feels like an excellent turn-based strategy game AND a great story-driven role-playing game.

The large number of factions/lords means that the most popular and latest ones tend to be less challenging and more enjoyable, while others languish. Factions like Warriors of Chaos and Norsca, who were once the "new hotness" when they were DLC for the first game, are now so "old and busted" it's a common joke among the community. However, the "fun" factions all have multiple lords, so there is still a great deal of replay-ability. 

Another issue is the inherent macro scale of the game. For all its rich flavor, at its essence, this is a strategy game, one in which you probably end up simulating most battles. That means you spend the majority of your time staring at a large map of a fantasy world, which is cool, but you often wish the game would embrace its RPG elements and narrow the focus of the game. Instead, CA has done the exact opposite, blowing up the map from the Old World to include the Warhammer Fantasy equivalent of the New World. WH III, the newest installment, blows up the map even bigger to include the setting's Asia analogue, something the original material didn't ever really do. The end result is a staggering number of factions and lords whose concepts and mechanics inevitably are bland, broken, or just bad. There is a tendency in games that "more content is always good content," but the WH series proves that, even with an excellent AAA game, that's not always true.

Instead of locking themselves into producing three different games and spreading themselves thin on flavor (which we are seeing now with WH III and Chaos), it would have been better if CA had stopped with WH II and spent its time perfecting what works and improving what doesn't with the various factions. Some of the even more RPG-ish stuff in WH III, like the customization of Daemon Prince lords, could have been incorporated into a new and improved Warriors of Chaos faction--which, even if it isn't popular to play is, is meant to be THE end-game force in Old World games. Presently, I'm far more worried about undead or greenskin doomstacks than I am about the armies of the dude literally chosen by the Dark Gods to usher in the end of the world.

Still, the merits of this game far outweigh the flaws. If you enjoy turn-based strategy games period, get this game. If you enjoy turn-based strategy and high fantasy, I can't believe you haven't bought this game yet.

This game is quite possibly the best out of the Total Warhammer trilogy thus far. In order to take advantage of this game fully it's recommended you get the previous game and some of the DLC races, you plan on playing as. Some are free as you can see on the page while others are not so. This depends and you've likely already read a bit about the Warriors of Chaos DLC, they're expected to get a major facelift to come to the new immortal empires FLC in the next game. But one reason to purchase the game is the mods here. It's highly compatible with mod sets if you have the right loadout and a still thriving mod community that hasn't abandoned the game just yet. I have created a mod list of about 677 mods with Kaedrin's Mod Manager.

So yeah, the game is highly fun and compatible and well worth the chance to get the other DLC you're curious about checking out. Might I suggest checking out The Prophet and the Warlock, the Queen and the Crone, The Warden and the Paunch, the Silence and the Fury, and finally the Shadow and the Blade. Any of these are fantastic additions. Unfortunately to access the new units as well you have to get these dlc units. Also, if you got a thing for undead pirates and giant crabs that are undead too, check out the vampire coasts dlc.

This game is awesome. Buy it now.
If you are a fan of the sadly decommissioned Warhammer Fantasy and / or any of the older Total Wars, you should buy this thing immediately. Even without any of the DLCs, the fun is incessant and the possibilities endless.
Of course, the Mortal Empires campaign is the "real deal" - it expands the number of playable factions from 6 to 15 the map five times over. You need to own Warhammer I for that, but this is easily worth the investment.
Plus a veritable shipload of all possible mods - my guess is you could probably play this forever.
That said, some of the Lords / campaigns might feel underwhelming at first. If you are a member of Camp Volound and prefer the old school style of Total War battles (pre-Atilla), you will hate the battles, as they are considerably less tactical and more arcade-y compared to the older titles. If you are looking for that grimdark feel of tabletop Warhammer, you will be disappointed - it is watered down to the point of nonexistence. The color palette resembles My Little Pony more than Warhammer. If taken to the extreme (painting the map in glorious Reikland red, for example), the campaigns can get long, repetitive and sort of tedious, as you just curbstomp anything that comes your way without even trying and the hardest part is logistics (getting your doomstacks across the ultrahuge map).
Even so, this is a 9,5/10 for me. 
0,25 point down for the aforementioned cartoonization of a universe that could make you retch with grimdarkness in its original form - and this can be done right, too, looking at you, Mordheim.
0,25 down for sometimes falling prey to grind and repetition. 
Even though this monstrosity with its countless DLCs has cost me a fortune and a half by now, I do not regret a single penny.

I liked this game at first, but the more i play it, the more I don't like it for several reasons.

The higher the difficulty, the more the ai cheats. It doesn't get smarter, it doesn't get better in battle, it cheats. AND. I. HATE. THAT. While it is cheating, you are also taking penalties to things like leadership for your units, upkeep, diplomacy, etc.

For instance:

The higher the difficulty the more the upkeep costs.
You can control a whole province (2 - 4 settlements) and barely afford one army on hard with mostly garbage units, if you want to keep building up your settlements. Control two provinces and you can get some nice units in your army! GOOD LUCK DEFENDING THEM! The AI can control one SETTLEMENT and have 2 and a half armies along with the garrison (3 and a half total armies). Making it INCREDIBLY frustrating trying to finish off factions with your single army. Because if you manage to corner a faction into one settlement they will sit and turtle on their last settlement until you get lightning strike or ambush them.

The AI has more movement points than you can possibly spec into. Unless you are Vlad Von Carstein. The AI regularly ignores your army and sprints through your lands raiding and razing to their hearts content because guess what? YOU WONT BE ABLE TO CATCH THEM. Your jaw will drop at the amount the AI can move and do in a single turn. THERE IS NO OUTRUNNING THEM.

The AI WILL NOT attack you unless they have overwhelming numbers. When they catch you there is little you can do. Now the devs recognize this so they put a skill in the game called lightning strike, that is a must have and only works when you attack. It allows you to ignore the enemy reinforcements and attack one enemy army 1v1 (very realistic btw this happens a lot in war). Nevermind that after the battle your units will be diminished and their reinforcements will attack you next turn, destroying you anyway because they can afford ridiculous numbers. BUT LIGHTNING STRIKE!!! In a game called total WAR: WARhammer, the AI does everything it can to avoid actually fighting you with one army. You must trick it with ambush to fight.

Most cities on water have mandatory ports and only the major port cities offer the entire port building chain, so if you have a minor port city, the port takes up a building slot and you can't build it up all the way and its AWKARD, especially since you can't recruit anything with them! And there are a lot of cities on water.

There are no navies in the game with the exception of the dark elves who will completely control the sea. If you want to cross over water your army becomes a ship when you move it over water, despite there being a million port cities, you can't build any ships with them. So you can't blockade any ports or trade routs because water is only meant for traveling. There are ship battles now, but they happen on land ? lol.

There are no unit formations. No wedges, testudos, phalanxes, shield walls, or loose unit formations to take less artillary/arrow damage. The battles are: whoever controls the flanks with their boxes of units wins. AND. ITS. BORING. Boxes of units going against other boxes of units. And unit stats? They don't matter, what matters is their traits like anti infantry, anti large, armor piercing, etc. rock. paper. scissors.

Regardless of difficulty the AI does not have fog of war. They can see everything you are doing. Want to send a fleet across the ocean and surprise attack the elves? They'll be waiting for you. RUINS. THE. FUN. If you take one wrong step because you can't see the enemy armies while they can see yours, you will be surrounded and deleted.

Diplomacy = everyone hates your guts. The AI can confederate twice in the first 10 turns (absorb other factions of the same race that requires the player to have almost impossibly high diplomatic relations) meanwhile you will get laughed at asking for mutually beneficial trade deals by factions of your own race because of diplomatic penalties called aversion, and great power that you have for NO REASON. 

The best part about diplomacy is when a faction across the world declares war on you and sends all their armies your way. I've had factions completely ignore their own defense to zerg me, another faction would be attacking and absorbing them on one side while they were sending all their resources at me, despite the fact that i had done nothing to provoke them in the first place. DUMB.

The AI has zero problems with public order. They can be in a settlement with an inhospitable climate, with me raiding them and they still, will have no issue with public order. Meanwhile I have to use precious building slots on buildings that only maintain public order. expect to use 1 - 2 each province TO BREAK EVEN in public order. Anything that happens (enemy/neutral army trespassing/ enemy heroes trespassing/ corruption goes up because the beastmen are on your continent(?) expect a rebellion shortly. The only time i see rebellions for the ai are from vampiric, chaotic, and skaven corruption. As you can imagine the AI can spread like wildfire with confederations and no public order problems while you could not possibly dream of doing so ( i wouldn't want to do it that way, I want things to be equal).

Units now have health bars! I almost did not buy this game because of this alone. But there is an option to make them invisible so it looks like the old games.

Sieges. After turn 50 the game becomes a non stop siege fest that is tedious and boring because the AI only runs from your army and turtles in their settlements. Every siege battle feels exactly the same, copied and pasted but with different colors and themes. The city towers have unlimited range, insane firing rate and will single handedly destroy your army if you don't charge the city the second you press start battle. Why would my army set up under enemy tower range to begin with? And when attacking units rout in a siege they RUN INTO THE CITY instead of out. LOL. The AI can recruit units WHILE sieging you, you know that 12 stack rebellion sieging one of your walled settlements you're not worried about? It will magically turn into a 20 stack in two turns despite the fact that there is no indication that they are RECRUITING WHILE SIEGING in their unit status flag.

The best things about this game are the large units and heroes but they manage to mess up heroes too.

Legendary Lords (LLs) that don't have mounts will lose to the weakest LLs that do have mounts. EVEN if you spec into buffing the hell out of your LL. GRIMGOR IRONHIDE the biggest, baddest orc ever, can't kill a horse? really? He's bigger than the fucking thing. but he gets knocked around like a soccer ball, and all you can do is facepalm.

Auto Resolve is a laughing stock, seriously, google it. You can have high end armies lose to basic units because one unit of enemy peasant archers gets 300+ kills while another gets 200+ kills and so on. Then you fight the battle, because quicksave and those same archers will get 7 and 15 kills. it's a complete joke and forces you to fight easily winnable battles or else have random units in your armies wiped which gets tedious FAST.

Reinforcements seem to spawn in wherever they feel like, with no rhyme or reason, despite being strategically placed on the campaign map, don't ever expect to rely on them being consistent.

Multiplayer has also played a big role in ruining the fun of this game, anytime they release something fun to play with, all 5 people in the multiplayer community complain about it being op and they nerf it for the rest of us. This is meant to be a single player game and should be prioritized as such.

It's. Not. Fun. So I can't recommend this game. It costs WAY too much money to have so many things wrong with it.

Unless you were looking for something more historical, this is game is the definitive Total War masterpiece experience. Yes, it is expensive in extra DLC but that's what kept the game alive. Yes, if you played the original Warhammer, the power creep of the new races might be a bit extra and make the already super complex gameplay even more complicated. However, there is enough content for at least 2000 hours of gameplay. I played 4 factions through and through and I'm just at 500 hours. Do note, whowever, that you want the original warhammer I and its DLCs to play mortal empires. Eye of the vortex campaign is full of interesting, but tedious mechanics that take the fun out of conquest.
As of this review I'd call this the best Total War game. It is the result of decades of iterative design improvements of the total war style mechanics plus the rich variety of the warhammer universe.

This is a really nice game, very solid. I am an old fan of Total War games, like I got to play the first Shogun Total War back in 1999 - 2000 when it was released and been playing the Total War games until now. At first I was sceptic and a bit reserved, about the whole fantasy, gave it a try and enjoyed it.

I have to admit it took a while to get used to the new Total War mechanics introduced. I had to spend more than 100 hrs to get used to how important heroes and generals were, taking into consideration that you can use them both in and out of combat and that in combat are close to Godlike creatures, unlike the previous titles were your general would just die. I finally completed the game with Bretonia no less, and fell in love with the game.

Diplomacy is basic, still the fact that you can coordinate with the AI is something interesting, especially if the AI responds... Unfortunately enemy AI is way better in recruiting units than your ally counterparts. I found the AI on many occasions stacking units well tailored against me, so I had to keep diverse (preety tough with Bretonia but still...)

Unlike previous titles where you had to win the game in like 120 - 150 rounds, since Rome 2 there is no definite point in time to win the game. You get objectives, certain global or race events and you have all the time in the world to build and expand. Of course this is easier said than done, enemy AI throws at you stacks after stacks with very little regard to upkeep costs, so you need to play smart. Use your Hero to assasinate enemy army specialist heroes while at the same time use another agent to slow the enemy army down giving you more rounds available to weed out enemy heroes and bring the enemy army to it's knees. Or if the enemy army is suffering attrition in your territory, dont engage it, delay it, slow it down, let it suck up on that attrition damage for a few rounds while you continue building etc and when you feel ready attack the enemy weakened force with lower casualties on your part! Facing of a melee specialist in combat could cost you tens of units and even a hero, when dealing with him in the campaign map mode only costs money which are fairly easy to gather! Be smart!

There are so many races to play that use different set of tactics and their units are variantly different in strengths and weakness that there is a great deal of replayablity. For instance I finished the Mortal Empires campaign (which is the main campaign) and started the Eye of Nexus I think? A "side" campaign where you get to chose from certain races and each one has each own unique questline to complete. My first was completed with Bretonia, now I am trying Dwarves and the list goes on....

Graphics are good, and at some points you are gonna get your Visual Card and RAM stuffed up their neck thanks to the AoE effects of spells, Siege equipment of flying monsters breathing fire!

When I went into combat I had to think on a scale of two dimensions now, what do i have to deal with in the Ground and What do i do against air targets! Incredible change of dynamic!

I can't recommend enough this game, despite of it's pricing etc which I agree it feels utterly ridiculous to have to pay so much money just to have a race available to you... The campaigns are ok, new maps, new events, special campaign units, more lore, sure I can pay for that, but for a race already included in the games code simply to pay extra 10 - 20 euro in order to just be able to play as Wood Elves or Nordlings?/?? Come oooon... 

Wait for 50% + discount and buy it... Oh yes,... You need to buy the Warhammer I game first, buy the races you want from Warhammer I game and THEN buy Warhammer II which balances out and improoves almost every single race in the game.... Yes I know terrible pricing and milking... You buy the first game for it's races,. ignore entirely the title and go for the Warhammer II...

Enjoy.,..

Bad Rats 2: Electric Boogaloo.

I know that you dream of being a rat-man, Living in your neighbors walls, Eating their cheese and stealing their gold.
And now you can live out that dream, In the award winning follow up to the critically acclaimed Bad Rats.

A quick list of features

LIVE in your neighbors walls
Steal cheese, Steal children, and Steal green MAGIC crack rocks.

Bask in the glory of your rat empire, As you feed THEIR children to YOUR children.
FUEL Your RAT-child slave army with green MAGIC crack rocks, Watch as they grow in STRENGTH and SIZE.
 (The neighbors won't know what hit them)

When the time comes, BURST forth from your neighbors walls, Watch as they succumb to a TIDE OF CRACK FUELED RATS.

Purchase the clan skyre dlc to overpower your neighbors with crack powered Miniguns, Flamethowers, Anti material rifles, 
Lightning cannons, And explosive crack catapults.

If the neighbors somehow survive all that, Just GAS EM, Or take the nuclear option, AND LITERALLY NUKE THEM.

Loyalty is optional, Ethics are unnecessary, and Friendly fire is mandatory,
But victory, Victory is guaranteed. The only question is,

Will it take one thousand rats? Or will it take one million. Out-bred, Out-gunned, And out-smarted,
It's only a matter of time, Before the neighbors fall.
