In short - the game is great. Especially with the right overhaul mods, but I recommend playing through some in vanilla first. I'm not a fan of the base "Vortex" campaign but the combined Immortal Empires campaign map with the factions from both WH1 and WH2 is fantastic. The only real flaw in this game is that the AI occasionally can fail in specific scenarios - such as in siege battles - but it isn't that bad unless you actively try to exploit it. I prefer playing Head to Head multiplayer anyway with a friend of mine, where he can fight battles as the AI opponents, and that works around the issue. I'll be grabbing WH3 once they release the combined map for that game and it has had some time to get polished, as all of the Total War games in recent years have been quite unpolished (as well as lacking in good mods) close to release.

Original Review: 

Where to start...

As of this time, I have played around 26 hours of Total War: Warhammer II. In 26 hours I have played all factions within the game at least a decent amount, and have gotten familiar enough with the game mechanics to feel confident in writing this review. 

For those of you who are new to the Total War series of games, Total War: Warhammer II is a game based around two things. The first thing it is based around is a turn-based strategy element, where you build armies, conquer cities, maintain an economy, and fight wars with other factions on a world map. The second thing it is based around are real-time battles, and it is in these battles where the love that many people have for the game truly begins to shine.

You control large numbers of units in formations, and use these units in order to fight your enemies. You have infantry of all sorts to choose from, from spearmen to swordsmen to monstrous beasts which rampage among the enemy lines. You have archers, slingers, javelin-wielding maniacs, and more to wear your enemy down from afar. You have giant solar-beam cannons strapped to the back of dinosaurs, warp-lightning cannons, catapults, ballista, and other things which you can use to wear down your foes from extreme distances. You have cavalry, monsters, flying beasts, as well as lords and heroes who can level up through experience and influence battles through direct combat might or through powerful magic and special abilities.

In Total War: Warhammer II, there are four main races to play as as of this writing. Other factions exist in the game (ported from the first game) as minor factions which you can wage war with, but they are not playable as of right now.

You can play as either the sadistic dark elves, the haughty high elves, the fanatical lizardmen, or the scheming skaven (ratmen, essentially).

Each has its own unique roster of units and specific racial mechanics (which is reflected in gameplay both in the campaign map and in battles). Each faction also has two unique starting positions on the campaign map, which correspond to a unique faction leader (for a total of 8 starting positions). Depending on which faction you begin as, and the faction leader which you choose, your playstyle will be encouraged to be one way or the other in the campaign by the unique skills and bonuses your lord provides, as well as their geographical starting location.

Throughout the campaign, you fight battles with the other main factions in a battle to achieve the campaign objectives. In Warhammer II, you are expected to win through the Vortex campaign, which sees your faction gaining control over the great vortex - its purpose to siphon away the winds of magic that draw the forces of chaos to the world.

This requires you to perform rituals after obtaining enough of a certain in-game currency produced in certain cities on the map, or by doing quests you may occasionally be assigned. While a ritual is being performed, the main enemy factions may send intervention armies to attempt to stop you by razing the small handful of cities in which the ritual is being done. Armies of chaos will appear on the map to stop you as well, destroying everything in their path on the way to their objectives.

Here is where the troubles begin. 

The game does not provide you with the economic means to maintain many armies in comparison to the territory that you can hold, so performing a ritual requires you to basically spend the 10 turns of the ritual camped and holding on for dear life in your important cities. You can spend money (as well as the AI) to send intervention armies towards enemy rituals, their quality dependant on the money you spend, but these armies are controlled by the game AI rather than by yourself, and appear in the middle of the enemy territory. 

Given the extreme size of the map, all four main factions may never end up fighting eachother during a typical game until near the very end, as well. Two of the major land-masses are inaccessible to the other two (which are connected) without traveling by sea, yet if you are caught on the sea by an enemy army, you can only rely on the game's often imbalanced auto-resolve to hope that your army is not immediately destroyed. 

The Vortex campaign is highly flawed for many reasons, primarily being the fact that the map is too large, the seas too vast, and the rituals too short for you to meaningfully fight against them without using the previously mentioned intervention AI armies. Additionally, you can win the campaign without even performing the rituals necessary by simply winning against the AI in a laughably easy final battle, knocking whoever performed that final ritual out of the race for good.

All of these concerns pale in comparison however to just how fun the core gameplay is. 

Fighting battles as any of the four factions in the game is a blast, and not long from now, those who own the first game will gain access to a combined campaign map (including the land masses and factions from both games), which will not include the broken Vortex campaign mechanics. The sheer fun of the game, and the knowledge that many problems I have can be fixed through mods and upcoming developer work, make me able to recommend this game quite readily.

However, know what you are getting yourself into. Watch some gameplay videos if you are unsure that you will enjoy the core gameplay; Youtube is filled with them. For all of my concerns about the Vortex campaign and general game pacing, these are minor concerns compared to just how fun it is to see your giant dinosaurs rampaging amount enemy soldiers, or seeing your Skaven hordes surround and massacre the enemy while magic flies across the battlefield, as all the while heroes and lords battle it out in the crossfire.

If you enjoy real time strategy games, this is probably the most fun that Total War has ever been. If you enjoy turn based strategy games, it can be fun, but the turn-based aspect of the game is not the main appeal of the game. As of right now as well, the workshop is not available for this game - so until it is, many mods that could improve the gameplay experience and allow you to tailor it are not ready.

I won't lie to you and promise you that this is the best game ever made, or that it is devoid of flaws, but there simply is no other game out there quite like Total War: Warhammer (I or II). It can definitely be worth the money, and then some, if the core gameplay is to your liking. I've enjoyed my time in Warhammer I and Warhammer II more than I have in any other Total War game to date, and for all of the problems the games may have, they are definitely worth giving a shot!

It is fascinating game. Started with Total War series and playing with easy level, but still a lot do learn. You need to be in the good level in all categories to succeed (several lords, heroes, finances, updates in cities, communication with other parties, vortex spell making)
Can not deal with only 1 main lord and make him the best in the map. Yes you can try, but it will not bring victory. You need balanced teams and give battles (experience) to all of them. Need to be ready for raiding parties and chaos and other extra forces what will attack you in regular basis. This means you can not leave some flanks without defense. Or if you do you need to have forces able to defend the cities. Big work on developing city to level 4 or 5 can be destroyed in 1 move. These are the first impressions and in my opinion this game has huge depth and challenges what I like to overcome. Definitely recommend to try it out at least.

This game can be really fun but it has issues that kind of ruin it. A big problem for me is the AI. For example, I was playing on very hard as Eataine. It was really fun until I got control of the gates. Then for the rest of the game, the enemy AI just suicides their armies into my gates, and making the game far too easy.  I'm fighting against multiple factions which are stronger than me, but it doesn't matter because they just can't get enough of my gates. They walk past my cities which they could easily take but they just love those gates so much. I have this exact same problem with the empire forts. The AI will repeatedly attack the fort. Auto resolve says I will lose, but when manually fighting the fights are really easy. So I have to manually defend my forts/gates basically every second turn. This completely ruins the fun. The game would actually be better if forts/gates were just completely removed, that would be better than the current state.

It's a very fun large scale strategy/civ style game with a ton of faction variety, lots of expansions and a very addictive ONE MORE TURN feel to it. If you like epic fantasy battles and a lot of weird factions and unit variety you will like this.

[b]The Good[/b]

+ Huge scale in terms of the overworld map, number of factions and number of units possible in battles.
+ Tons of personality and variety in each faction and sub-faction. Many have their own specific UI features for research, units or buildings specific to them. Most of them still share the vortex campaign, but the differences are deep enough to make each play through feel different.
+ Even though the scale is huge the graphics when zoomed in during a battle look really good. Giant fireballs raining down on hundreds of units looks awesome.
+ Lots of cool extra factions to add in as DLC (many of which are Free DLC) so you should be able to find one you like. (Ikit Claw from Prophet & The Warlock is tons of fun!) Sadly, there's no way to try them out first before you buy, but you can face off against them in singleplayer campaigns to get an idea of what they do.

[b]The Bad[/b]

- While there is a help wiki built into the game it doesn't do a great job of explaining all the battle movement controls so I had to go on Youtube to figure them out.
- Installing the free DLC is really strange. You have to manually go and add each one (despite those characters/factions already showing up as opponents in the game), download from Steam while the game is running and then restart the game for them to activate. A few random ones also require you sign up for a Total War account, which is annoying but you can just skip those. I don't get why they don't just let you install the Free DLC from Steam or patch it into the base game like other games do for Free DLC. The paid for DLC works normally with it being added directly from Steam.
- While the customized UIs for each faction are really good in general, there are some awkward UI issues where things don't do what they say they do. For example, there's a "Rite of Summoning" to "summon" a Slann as Lizardmen, but when you click it nothing appears to happen despite saying the ritual is done. What it actually does it add that Slann to the Lords list where you can recruit them like any other Lord but the UI doesn't say anything about that and makes it sound like they should just appear. There's a couple things like that randomly throughout the game that are annoying when you run into them.
If you like turn based strategy with real time combat this is a great choice.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Total War WARHAMMER ll is a great game. At least in my opinion. It has the most unit variety and the best battles in the Total War franchise, and it's barely a competition. However, despite the absolutely AMAZING battles, the campaign leaves a lot to be desired when compared to games like Rome or Medieval 2. Honestly, the campaign is my biggest gripe with the game. It's not bad, but CA has already shown they are capable of making it much better. Again, in my opinion. And the last thing to say, the DLC policy. I know a lot of people complain about it, but I find it fine since every DLC is worth the money, though if you look at the later DLCs it is clear that CA has listened to the community and greatly improved it. Look at the Warden and the Paunch compared to the Queen and the Crone, Grim and Grom are objectively better. They're both great, but the latter is better. Oh and by the way, NEVER ignore the mod workshop, it's an absolute godsend. All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

tl;dr : Amazing game for amazing people with amazing brain

at first i thought total war : warhammer is like the other warhammer series where the gameplay is like starcraft or warcraft campaign, i didn't expect that it is a turnbased strategy game like this ( i'm a big fan of strategy game since age of empires 1 )

i'm only playing as a Dark elf malekith so far but i've been really addicted into the game. The environments, unique heroes, unique subordinates, unique abilities, different main base with their special building to build, TONS of skills and items, and lots more. Everything in the game is just a perfection in my eyes and brain, it might be a little bit exaggerated but you will find out when you try and choose your first faction and character to play.

do i need to mention FREE DLC? yes you read it correctly, FREE DLC!!! they have been updating their game since release with new characters to play from each faction and lots of them is actually free so u can just download and play, some more interesting characters need to be purchased to be played. 

so far i haven't seen anything that makes me dislike this game other than the pacing, sometimes the enemy progressing super fast than you expected and you have to fight their advanced unit with your basic unit, but hey I WON!! XD the true art of the TWW is how you can turnaround the battle with your unique heroes, subordinates, skills, units, formattion, and terrain. literally need your brain to maximised the output of your units so you can win every battle which is very appealing for me.

there is no try for this game, I WARNED YOU! once you try this game, 1 hour won't be enough to see wether you like it or not, the moment you realised it is already passed 1 hour and you won't be able to refund the game... but hey! who needs to refund a masterpiece game? 

9/10 overall and i'm thinking to finish all the free content to tryout TTW3

I wanted a Warhammer game like this. I wanted a Total War game like this. Warhammer should have been CA's magnum opus. Instead they gutted so many integral, core mechanics from previous titles and fail to meet the bar that was set by themselves over a decade ago. This game is a straight downgrade compared to what we had in 2011 and before. They have failed to meet their own standard of quality time and time again.

This is an expansion pack. not a full game. It is not worth $60, nor is Warhammer 3. No naval. How dare you add entire factions whose society is based around the fact they live near the ocean and not have naval.The dumbing down and oversimplification of mechanics, assuming those mechanics are even still present. Magic and heroes being the single deciding factors for victory, making armies inconsequential. The cartoonish nature of the whole thing, making it more and more arcade-like to where it more resembles a MOBA. Over monetization, unsatisfying gameplay. Nothing more than a glorified reskin of Warcraft III.

After having sunk many hours into this game, I gotta say that this is probably one of the best entries in the series in terms of sheer variety and scope. If you're looking for a major time-sink with a lot of different factions and armies to command, then this is probably your kind of game. It's pretty good for longtime fans and new players alike. The only complaint that I do have is that it can be a bit too bloated, especially when it comes to attempting side objectives or stuff like hunting for Legendary Gear. It isn't too horrible, but having to travel all the way around the map to an area I won't go to or don't want to go to can get a little annoying. This is more noticeable on the B-Tier holdovers from the first game. Looking at you Volkmar.

Review for fellow Total War newbies and those considering the franchise.

But first, should you buy Warhammer 2?

Get it on discount alongside Warhammer 1. The price of both on discount cost $34.81 (at time of writing). Each game costs $59 so you'll still save $24.19. If you bought them at full price, that's $118 - not affing worth it. 

- Now for the long review.

I played more Paradox Interactive games than Creative Assembly's in my life. Europa Universalis, Crusader Kings, HOI and Stellaris being the main ones I've tried in different points of my life. They're all very complex. Total War titles can be just as complex, but the most important thing is them being historically-rich and accurate. And thus, TW Warhammer is the elephant in the room: Creative Assembly took a risk by removing history in favour of fantasy.

However, it's unfair to dismiss TW Warhammer for it since it is still a Total War game. Large-scale battles and turn-based grand strategy. The environment is staggering, with refined details. The developers really put the work into designing virtually character model, equipment, structures and vegetation. It makes you realise Total War has come a very long way.  

For seasoned TW players - I'm not one of them - I hear criticism about the grand campaigns being toned down in favour of warfare. Though I agree, I feel that this is forgivable given the nature of the Warhammer franchise, wherein the war machine is king, and I reckon this was intentional. After all, Warhammer fans from the tabletop games or video games like Dawn of War 1 & 2 would definitely prefer Warhammer retaining that flair of merciless violence and unremitting brutality. Think about Blood Bowl and how it turned peaceful American football into a gory affair. It's just Warhammer. Hence, the dagger is more preferred than the tongue - a notable keepsake for the Dark Elves perhaps. 

When I bought Warhammer, I expected grand strategy as complex as Rome II, but I was pleasantly surprised it wasn't. Now, I could just focus on harassing my neighbours and befriending dinosaurs, instead of thinking hard about my decisions like in Paradox's games. Sp, Total War Warhammer felt like a breath of fresh air for me. Furthermore, being Total War, I now commanded large armies again; kinda feels like Dawn of War 1. 

Criticisms:
You'd think I'm very happy with this product. Not entirely. 
Total War Warhammer is a trilogy and it is all interconnected. However, it is not like Call of Duty Modern Warfare in which you continue the stories of recurring characters. Rather, this has to do with the campaigns and the playable factions. Upon purchase of Warhammer 2, I am told to claim my FREE Mortal Empires DLC. So I went ahead to click it install to no avail. Turns out, you need to own TW Warhammer 1 first in order to unlock Mortal Empires. I never played Warhammer 1 but from what I've heard, Mortal Empires just allows you to play the Warhammer 1 factions in a brand new campaign and see them with better graphics. Seriously? FREE DLC if you've bought and owned the first game. So it isn't free. 

How about those who bought Warhammer 2 from the store? The ones who haven't discovered Steam, let alone create an account? Perhaps Creative Assembly addressed this before, and told players about this, but still it's a business practice that disrespects the customer base. I hope CA doesn't do this again.

_ 

For those new to the Warhammer franchise, TW Warhammer takes place in the Age of Sigmar (AOS). It is high fantasy as opposed to the gothic, grimdark scifi fantasy setting of Warhammer 40k. You will not recruit and command Space Marines, and melee units dominate the battlefield. There are Orks, Chaos, Elves and Monkeigh around but they'll be loosely connected to the Warhammer 40k universe. There is of course theories about that claim AOS occurs after the events of Warhammer 40k or were concurrently happening alongside Warhammer 40k. You can come up with your own theories, but the idea of magical factions murdering one another for the planet before the uninvited arrival of the Imperium and its Space Marines sends chills down my spine.

I like the game.  I liked the first one as well. But the auto-resolve is broken af and a quick google search will show that I'm not even close to the only person who realizes this.  Apparently it has been broken since one of their long previous games.  I literally have to have twice what the enemy has to win an auto-resolve.  This isn't a problem when its two armies on one but when the enemy stomps around the battle field with 5 armies together or like 10 when chaos shows up then you are basically screwed.  4 armies vs 3?  Ha yea right.  3 armies vs 2?  Nope. Not even close.  4 armies vs 2?  Gee thats a close fight.  And yes my units are ranked up.  I kinda understand why they did it. They did it so that people would manual fight the battles, but if I did that it would take me a year to finish the game with just one faction.   So yea, its a fun game but I'm done with it.  The broken auto-resolve is what killed it for me and I don't plan on getting the third installment.  Apparently it isn't just the auto resolve thats broken in that game.  From the steam reviews it looks like its the whole game.

Of the Total War series, Warhammer 2 is my favorite so far. The different races offer the opportunity to adapt your play style and make the game feel all fresh when you switch it up.

Since the formula for the Total War games is already known and tested in all the previous releases, no game breaking bugs have occurred when playing my 1400+ hours, and I'm still not fed up with the game. 

The TTW games and DLC are kind of pricey, but compared with the time played I find it justified. They also often come back with discounted prices during steam sales.

It's nice to see the lore and familiar characters brought to life, any warhammer or Games Workshop fanboy should own this title :)

Edit: Warhammer 3 is out now, and offers alot of potential.... but it's not there yet. Needs more work and DLC. This means that WH 2 is still my favorite so far.

I give a thumbs up, with a big caveat.

The Good:
Total War: WARHAMMER II is exactly what you would expect if Warhammer fantasy and Total War had a baby together. If you like either one, you'll probably like this. The combination is entirely natural and works together beautifully. Pausable real-time combat is perfect for a table-top tactical combat game, and the grand strategy map gives you all the nuance of the game's lore and complexity.

The Bad:
Product registration and DLC download is so poorly handled that both failed repeatedly. Registration failed on Chrome, Edge, and Firefox due to the registration button doing nothing. DLC in-game brings you to a website, which brings you to Steam, which brings you in-game. At no point does the download/get DLC now button actually download the DLC. Following advice online to fix this buggered Steam so badly that it crashed. I've never seen Steam crash before. Eventually everything got reinstalled, and the game mostly works. I still can't access all of the DLC that I bought though.

Once the game is working, there is another impediment to playing: the tutorial. The tutorial is so aggressively bad that it prevented me from learning how to play the game. DO NOT PLAY THE TUTORIAL! Just play a campaign on easy until you learn the controls, then start a real game. The game actually has a reasonably intuitive user interface.

If you just want to know what the game is like, it's fantastic. The battles are a sight to behold. You can't really pay very close attention to what's happening with individual troops while you're actually fighting a battle, but when you watch the replay you can zoom in and see all the bloody carnage in full glory (Note that there is 0 actual bloody carnage unless you purchase the DLC that adds blood and gore to the game, which rubs me the wrong way, but the game is far less playable without it). It's so much fun to see your spells obliterate whole units or to watch a huge monster tear into formations and toss everyone around in a shower of blood and viscera. 

The game does a terrible job of teaching you how to play. You'll have to figure out how everything works through trial and error. I have a pretty decent handle on how the game works after 35 hours, but there are still mechanics I don't understand and plenty I have to learn about how to fight battles. It's very overwhelming at first and you might feel like giving up, but if you stick with it the game will reward you with an experience you can't really get anywhere else. 

That said, if you want the full Total War Warhammer experience, you're going to have to buy all 3 $60 games. That's a minimum $180 price of entry, which doesn't include any of the DLC factions of course. In my professional opinion, you're going to want to wait until there's a sale to buy these games. I don't have Warhammer III yet, but I bought Warhammer I and Warhammer 2 plus two major DLC packs for around $55 on sale, which is pretty good value. 

If you're looking to buy this game, you should buy Warhammer I first, because Warhammer 2 is essentially more of an expansion pack for Warhammer I than it is a standalone game. You'll notice the huge amount of DLC available for these games, but don't worry- you don't need any of it (apart from the blood and gore DLC, you'll want that, it's about $3) to play the game, they're just new factions you can buy if you want to.

Not a terrible thing, it's just that after 1600 hours of playing, it can get a bit tiresome. And then...you have that itch! You must come back and punish your enemies once more!

So, far, Warhammer III cannot compete with this classic.

The battles are fun but the overall strategy is so shit/braindead.

The only way to get ahead in harder difficulties is to cheese since the AI is so bad they need free resources/armies coming out of their ass to have a chance to compete with the player.

The AI can always see where the players armies and weak settlements are and they have the ability of knowing exactly how far your'e armies can move while also having the advantage of having more movement points than the player. 
This pretty much ruins all the strategic aspects of the campaign and leaves the player with just the decisions of what building to build in their settlement and the choice of expansion.

Meanwhile endless legend with the community patch and age of wonders has way better campaign AI.
The technology is there but SEGA doesn't seem to want to put in the money and time to make it happen.
All I am saying is that this game could have been so much more if it weren't for one of the worst grand strategy AI to date.

In conclusion get this game for the tactical combat, not the empire building you get from 4x games.

I've played the Total War series since Medieval II. Total War: Rome II was the last one I enjoyed thoroughly. Three Kingdoms caused me to raise an eyebrow, but I still enjoyed it quite a bit. I realized that they were falling into the same trap that most games do these days - paywalls. This is the most dumbed down version of Total War that I've seen and it's a shame. I was really looking forward to this one. Fortunately, I waited until it was on sale for $20. I feel that that's a fair price for this. You have 4 factions and 2 faction leaders to choose from each. Otherwise, you'll be paying for any other beneficial leaders.

I remember when you'd have 20, 30+ faction options to choose from - all with unique pros and cons - rich in lore and history when opening the codex to learn more about them. You'd at least somewhat care for your family members (there are none in this game, AFAIK) and the continuation of your family line. The UI sucks, map design sucks, city design is cheap, the units look roughly the same, etc. In a nutshell, it feels like a knock-off of the series.

Disclaimer: I've only played one Warhammer game prior but I love sci-fi/history/fantasy stuff. As a kid, this series was a part of the spark that fueled my interest in Medieval and Roman history. I thought this may have the same magical effect with the Warhammer games. Unfortunately, it only reaffirmed my decision to stop buying from them. Money is too tight now to waste on crap releases like this.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I enjoyed this game for hundreds of hours.
Yet I do not recommend to get it right now due to bugs with the new Intel CPU and coop crashes.

During Winter Sale I recommended this game to a friend. I praised the game and he finally decided to get it.
He can play it solo just fine. But the biggest selling point was the COOP. However we cant get the COOP campaign past turn 3 without the game crashing or corrupting the save for one player. Not just the two of us but it crashes with another player aswell. This never happened the years i enjoyed the game but is a known bug for the last few weeks ( maybe months). COOP Campaign is broken right now and a frustrating experience right now.

On top of that, the game is extremely buggy with the new Intel Alder Lake CPUs. I was able to play just fine with my 12 year old computer, but now that i got a new CPU the game crashes in solo game frequently. Sometimes it will not even start a brand new campaign.This is also a known bug.

In my opinion, the best Total War Game yet. I've played every single game in the series, going all the way back to Shogun: Total War. The modding scene is also very active for this game, with some really polished work on display.

And most importantly, playing as the Empire, I finally get to have my Renaissance/Pike&Shot: Total War.

This is probably the best total war game (maybe until immortal empires). 

There is a lot of DLC and cost you need for it to become that however. You do need the previous game, its DLC, this game and its DLC. Mortal Empires is an amazing experience, with generally fun mechanics for each race; however, you should wait for a sale to experience it unless you really don't care about money.

The AI isn't perfect but they do not blindly go into sieges with 5 dudes they will lose handily like I remember the Medieval II AI doing. The AI is heavily helped by cheats, especially on higher difficulties, but that's kinda to be expected. 

The Beauty of total war games is the combination of turn based 4X like strategy, and the real time battles. Combat is not just a numbers game or luck, your skill plays a pivotal role in success. You maneuver your troops, use abilities, and use the terrain to your advantage. Outside of combat you decide what troops and structures to build, what to research, with whom to engage in diplomacy, and move your armies. 

There really are not man games that combine these two elements., and that is what makes Total War special.

What makes Warhammer 2 special is the differences between each race. The magic and undead masses of the Vampire Courts, the familiar and varied armies of the Empire, the defensive nature of the Dwarves and so on. Not to mention how fun it can be to level, equip, and play with the Lords and heroes.
As a 40k fan, I approve. Balance could be better maybe. Fun tho

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.
Yes

I enjoy it. I wanted to wait until I have 100 hours of gameplay, and almost without realizing it, here we are. I have over 2k hours logged on Civilization 5 so I have a positive outlook on turn based settlement games.

I do not auto-resolve battles. And I recommend that you do not either. The combat (terrain and army formations) is second to none that I have played.

It is a mixture between turn-based settlement strategy and a RTS battle simulator. From what I can tell, the technology/building development trees are palpably unique per each race.

I have had the most fun playing co-op campaign with my good buddy. Spectator mode is even fun because you or he can point out areas of concern such as where enemies are charging towards units, or if a unit is standing idle.

I am more than satisfied with the game thus far and I look forward to pouring countless more hours into it.

"I liked this game at first but the more i play it the more I don't like it for several reasons.

I play on hard mode because normal will make me fall asleep and very hard and legendary are just silly.

The higher the difficulty, the more the ai cheats. It doesn't get smarter, it doesn't get better in battle, it cheats. and. I. hate. that. While it is cheating, you are also taking penalties to things like leadership for your units, upkeep, diplomacy, etc.

For instance:

Your army goes up against the dwarves, and they almost refuse to break and rout down to the last man for every unit. Now you play as the dwarves because you figure, hey that must be nice. Your dwarves will be mistaken for small children as they start to rout almost instantly at higher difficulties because of the leadership penalty and or you don't have other units flanking and cycle charging.

The higher the difficulty the more the upkeep costs. You can control a whole province (2 - 4 settlements) and barely afford one army on hard with mostly garbage units. Control two provinces and you can get some nice units in your army! Good luck defending them!

The AI can control one SETTLEMENT and have 2 and a half armies along with the garrison (3 and a half total armies). Making it INCREDIBLY frustrating trying to finish off factions with your single army.

The AI has more movement points than you can possibly spec into. Unless you are Vlad Von Carstein.The AI regularly ignores your armies and sprints through your lands raiding and razing to their hearts content because guess what? YOU WONT BE ABLE TO CATCH THEM. 

I've seen an enemy army leave their settlement, come into my territory, raze my settlement, adopt FORCED MARCH STANCE and go all the way back to their settlement so they can hide with their garrison. LUL. As the player, once you raze a settlement your turn is over, but not for the ai. Now my problem is not that they razed my settlement, my problem is, they don't have the same opportunity to be punished that i do.

The AI doesn't attack you unless they have overwhelming numbers. In that case there is little you can do. Now the devs recognize this so they put a skill in the game called lightning strike, THAT IS A MUST HAVE and only works when you attack. It allows you to ignore the enemies reinforcements and attack one enemy army 1v1 (very realistic btw this happens a lot in war). Nevermind that after the battle your units will be diminished and their reinforcements will just attack you next turn, destroying you anyway because they can afford ridiculous numbers. BUT LIGHTNING STRIKE. 

What's even cooler, is when engaging multiple enemy armies from the front on the campaign map, you can see them standing next to each other IN FRONT OF YOU, and on the battlefield, their reinforcements come in BEHIND YOU. It's a great feeling when your setup and plan for the battle goes out the window. It happens rarely but more than 0 times can ruin your entire campaign

The AI can recruit units they don't have the required buildings for. Orc factions recruting big un's 10 turns in, the vampires recruiting grave guard 20 turns in. The Tomb Kings recruiting well passed their building limits.

There are no navies in the game. You can't blockade ports, your army just becomes a ship when you move it on to water. You can't strangle the enemies economy. you can't target critical infrastructure. It doesn't matter because it doesn't affect how the ai plays.

Most cities on water have mandatory ports and only the major port cities offer the entire port building chain, so if you have a minor port city, the port takes up a building slot and you can't build it up all the way and its just awkward especially since you can't recruit anything with them

There are no unit formations. No wedges, testudos, phalanxes, shield walls, or loose unit formations to take less artillary/arrow damage. The game is just whoever controls the flanks with their boxes of units wins. AND. ITS. BORING. Boxes of units going against other boxes of units. And stats? don't matter. what matters is their traits like anti infantry, anti large, armor piercing, etc. rock. paper. scissors.

Ambush stance almost never works. don't even bother. i would say a clean 98% chance it won't work. Unless you are skaven or beastmen.

Regardless of difficulty the AI does not have fog of war. They can see everything you are doing. Want to send a fleet across the ocean and suprise attack the elves? They'll be waiting for you. RUINS. THE. FUN. If you take one wrong step because you can't see the enemy armies while they can see yours you will be surrounded and deleted.

Diplomacy = everyone hates your guts. The ai can confederate twice in the first 10 turns (absorb other factions of the same race that requires the player to have almost impossibly high diplomatic relations) meanwhile you will get laughed at asking for mutually beneficial trade deals by factions of your own race because of diplomatic penalties called aversion, and great power that you have for NO REASON. 

The best part about diplomacy is when a faction across the world declares war on you and sends all their armies your way. I've had factions completely ignore their own defense just to zerg me, another faction would be attacking and absorbing them on one side while they were attacking me. DUMB

The AI has zero problems with public order. They can be in a settlement with inhospitable climate, with me raiding them and they still, will have no issue with public order. Meanwhile i have to use precious building slots on buildings that only maintain public order. expect to use 1 - 2 each province JUST TO BREAK EVEN in public order. Anything that happens (enemy/neutral army trespassing/ enemy heroes trespassing/ corruption goes up because the beastmen are on your continent(?) expect a rebellion shortly. The only time i see rebellions for the ai are from vampiric, chaotic, and skaven corruption. As you can imagine the AI can spread like wildfire with confederations and no public order problems while you could not possibly dream of doing so ( i wouldn't want to do it that way, I just want things to be equal).

Units now have health bars! I almost didnt buy this game because of this alone. You can have a unit with almost all of their guys in the unit but have almost zero health. It is a site to see them all fall over at once when the unit health reaches zero or see routing units squeeze through enemy units instead of dying because they haven't reached the right health threshold.

Seiges. The towers have unlimited range, insane firing rate and will single handedly destroy your army if you don't charge the city the second you press start battle. Why would my army set up under enemy tower range to begin with? And when attacking units rout in a siege they RUN INTO THE CITY instead of out. LOL.

The best thing about this game are the large units and heroes but they manage to mess up heroes too.

Legendary Lords (LLs) that don't have mounts will lose to the weakest LLs that do have mounts. Even if you spec into buffing the hell out of your LL. GRIMGOR IRONHIDE the biggest baddest orc ever, the black orc that headbutt and shamed Archaeon the Everchosen, lord of the end times, loses to ANY mounted LL.

Auto Resolve is a laughing stock, you can have high end armies lose to basic units because one unit of enemy archers gets 300+ kills while another gets 200+ kills and so on. Then you fight the battle, because quicksave and those same archers will get 7 and 15 kills.

I can't recommend this game. The game in its entirety, costs WAY too much money to have so many things wrong with it. Save your money."

Alright this is a hard review to leave given I view Total War: Warhammer as a platform rather than just one game. If I could I would give it a stiff maybe, on the grounds that all of the content is going to be used in Immortal Empires.

WH1 and WH2 are amazing games and the mortal empires campaign has been giving me hundreds of hours of fun over the last few years. The races are refreshing and enjoyable to play. DLC content has kept the game fresh and expanded an already large map. However, if you want to play as every single faction be prepared to pay a hefty fee to do so. As a player who has bought new DLC typically at release, I have spent hundreds of dollars to date.

I've been lucky to see this series through to the end from start to finish. As a whole its better than any other Total War game (and I really loved Medieval II), the systems play beautifully and I rarely run into issues after all this time. Hopefully the developers can turn WH3 around and get it to the same state they did WH2.

Now for the bad. Because all the games are interconnected, there are factions that just simply haven't gotten enough love. Dwarfs, Warriors of Chaos, and several others have been left behind. It doesn't mean they are unplayable, but they don't have the same gimics and features that new factions have. Thankfully this should be taken care of by the time WH3 is completely finished. There is also a growing trend with several factions that have the attack ambush stance. This single feature can destroy even the strongest doom stack. Praise be to modders because if I get wiped by a Skaven ambush on turn 150 again I might just lose it.

All in all, the Total War: Warhammer saga is a joy to play, and I eagerly await the release of Immortal Empires to bridge all this great content together. Orrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr its gonna suck and I'll just come back to WH2 again lmfao.

Campaign... It's boring. If you're not a fanboy of the Warhammer stuff... then You'll probably not like this game. The politics are boring. I played this game for probably 200+ hours off of steam before deciding to purchase the entire TWWH1/2 catalog on steam (the base games and DLCs were on 75%/66%/50% sale)

If you can get everything for like $100 or less, I'd actually say it's a fair deal.  Normally I'd call a price like that grotesque and likely give the game a thumbs down, but TWWH2 (especially Mortal Empires) is pretty astonishing. I enjoy this game because of the challenge it provides.  The graphics and overall presentation are excellent.  The game mechanics are, for the most part, very well orchestrated and thought out.  With that said, there are things that could be improved on, mainly spell variety.  There are many Lores to choose from, but the spells within each lore is just a duplicate spell from a different lore.  The name may be different but it is essentially the same spell.  Overall, I would give the game two thumbs up and, if you like fantasy, I believe you would like this game too.

The apotheosis of strategy gaming.  The game that is in direct communication with both my inner 10-year-old, and my inner Napoleon Bonaparte.  Nearly infinite replayability, perfectly tuned mechanics, responsive controls, the best AI and diplomacy in the franchise.  And dinosaurs, and dragons, and elves, and knights, and elder gods, and vampire counts and...  I mean really.  Did I hype it too much?  Cause I'm kinda thinking not enough...  A true PC gaming masterpiece.  A++ gaming.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Honestly I am addicted to this game. First played Warhammer 3 and that was an atrocious piece of garbage. This on the other hand (and obviously because of it having been out for years) is a very fun game to play. There are some issues I tend to notice that really ruin the fun such as an AI running your army around in circles attempting to chase it otherwise they will destroy you from behind where you aren't protected, then while you're running around in circles after the one unit another faction that decided to go to war with you for no reason what so ever comes in an swoops away half your damn settlements forcing you to disband half your army because they end up making you go negative. That and AI on the other side of the map randomly declaring war on you because they have a stick up their a$$ for no reason in particular but the game calls it aversion... some instances of aversion make sense like orcs and humans (elves, dwarves), others don't but its more of a lore thing which I guess isn't too bad, except when that one faction all the way across the map in mortal empires decides to send a doomstack of overpowered units all the way over to you and annilate you after 20 turns. Another issue I have is far into the game  its like the smaller faction AI's just stop doing anything altogether. You got the major factions taking up 40-50 settlements and you're trying to get your 10 allied factions that are all underdogs to help you and they just sit there or basically spam peasant like units and attempt to go after the target you have set for them. I've had this game for a few weeks and have 111 hours but I honestly do love it. First got into Rome total war, and thanks to my brother I now have a Warhammer addiction.

UPDATE 2: EOS is here.  Thankfully, it can be disabled for TWWH2 with the good old Betas tab.  Basically, right click TWWH2 in your library, select properties, go to Betas, and select Cavalry Beta from the list.  BOOM, EOS is now gone.  Review changed to positive because while it's probably not intended to function that way, the betas tab indeed makes Epic optional.

UPDATE: Sadly despite updates providing enormous amounts of good new content I have to change my review to thumbs down for one reason: they forced Epic Online Services on TW:WH1.  I'm 99% sure TW:WH2 will soon follow suit, so I'm preemptively downvoting to show my dislike of this cancer infecting PC gaming.  Either keep it out of TW:WH2 or release the source code so that someone can make a sourceport without EOS infecting it.

My most played game since Civ V. By far the best Total War game to date. Faction diversity and unit responsiveness are unmatched. Hero system solves the problem of agents feeling disconnected from tactical battles without being as oppressive as in Troy or 3K. This is the rare game where I actively wanted more DLC for it, all of the packs for WH2, and most of the WH1 packs are well worth buying once you've played the main game. 

That said, this is not for everyone. Magic, monsters, and powerful lords and heroes often are the center of battles, and ranged and artillery units dominate, especially on higher difficulties. As a result, battles are decided faster than in previous titles. Siege gameplay is quite poor as well. Therefore, fans who prefer slower, more grindy infantry fights and more compelx street layouts should stick to Rome 2 or Atilla.

Higher difficulty just focuses on debuffing the player and buffing the AI as much as possible, which doesn't really make the game very difficult, since i have completed many legendary runs. After playing other grand strategy games i have noticed how shallow TW is. The land battles are quite good and the grand campaign map can played in multiple playthroughs.

The main reason that this is getting a negative review is that the updates for the game have been stopped and the last update made cavalry units useless. The teams have shifted to wh3 which imho is an inferior game with the next iteration of immortal empires being months away. Overall I have mixed feelings about this game, since after finding a big dissapointment in wh3 I tried to replay this but got bored in the end.

I've got about 500 hours in this game and almost as much watching people like LegendOfTotalWar and Majorkill, this game is seriously the best Total War Experience and single-handedly got me into Warhammer and Warhammer 40000. 

Plenty of replayability with all the races, each faction is different when it comes to their mechanics, and Mods add even more replayability and balance, 500 Hours and I still haven't even beaten every single campaign. 

co-op campaigns are a bit bland, since it's always just the same "Take X Settlements, Have X Amount Of Units" But since you're with a friend it's much more fun and two brains can take on the AI much easier. 

Don't let anyone tell you what difficulty to play on either ; I played most of mine on Normal - to get use to the factions, you don't have to play on Legendary Or Very-Hard unless you care about achievements. 

Beware Of the AI Bias on Higher Difficulties though.

A marvelous experience of strategy and fantasy that requires aditional content to really shine.

The Civilizations series meet Warcraft, creating a type of game that may not be the most enjoyable for people that do not like both aspects. The turnn-based global experience is alternated with real-time battles, that can be almost decided by the management on the big map and units deployed. 
As the base game only includes one campaign mode and four factions, it gives a limited time to enjoy. On the other hand, when adding DLCs and the first game, the experience really shines. Would not recommend buying it alone without discounts as it is quite expensive, but if the player likes this type of games, this is one of the most ambicious ones.

I start immediately by making the biggest distinction ever: TW:W is not 1 game. It's 2 completely different games that have NOTHING whatsoever to do with each other contained in the same product. FORTUNATELY they are very easily separable and one is NOT forced to play both of them. I underline FORTUNATELY.

Game 1: Battles. Battles are very interesting. It was completely new to me and I really enjoy the mechanics. You choose which units to put in your army, you may also build the enemy's army, you dispose the units on the battlefield, you send them into battle, you manage their movements, you match which units have an advantage against which and depending by your management you win or you loose a battle. You play, as a matter of fact, a military leader. In this game I also want to talk about the content of the game you pay for. So, speaking materially/artistically you pay for a rich multitude of 3d textured models, animations and atmospheres, not to talk about artistic design of these. These contents are VALUABLE, well done. There are many creatures, including dragons, manticores and monsters of all sorts. There are knights, warriors, vampires. You can play in various settings and with various elements, which all deliver different vibes. Seeing your armies clashing against those of the enemy by moving the camera is a joy for the eyes. This is where the product really shines, a lot of art and technical production articulated in an interesting battle dynamic. I LOVE the fact that you can play this game in custom battles, so when you want, without any burden and using ANY element you wish without having to unlock it through any boring process. You have to buy it, fine, but it's honest. You pay for content, not for illusions.

Game 2: Campaign. Boring. Deadly boring, and useless in my opinion. It's a completely different game that has NOTHING to do whatsoever with battles. The content you pay for is not actually this. I would define campaigns as a mortal trap to cripple the content you pay for by showing it to you in a dreadfully long sequence of repetitive non-interesting battles that you end up skipping with auto-resolve and having to deal with a game that you didn't actually want, the one of expansion in the territory and diplomacy and stuff. I mean... I just don't like to play that. It has nothing to do with the 3d models and the battle mechanics, it's a strategic game of land movements and timing based on turns which I really don't enjoy. I tried several hours of campaign both in WH1 and WH2 JUST because the map looked to good, but it wasn't enough to keep me playing. I totally discarded that side of the game and now I play just custom battles which is what I really like. FORTUNATELY I can do this. If I was forced to play battles only through the campaign, without having any option to do it separately, I would have never continued playing WH nor bought the sequel.

In conclusion, PLEASE keep focusing on custom battles with everything unlocked from the beginning and give campaigns a secondary importance if you really have to keep them. If it was for me I'd COMPLETELY remove campaigns form Warhammer and focus ALL the efforts on material contents to be played in custom battles. Where the game really shines is the art, the variety of elements that are materially present in the game and the battle mechanics, NOT the campaign. God, if they are beautiful. I always stare at creatures and warriors before clicking "start battle" and I admire the care for details and the special design. WH works best as a game that you are free to play as you want and when you want. There's no need for a quest line or turns or whatever else, really.

OK it's good, but the entire DLC system is money-grubbing crap. They changed nickle-and-diming into dollaring, seriously, some of the most basic DLCs cost $20.00, and many of them honestly should be included in the base game. So do the math, $60.00 for each of the 3 basic games, and then probably another $100.00 to the DLCs you want the most, that's almost $300.00 for a game. Crazy. But if you end up like me putting hundreds of hours into it, well, then you're getting your money's worth I guess.

Now, onto gameplay. It's good. This one fixes most of the issues that other TW games had (namely insanely bad tactical game AI and cheating campaign enemies). The only major gripe I have about the gameplay is that sometimes you'll be totally gangbanged in the first 20 turns because factions that have no real incentive to declare war on you, and which would never declare war on the AI in your position, will do so, and then beeline all their troops at you. This is fine unless you're trying a minor power and 2 majors do it to you. OK that's really my only complaint though.

So just realize that it's gonna cost you an arm and leg for the whole game before you buy. If you can do that with a clear head, then I recommend it.
Of all the Total War games. This one I play the most. Just the diversity of each nation is like playing a new game each time.

The game is decently fun, but mp is p2w, the AI is incredibly stupid, diplomacy is barebones and nonsensical (join war feature completely bypasses alliances and AIs that hate each other can still invite each other to join war against the player), basic troop movements are bugged (you can't go into encamp or ambush stances despite having enough movement points on the screen, until you remove your 'boost mobility hero' from the army), ambush battles frustratingly ignore context (it doesn't matter whether your army was encamped, recruiting, ambushing, or marching. If you get ambushed, the game puts your whole army into a single column march regardless), and there is significant variability in the quality of content for each race

I recommend buying this game on sale, and playing with significant number of mods which will help fix the content quality disparities and the broken diplomacy.

Also CA decided that putting intrusive ads in the main menu and removing multiplayer chat was more important than fixing a serious gamebreaking bug that causes the AI to not fight back when attacked by artillery. Not something that inspires faith in these devs.

I had this review as a negative one in light of issues with a recent update that added an ad to the main menu and broke several of my save files, however I feel this issue is unlikely to be repeated and has been resolved by a patch I noticed while going to boot up the game so I'll change my review for now. The ad while irritating goes away if you confirm you have a connected total war access account however if that is something you have an issue with it is present now when it wasn't before. The game itself is great, allowing you to play out epic fantasy battles in the world of Warhammer Fantasy Battles in real time  battles potentially hosting thousands of soldiers, heroes and monsters with a world map resembling a 4x strategy  game in the campaign from which to expand and build your empire, lay ambushes etc. In the base game there are 4 races with roughly three factions each (including free DLC factions) that you have access to with wildly different playstyles and if you happen to own its predecessor Total War: Warhammer you get access to a free combined campaign map with access to 9 races and a huge sand box of a map to play in which I highly recommend.

They seem to have patched the issues with old saves being unreadable but if you're still having those issues try this:
If anyone is having these issues you can do this right click on the game in your steam library-> properties -> betas -> Here you can load previous versions of the game and undo the update I'm currently playing on the cavalry fix beta and am able to access my saves through that.

Honestly, I can say that this game has taken more nights of gaming away from me than any other game I have played. Although the cost to enjoy ALL of the content is this game can be steep (if you are lucky you can wait until a steam sale / bundle), this game delivers on a wide variety of content and replay-ability. 

Total War: WARHAMMER II will take a toll on your system at times (although this is something which is has been drastically improved since the game's inception) and has a steep learning curve to those not familiar with Total War / lore curve to those not familiar with the franchise. Getting past though barriers however is one of the greatest joys a game can bestow. Learning how to properly place armies, mastering building tech chains, and enjoying the lore behind this wide variety of content more than makes up for the technical flaws this game sometimes brings up.

If you are a fan of strategy games, this one is a winner!

To kick things off, the hours I have into this game aren't even close to reflecting how much time I've put into this game. With that being said!

Pros:
-Extremely addictive, and immersive campaign map. (I mean it's absolutely huge.)
-Without having background information, the game does a really good job of giving you the *aesthetic* and *immersion* of each faction. I wasn't super well versed, but had a basic understanding of Warhammer Fantasy lore coming into these games, as I took to 40k a little more. For me the game did a great job of giving me a general sense of what each faction was fighting for.
-Combat is exciting! The clash of battle lines put me on the edge of my seat every time, and lets be honest, who doesn't enjoy a nice Cavalry charge, and watching little people fly across their screen.
-Mods! Oh how we love you independent modders making our lives so much easier.
-Warpstone Good-good kill man-thing.
-Do you think Lord Toyotamundi has a toilet in his Star Chamber? And if so, does he think about the Great Plan while taking a dump?


Cons:
-Nakai (Sorry Papa Croc.)
-Unit responsiveness feels a little... delayed for me sometimes. Maybe it's a user error since I only have like 3 brain cells, but in combat the units feel like they delay their actions in the most crucial moments for me.
-You have to pay for EVERYTHING. It's a Total War game, which is not new to me, so I kind of expected this one. Most of the DLC's are worth the purchase in my opinion, but do I feel like I should've paid for them? Not really. I'm looking at you, Blood DLC.
-This one is another personal issue I've run into here and there, but on the Campaign map, I'll have some issues attacking settlements and what not. Like, no shit hitting the attack button. I just can't do it. It's only happened a select few times, but the game has those bugs here and there. Completely ruined my campaign for me.

Overall:
Really great game. I honestly love it. It has it's imperfections like any Total War game, but it's a gem truly. If you're on the edge, I recommend getting it for sure. The replay-ability of this game is awesome, and I couldn't recommend this game more. You'll most definitely put multiple hours into this game, and spend days, if not weeks on just one campaign alone. Now go kill-die some man-things in the name of the Great Horned Rat!

I want to play this game but the load times are way to slow to make it worth it.  No, I am not going to buy a SSD because the company is to lazy to fix it.  I just wont play or ever buy another Total War Product.

The animations are personalised and vary quite a bit according to the units that are engaged; very immersive. 
The majority of armies function by their own unique method of play and that does translate to a tangible experience when switching from one to another. 


AI requires four major improvements; 
     
     1. Companies need to be able to disengage when ordered to. Presently, they generally require you to click multiple times at a 180 degrees from the point of contact. At times you have to click constantly until they separate. The front line of the company should have difficulty as they are engaged, but 1/2 to 3/4 of the troops who are simply waiting behind, should be able to follow the instruction immediately.  If you fight in real time that takes away valuable seconds from your direction. This leads to the next point. 

     2. Companies should try and flank another company automatically. Alternatively, allow the player to toggle the option per group. At least 50% of the company is idle waiting for your front line to die in order to advance forward. If they could walk forward in the manner drivers dodge traffic in the Philippines we would be golden; no lining up just fit where you can. Companies route when low in troops. If my own troop is superior, I could force another to dwindle down in numbers to reach a possible route much quicker if everyone is participating together. Liberating another company to assist elsewhere is the root goal. 

     3. To be persistent. You order your company to attack company A. Before reaching A they are engaged by company B. B is decimated and chooses to route off of the map. Your company should continue to A but instead they pursue B until they exit the map. The maps are large, it takes minutes for B to arrive at the borders of the map in order for them to exit the battlefield. I need that company to push another objective and they assure me when they are done pursuing ten guys or less, they will be right back in the action.  Later I find out that my lieutenant was lying because his company is AWOL, chilling at the map border waiting for better days.

     4. Enough of the clairvoyance. When ordering a company to attack another they are aware of that decision from the moment you click your mouse. You know this because they will immediately start to take evasive or offensive positions to counter that order. At times it would be impossible for these companies to know that they are the specific target of a group. Archers are the worst offenders of this. Delay the awareness and in the right situations, don't permit the AI to react fast enough or know that we are hiding in trees.

Brillaint game, if you love Total War, you'll love this. Once fleshed out with the DLC's, which do add up to a fair bit if you are coming in new and not buying them as they released, it's really something special.

It's Total War, so you already know how it works. This is a game of two halves: Battles and a 4X-style campaign. And the battles are great - they're spectacular, flexible, and accommodate both deep tactical min-maxing alongside brainlessly throwing random units together and watching the carnage unfold, with all the violent campiness that the Warhammer setting yields. There is a level of army roster and hero customisation and depth unprecedented for the series, enhanced by the relatively elaborate magic system of match-changing abilities, encompassing huge torrents of damage, powerful healing or necromancy spells, and strong buffs and debuffs. The lack of competition cements Total Warhammer 2's ability to produce unique encounters on the battlefield. The seemingly infinite pool of paired animations also reward pressing your nose up against single units, taking in the chaos of enormous monsters tearing poor peasants apart as armoured horses send infantry flying in violent charges and preposterously clothed lords elegantly duel on the frontline. The only major complaint of the battles is that the city siege maps are worthy of their infamous reputation as, boring, uninventive, buggy slogs that fall short of siege maps in previous Total War games, so hopefully the sequel's marketed improvements will be fruitful.

On the other hand, there's the campaign - specifically the overworld - which continues to be a huge detriment to the whole package. It's bad across the board, suffering from incompetent AI, little meaningful management, painfully obvious critical progression paths that decentivise experimentation or role-playing, and an inescapable air of staleness inherited from years of legacy mechanical design. There's no interesting storytelling or any particular depth or challenge, and other than the occasional touch of flavour, every campaign quickly ends up feeling the same through repetitive actions and tedious, shallow strategy.

I recommend this with the huge caveat to not expect to enjoy it as a 4X or grand strategy game, and instead solely on the strength of its battles and vibrant PvP skirmish scene.

An overall improvement upon what came before with expanded game modes as well as factions. I have played Total War games a lot over the years and this is one of the few that has called me back to it time and time again more than Shogun 2 ever has.  The community support behind the game is also amazing with some Workshop mods bringing a lot to the table (Check out The Simply Fun Overhaul (SFO) for example) and greatly increases the replay value of the game. I recommend it heavily for strategy game fans.

The only negative thing I can think to say about the game is that there is a bit of a learning curve for getting used to how each Faction plays and what their strengths and weaknesses are. The Eye of the Vortex game mode is probably the best experience for new players to get used to the game-flow as Mortal Empires can be intense with all the factions at the start, which means this is also a game that is going to need a good rig to run at optimal settings. 

Make sure your RAM can handle it folks!

Update 5 - 30/03/22 - TWWH3 is a sh*tshow. Despite everything WH2 is wonderful compared to it. If you want to buy one of the Warhammer games buy this one.

Update 4 - 24/11/21 - The last update to the game before the sequel broke several things (cavalary, ambushes, etc.) but only the cavalry was addressed. I say "addressed" because it was not fixed, CA just kinda of adjusted so the problem is not as drastic. The bugs caused by the update will not be fixed and only WH3 matters.

Update 3- 27/11/20 - The game is good. If the next update (on 03/12/20) screws the game like the last update did I will change this back to negative.

Update 2 - 29/06/20 - I was ready to change my review to positive. After seen all that CA was doing for the old factions I really wanted to say they redeemed themselves but this new update broke the game like no other did before. It has been more than a month and the "beta" fix not only fixed at best half of those bugs but also added it's own bugs that manage to be worse than the ones it fixed. The game is good, but if you don't want to deal with a game that is broken, fixed and broken again just buy something else.

Update 1 - 04/11/18 - The DLC came out some months ago. More bugs were introduced. All CA's communications are about Thrones of Britannia. Abandon all hope.

The game is a mess, unfortunately. Two months in and the bug fixing is abhorrent, with old bugs not been fixed (in some cases despite the fact that CA said they fixed it), the implementation of ME is just terrible, with half the new map been cut out, and just for clarification, if you think the smaller map is good all power to you, but if they had announced that prior to release (and thanks to the leaks we know they already knew the size would be this one) I would not have bought the game, and many more other problems.

As of right now they still have to implement one of the old races (Norsca) and fix a significant number of bugs that have been dragged since release.

The old factions feel dated compared to the new ones, and with so much to do, I don't think they will even try to fix those things.

Also, some mechanics are broken but shouldn't be. The chaos invasion on ME are just a recycled use of the invasions on the Vortex campaign (and they are not good there by the way) instead of using the old method from the first game. This game been just an extension of the first, why can't they use the same mechanics is beyond me.

If you can, avoid this game until is 50% off, with all the bugs fixed, in 6 months or something close to that (we hope).

The only thing that saves this mess is the awesome mod community that fix and improves where CA doesn't or can't (and they are extremely limited in what they can change since the mod support is also bad, been one of the main tools for moding made by moders because of lack of support).

CA said they learned from their previous mistakes, I believed in that and I was wrong. Now I learned from my mistake. I might update this after the updates they are promising come in.

Writing this now, as Warhammer 3 is out, but not worth purchasing yet. It would seem Creative Assembly rushed their production of this game's sequel, so I would recommend waiting for a Summer Sale, or until the release of Mortal Empires for Total War: Warhammer 3. 

THIS game, however, is excellent. I will say however that in order to get the full experience, there will probably be some gentle modding, and a LOT of DLC. Would definitely wait for a sale on a package deal though, because this game is absolutely worth it in it's entirety. 

A campaign map that is absolutely massive, with turn-based movement and simple but fun empire management. Each race is unique, with unique objectives and mechanics. A personal favorite of mine are the Beastmen as a faction, with Taurox in particular being a satisfying campaign to play. Just something about a screaming, 10-foot tall brass Minotaur dual wielding fire axes that makes me smile. I really smile when that self-same Minotaur literally dives face-first into a mob of Skaven rat men, sending most flying, but there are definitely a few that just... pop into gore fountains on impact. 

The campaign map is gorgeous, and every time one of your armies meets another in battle, you have the option to fight in real-time, or the game can auto-resolve the combat for you. Campaign objective battles are not able to be skipped, however, so you will be commanding troops in real-time. 

I have over 1200 hours of game play under my belt with no intention of stopping anytime soon, so yeah... I recommend it. 

Just wait for a sale unless you're in a place to buy the whole thing full-price. It really is a lot of DLC, but fortunately at least half of it seems to be free. Worth every dime either way though.
