I mean it's pretty great, gave me many hours of fun. DLC can get expensive but hell I thought it was worth it, There are always sales going on many times a year to get them on sale too. Even though I have moved on to Warhammer 3 I will never forget many awesome times involving this game, From my first  Tyrion Campaign when I thought I was doing great only to get steam rolled by the Dark Elves  120 turns in and lose to a hail of Black Arks and Dragons, or my first co-op campaign as the Dawi on mortal empires...endless turns of not knowing what to do and learning many things through trail and error with my friend, We finally got our empires strong only to have Arachaon come out of the fog of war and send our souls to the Chaos gods. Every single race from this game has given me a story or a shared memory with a friend,  I remember fighting what felt like an endless war against Chaos and Norsca as Karl Franz, bulking up Kislev with many armies and walls waiting for the waves to come, Or taking over the entire mortal empires map as good old Settra.  I have being the hero thousands of times, saving a weak faction or allies from utter annihilation and purging evil wherever it is found. I have also been the Harbinger of death, dooming entire Nations, Empires, even continents to the void. Watching allies burn just so I could take their land or laugh as they beg me for mercy every turn after I decided to wipe them out for the smallest slight against me. Epic victories, crushing defeats, with battles so close and intense it makes you wonder how you went from two armies on each side with thousands of troops, war-machines, magic, and beasts that will blow your mind down to a nail biting slug feast between the shattered remaining men, four horses, a fart of magic, one squad of missiles with only their bare knuckles left to throw, and a couple of LL's ready to duel to the death. It really is a sight to see, I have no doubt I will return to this game in the future but once Immortal Empires comes out it will be a sad day to uninstall this legend of a game.

[h1]I recommend this game... when it's on sale.[/h1]  Don't get me wrong, it's a good game and well done CA for it and TW 1. But the fact there's more DLC than a Paradox game (Which is saying something) and it costing $71 Canadian for me [b]not including[/b] DLC, it'd be impossible to get everything together unless you're either rich or got lucky with someone gifting you all this for free. But I will put up a few positives I have with this game.

First being the races and the wide variety of factions if you own anything related to it. There's almost everything in TW II: Elves, Lizardmen, Skaven, and countless others with the first game and along with both paid and free DLC.

Second being Mortal Empires. It's a sandbox mode that's fun to play in. While you have to own both games, I recommend you do so when it's on sale. Especially if you're playing as Grimgor and want to give chaos a good krumping. Or with Queek who is a monster when it comes to the near late game. (Had him take in almost every other Skaven factions and him ruling over the east side of the map one game.)

Third being the fact that this is keeping Warhammer Fantasy alive. (For those who don't know, Fantasy was a miniatures game alongside 40K but was ended a while ago and was unfortunately replaced with Age of Shitmar. It may not sound bad at first but that's until you realise that they took Fantasy and inserted some generic fantasy things in it. And even then, we still don't have new Skaven models for how long now?!) This game got me more into Fantasy and has me considering on buying Vermintide 2 given that it's Warhammer's take on Left 4 Dead but with Skaven.

But there's a few problems I'd like to highlight.

First and foremost being "the Blood god DLC". They took blood and gore, an option that comes free with any other game, and made it a paid DLC. Yeah, a bad idea in a nutshell. What makes it worse is the fact that they did so with their first one and are planning to do so in their third addition.

Second being the amount of DLC. Yes, a good portion of it's free but at the same time, this game has more DLC than a Paradox game. It's good but for quite a bit of money, it's not worth it short term. Like I said before, wait for sale then buy what you can.

Last being the campaign. [spoiler]The cutscenes look decent but for something that ends up devolving into a hold objective city from random Chaos Marauders until a set amount of turns. Then in the mid to late game, becomes a game of keep away the Skaven or everyone dies. The Vortex mission is a bit fun though with the powers and what not.[/spoiler]

To sum this long review up, buy it if you're interested and when it's on sale when you can along with it's DLC and the last one to play Mortal Empires.

I reviewed after 40 hours, a month or two after launch, but at this point I think it deserves a rewrite: 

The refinement done to this game over its years of release turned it from a decent-if-flawed followup to one of my favourite games of all time. At this time, with TWH3's flawed launch, it's perhaps good to look back at where TWH2 started and where it ended up.
